United States.name: AIPAC (American Israel Public Affairs Committee)
United States.description: Founded in 1951 by Isaiah Kenen. AIPAC is considered one of the most powerful lobbying organizations in the US. Holds an annual policy conference attended by thousands including most members of Congress. In 2022, AIPAC launched United Democracy Project, a super PAC that spent over $100 million supporting pro-Israel candidates. Does not donate directly to candidates but mobilizes grassroots support. Has approximately 100,000 members nationwide.

United States.name: American Jewish Committee (AJC)
United States.description: Founded in 1906 in response to pogroms in Russia. AJC is one of the oldest Jewish advocacy organizations in the US. It helped create the JDC (1914) and played a key role in the UN adoption of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Maintains offices in Washington, New York, Berlin, Paris, Brussels, and Jerusalem. Publishes the annual "State of Antisemitism in America" report. Led by Ted Deutch (former US Congressman) as CEO since 2022.

individuals.bio: Former US Congressman, CEO of AJC since 2022.

individuals.bio: Led AJC for 28 years as CEO.

individuals.name: Jacob Blaustein
individuals.bio: Industrialist and philanthropist who served as AJC president (1949-1954). Negotiated the historic Blaustein-Ben-Gurion Agreement defining US Jewish-Israel relations.

United States.name: American Jewish Congress
United States.description: Founded in 1918 by Rabbi Stephen Wise to give American Jews a democratic voice. Played a major role in the American civil rights movement and church-state separation litigation. Filed amicus briefs in landmark Supreme Court cases. Helped establish the World Jewish Congress in 1936. Though diminished from its peak influence, it remains an important voice in Jewish public affairs.

United States.name: Anti-Defamation League (ADL)
United States.description: Founded in 1913 by B'nai B'rith in response to the lynching of Leo Frank. Tracks and combats antisemitism and all forms of hate. Publishes the annual Audit of Antisemitic Incidents. Operates a Law Enforcement and Society program training police across the US. CEO Jonathan Greenblatt (former Obama administration official) has led the ADL since 2015. ADL has a budget exceeding $100 million and works with major tech companies on content moderation.

United States.name: Christians United for Israel (CUFI)
United States.description: Founded in 2006 by Pastor John Hagee with 10+ million members, making it the largest pro-Israel organization in the US. CUFI brings thousands of Christians to Washington annually for its summit. Advocates for strong US-Israel relations, opposes BDS, and supports Israel's biblical claim to the land. CUFI's Night to Honor Israel events are held in churches across America.

United States.name: J Street
United States.description: Pro-Israel, pro-peace advocacy organization founded in 2007 by Jeremy Ben-Ami. J Street lobbies the U.S. government on behalf of a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and has become a major counterweight to AIPAC within the American Jewish political landscape. The organization maintains a PAC (J Street PAC) that is one of the largest pro-Israel PACs in the country, endorsing and funding congressional candidates who support diplomatic solutions. J Street has faced controversy from both the right, which considers it insufficiently supportive of Israeli policies, and parts of the left who find it too centrist. It has strong ties to the Democratic Party and has been endorsed by numerous Jewish communal leaders.

United States.name: Jewish Council for Public Affairs (JCPA)
United States.description: Founded in 1944 as the National Jewish Community Relations Advisory Council. JCPA serves as the representative voice of the organized American Jewish community on public affairs and civic engagement. Coordinates a network of 125+ local Jewish Community Relations Councils (JCRCs) and 16 national Jewish agencies. Focuses on civil rights, Israel, combating antisemitism, and social justice.

United States.name: Jewish Democratic Council of America
United States.description: Founded in 2017, JDCA serves as the voice of Jewish Democrats. Led by CEO Halie Soifer, the organization advocates for Jewish values within the Democratic Party, including support for Israel and combating antisemitism. JDCA has emphasized that the majority of American Jews vote Democratic and that the party maintains strong pro-Israel positions.

United States.name: Republican Jewish Coalition
United States.description: Founded in 1985, the RJC promotes Jewish involvement in the Republican Party. Under the leadership of Matt Brooks (executive director since 1990s) and with major funding from Sheldon Adelson, the RJC has become a significant force in GOP politics. Hosts an annual leadership meeting in Las Vegas attracting Republican presidential candidates. Advocates for pro-Israel policies, tax reform, and school choice.

United States.name: Simon Wiesenthal Center
United States.description: Founded in 1977 by Rabbi Marvin Hier, named after famed Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal. Operates the Museum of Tolerance in LA (visited by millions). Publishes an annual Digital Terrorism & Hate report tracking online extremism. Maintains a list of most-wanted Nazi war criminals. Has 400,000+ member households worldwide. Dean and Founder Rabbi Hier delivered a prayer at President Trump's 2017 inauguration.

United States.name: StandWithUs
United States.description: International Israel education organization founded in 2001 by Roz and Jerry Rothstein in Los Angeles. StandWithUs combats antisemitism and delegitimization of Israel through campus advocacy, educational programs, and media campaigns across 19 offices worldwide. The organization runs the Emerson Fellowship, training college students as Israel advocates, and has been at the center of campus battles over BDS (Boycott, Divestment, Sanctions) movements. StandWithUs works closely with the Israeli government, receiving funding from the Ministry of Strategic Affairs, and partners with major Jewish organizations including Hillel and the Jewish Federations of North America.

United States.name: Zionist Organization of America (ZOA)
United States.description: Founded in 1897, ZOA is the oldest pro-Israel organization in the US. Led by Morton Klein since 1993, ZOA takes hawkish positions on Israel-Palestinian issues, opposes the two-state solution, and advocates against BDS. The organization has received support from major donors like Sheldon Adelson. ZOA hosts an annual gala dinner attracting top political figures.

United States.name: BlackRock
United States.description: Founded by Larry Fink (Jewish) in 1988 in a single room at Blackstone Group. BlackRock is now the world's largest asset manager with over $10 trillion in assets under management. The Aladdin risk management platform is used by institutions managing $20T+ in assets. BlackRock has been hired by the Federal Reserve and other central banks as an advisor. Fink is one of the most powerful figures in global finance.

Lutnick rebuilt the firm and created the Cantor Fitzgerald Relief Fund. He pledged 25% of Cantor's profits for 5 years to families of victims. Lutnick was named Commerce Secretary designate in the Trump administration in 2024. Major financial services firm in bond trading.

United States.name: PayPal
United States.description: Co-founded by Max Levchin (Jewish, born in Kyiv, Ukraine) and Peter Thiel in 1998. David Sacks (Jewish, South African-born) was COO. The "PayPal Mafia" is among the most influential networks in tech - alumni went on to found or lead Tesla, YouTube, LinkedIn, Yelp, Palantir, and Yammer. Acquired by eBay for $1.5B (2002), spun off in 2015. Now a $70+ billion fintech company processing $1.5 trillion per year.

FIDF's annual gala in New York is one of the largest Jewish fundraising events in the US, with single-night totals exceeding $60 million.

United States.name: American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC)
United States.description: Founded in 1914 to aid Jews in Palestine and war-torn Europe. JDC has since provided humanitarian assistance to Jews in over 70 countries, spending over $4 billion. Helped rescue and resettle Holocaust survivors. Rebuilt Jewish life in the Former Soviet Union. Currently provides welfare services to 80,000 elderly Jews in the FSU. Also runs non-sectarian disaster relief worldwide. JDC Entwine engages young Jewish professionals in global Jewish service.

United States.name: Charles and Lynn Schusterman Family Philanthropies
United States.description: Major Jewish philanthropic foundation established by Charles Schusterman, a Jewish-American oil and gas entrepreneur from Tulsa, Oklahoma, and continued by his wife Stacy and daughter Lynn Schusterman. The foundation has given over $3 billion to Jewish causes, Israel engagement, and education in the United States. It is a primary funder of Birthright Israel, ROI Community, and numerous Jewish campus initiatives. The Schusterman Family Philanthropies has been one of the most transformative forces in modern Jewish philanthropy, particularly in engaging young adults with Jewish identity and Israel. Lynn Schusterman has also been a major supporter of public education reform in Oklahoma.

United States.name: Jewish Funders Network

United States.name: The Jewish Museum (New York)
United States.description: Art and cultural museum located on Manhattan's Museum Mile at the former Warburg mansion on Fifth Avenue, exploring 4,000 years of art and Jewish culture. Founded in 1904 with a gift of 26 ceremonial objects to the Jewish Theological Seminary, it has grown into one of the world's preeminent Jewish museums with a collection of nearly 30,000 objects. The museum's exhibitions range from ancient archaeological artifacts to contemporary art, and have featured major retrospectives of artists like Marc Chagall, Amedeo Modigliani, and Modigliani. Its permanent collection includes works by leading 20th-century artists with Jewish connections. The museum occupies the Felix M. Warburg House, a 1908 Gothic Revival mansion donated by Frieda Schiff Warburg, connecting it to two of the most prominent Jewish banking dynasties in American history.

United States.description: The largest Jewish day school in the Washington, D.C. area, named after Charles E. Smith (Jewish), a prominent DC real estate developer. Located in Rockville, MD, it serves students from lower school through 12th grade. The student body reflects DC's unique community - children of government officials, diplomats, journalists, and policy professionals. Known for strong academics and Jewish studies.

United States.description: Founded in 1875 by Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise in Cincinnati, HUC-JIR is the oldest Jewish seminary in the Americas. Operates on four campuses: Cincinnati, New York, Los Angeles, and Jerusalem. Ordained the first woman rabbi (Sally Priesand, 1972) and first openly gay rabbi. Houses the American Jewish Archives and significant archaeological collections from Israel.

United States.name: Heschel School (NYC)
United States.description: Named after Rabbi Abraham Joshua Heschel (1907-1972), the legendary Jewish theologian who marched with Martin Luther King Jr. at Selma. The Abraham Joshua Heschel School is a progressive, transdenominational Jewish day school in Manhattan serving Pre-K through 12th grade. Known for social justice education, arts, and environmental stewardship. One of NYC's most sought-after progressive Jewish schools.

United States.name: Hillel International
United States.description: Foundation for Jewish campus life, engaging college students at more than 550 campuses worldwide. Founded in 1923 at the University of Illinois by Rabbi Benjamin Frankel, Hillel is the largest Jewish campus organization in the world. Named after the ancient Jewish sage Hillel the Elder, the organization provides religious, cultural, social, and Israel-related programming. Hillel's engagement model reaches hundreds of thousands of students annually. The organization has faced debates about its Israel guidelines, which restrict partnerships with groups that support BDS. Major funders include the Charles and Lynn Schusterman Family Philanthropies, the Jim Joseph Foundation, and billionaire philanthropist Lynn Schusterman. Edgar Bronfman Sr. served as a transformative board chair.

JTS ordained its first woman rabbi, Amy Eilberg, in 1985.

Now reaching 680,000+ children in 35 countries. "PJ" stands for "pajamas" - the idea of parents and children reading together at bedtime. The program has distributed over 20 million books and is widely considered one of the most successful Jewish engagement initiatives.

United States.description: Founded in 1937 by Rabbi Joseph Lookstein, Ramaz is a prestigious K-12 Modern Orthodox day school on Manhattan's Upper East Side, affiliated with Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun. Known for academic excellence, with graduates regularly attending Ivy League universities. Named after Rabbi Moses Zevulun Margolies ("Ramaz"). SAR High School, founded by Rabbi Tully Harcsztark, is known for its innovative "open Orthodox" approach to Jewish education. SAR Academy serves K-8 students. The school emphasizes critical thinking, intellectual openness, and commitment to halacha (Jewish law). Recognized as one of the best Jewish day schools in America.

United States.description: A network of approximately 60+ Jewish day schools across North America affiliated with the Conservative movement. Named after Solomon Schechter (1847-1915), who led JTS and discovered the Cairo Genizah. Schools provide dual curriculum of rigorous secular and Jewish studies. Schechter schools have produced generations of engaged Conservative Jewish leaders. The network is managed by the Schechter Day School Network.

United States.description: Part of the network of 15 URJ (Reform movement) summer camps across North America. URJ camps serve over 10,000 campers annually and are considered the Reform movement's most effective tool for building Jewish identity. Alumni of URJ camps disproportionately become Reform rabbis, cantors, and communal leaders. Camps emphasize music, prayer, social justice, and joyful Jewish living.

United States.name: Yeshiva University
United States.description: Private Orthodox Jewish university in New York City, founded in 1886, and the oldest Jewish university in the United States. Yeshiva University combines secular academic programs with intensive Torah study, operating the prestigious Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine until its sale to Montefiore in 2019. The university has produced generations of Modern Orthodox rabbinical and lay leaders, and its rabbinical seminary (RIETS) ordains more Orthodox rabbis than any institution in America. Notable alumni include Senator Joe Lieberman, novelist Chaim Potok, and Rabbi Joseph Soloveitchik, one of the most influential Orthodox thinkers of the 20th century. YU has been at the center of debates about the intersection of Orthodoxy and modernity, including recent Supreme Court cases regarding LGBTQ student groups.

United States.name: 20th Century Fox (historic founding)
United States.description: Major film studio born from the merger of William Fox's Fox Film Corporation and Twentieth Century Pictures (founded by Joseph Schenck and Darryl Zanuck). William Fox (born Vilmos Fuchs), a Jewish-Hungarian immigrant, pioneered the movie theater chain model and the newsreel. He developed the sound-on-film technology (Movietone) that competed with Warner Bros.' Vitaphone. Fox lost control of his company during the Great Depression. Darryl Zanuck, while not Jewish himself, was deeply connected to the Jewish film community and ran the studio for decades, producing classics like The Grapes of Wrath, All About Eve, and The Sound of Music. The studio was acquired by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation in 1985 and later by Disney in 2019 for $71.3 billion.

United States.name: A&M Records (historic)
United States.description: Co-founded in 1962 by Herb Alpert (Jewish) and Jerry Moss (Jewish) in Alpert's garage. A&M became one of the most successful independent labels in history, signing The Police, Janet Jackson, Peter Frampton, Cat Stevens, and The Carpenters. Sold to PolyGram for $500 million in 1989. Alpert became the best-selling instrumentalist of the 20th century. Both founders donated $30M+ to UCLA's Herb Alpert School of Music.

United States.name: A24 Films
United States.description: Independent entertainment company founded in 2012 by Daniel Katz, David Fenkel, and John Hodges, which has become one of the most acclaimed studios in modern cinema. Katz and Fenkel are Jewish. A24 has produced and distributed numerous critically acclaimed and commercially successful films including Moonlight (Best Picture winner), Everything Everywhere All at Once (Best Picture), Lady Bird, Uncut Gems (starring Adam Sandler as a Jewish diamond dealer in NYC), and Ex Machina. The studio has redefined independent film distribution and has developed a cult-like following among cinephiles. A24 also produces television shows including Euphoria.

United States.name: Alfred A. Knopf
United States.description: Prestigious publishing house founded in 1915 by Alfred A. Knopf (Jewish) and his wife Blanche Knopf, known for its distinctive Borzoi imprint. The Knopfs built one of the most respected literary publishers in American history, championing authors including Albert Camus, Langston Hughes, Willa Cather, Gabriel Garca Mrquez, Toni Morrison, and Haruki Murakami. Alfred Knopf brought European and world literature to American audiences and set new standards for book design and production quality. The publisher was acquired by Random House in 1960 and is now part of Penguin Random House. Sonny Mehta served as editor-in-chief from 1987 until his death in 2019, continuing the tradition of literary excellence.

United States.name: Atlantic Records
United States.description: Major record label founded in 1947 by Ahmet Ertegun (Turkish, not Jewish) and Herb Abramson (Jewish). Jerry Wexler (Jewish), who joined as a partner in 1953, coined the term "rhythm and blues" and produced landmark recordings by Aretha Franklin, Ray Charles, and Led Zeppelin. Atlantic was instrumental in bringing African-American music to mainstream audiences and was a cornerstone of the civil rights era's cultural revolution. Jewish executives including Jerry Greenberg and Craig Kallman (current chairman) have led the label. Atlantic is now part of Warner Music Group, owned by Jewish-Ukrainian-American billionaire Len Blavatnik.

Bloomberg L.P. also operates Bloomberg News, Bloomberg TV, Bloomberg Radio, and Bloomberg Businessweek. Bloomberg served as NYC Mayor (2002-2013). United States.name: Columbia Pictures (historic founding)
United States.description: Major film studio founded in 1924 by Harry Cohn and his brother Jack Cohn, along with Joe Brandt - all Jewish Americans. Harry Cohn ran the studio with an iron fist for over three decades, earning the nickname "King Cohn." Under his leadership, Columbia produced classic films including It Happened One Night (the first film to sweep all five major Academy Awards), Mr. Smith Goes to Washington, and From Here to Eternity. Columbia was unique among the major studios for lacking a theater chain, relying solely on film quality. The studio was acquired by Sony in 1989 for $3.4 billion, marking one of the first major Japanese acquisitions of American entertainment property.

Contributors included Hannah Arendt, Irving Kristol, Norman Mailer, and Saul Bellow. Currently edited by John Podhoretz (Norman's son).

United States.name: Paramount Pictures (historic founding)
United States.description: Major film studio founded by Adolph Zukor, a Jewish immigrant from Ricse, Hungary, who arrived in America as an orphan with $25 sewn into his vest. Zukor founded Famous Players Film Company in 1912, which became Paramount Pictures. He pioneered the feature-length film format and the star system, signing Mary Pickford and other early film legends. Jesse L. Lasky (Jewish) co-founded the Jesse L. Lasky Feature Play Company, which merged with Zukor's company. Zukor led Paramount for decades, living to age 103. Under Barney Balaban (Jewish), Paramount became one of the most profitable studios. The studio's history exemplifies the Jewish immigrant experience in building Hollywood from nothing.

United States.name: The New York Times Company
United States.description: Controlled by the Sulzberger family (Jewish) since Adolph Ochs (Jewish) bought the paper in 1896. A.G. Sulzberger (5th generation) is the current publisher. The Times has won 132 Pulitzer Prizes - more than any news organization. "All the News That's Fit to Print" has been the masthead motto since 1897. Now a digital-first company with 10+ million subscribers. Acquired The Athletic, Wirecutter, and Wordle.

TOI has become one of the most-read English-language Israeli news sources, attracting millions of monthly readers. Early investment from Seth Klarman (Baupost Group). Publishes in English, Arabic, French, and Persian. Known for its blogs platform featuring thousands of contributors.

United States.name: The Walt Disney Company
United States.description: While Walt Disney himself was not Jewish, Disney has been led by Jewish executives for decades. Michael Eisner (Jewish, CEO 1984-2005) grew Disney from $1.8B to $60B market cap. Bob Iger (Jewish, CEO 2005-2020, 2022-present) acquired Marvel ($4B from Ike Perlmutter, Jewish/Israeli), Pixar ($7.4B), Lucasfilm ($4B), and 21st Century Fox ($71B). Jeffrey Katzenberg (Jewish) ran the studio during the Disney Renaissance (Little Mermaid, Lion King, Beauty and the Beast).

United States.name: The Washington Post
United States.description: Purchased in 1933 by Eugene Meyer (Jewish), first president of the World Bank. His daughter Katherine Graham (Jewish father) became publisher and the first female Fortune 500 CEO. Under Graham, the Post broke the Watergate story. Jeff Bezos bought the paper in 2013 for $250M. The Meyer-Graham family led the Post through its most influential era in American journalism.

United States.name: Universal Music Group (US operations)
United States.description: The US arm of Universal Music Group, the world's largest music company (~30% global market share). CEO Sir Lucian Grainge (Jewish, British) has led UMG since 2011. UMG owns Interscope, Def Jam, Republic, Capitol, Island, Motown, Geffen, and dozens of other labels. Artists include Taylor Swift, Drake, Billie Eilish, and The Weeknd. UMG went public in 2021 at a $40+ billion valuation.

United States.name: Universal Pictures (historic founding)
United States.description: Major film studio founded in 1912 by Carl Laemmle, a Jewish immigrant from Laupheim, Germany, who started by opening one of the first nickelodeons in Chicago. Laemmle created Universal City Studios - the first-ever planned film studio community. He is credited with creating the "star system" by publicizing actress Florence Lawrence's name. Laemmle's nephew, William Wyler (Jewish), became one of Hollywood's greatest directors. Universal pioneered the horror genre with Frankenstein and Dracula. Laemmle famously used affidavits to rescue over 300 Jewish families from Nazi Germany. The studio went through multiple ownership changes and is now part of Comcast's NBCUniversal, where Jewish executives have continued to play leadership roles.

United States.name: ViacomCBS / Paramount Global
United States.description: Controlled by the Redstone family through National Amusements. Sumner Redstone (Jewish, born Rothstein, 1923-2020) built a media empire. His daughter Shari Redstone (Jewish) merged Viacom and CBS in 2019. Owns Paramount Pictures, MTV, Nickelodeon, BET, Comedy Central, Showtime, and CBS. In 2024, Paramount merged with David Ellison's (Jewish, son of Oracle's Larry Ellison) Skydance Media in a $8B deal.

United States.name: Warner Bros. Discovery
United States.description: Global media and entertainment conglomerate formed by the 2022 merger of Warner Bros. and Discovery, Inc. Warner Bros. was originally founded in 1923 by four Jewish brothers - Harry, Albert, Sam, and Jack Warner - who were sons of Polish-Jewish immigrants. The studio was a pioneer of the "talkie" era, producing The Jazz Singer (1927), the first feature-length talking picture. Today the company encompasses HBO, CNN, DC Comics, Warner Bros. Pictures, Discovery Channel, and numerous other media properties. David Zaslav, the CEO, oversees a media empire that reaches billions of people worldwide. The company's Jewish founding and ongoing leadership connections make it a cornerstone of Jewish involvement in the entertainment industry.

United States.name: Warner Bros. Pictures (historic founding)
United States.description: Major film studio founded in 1923 by the four Warner brothers,Harry, Albert, Sam, and Jack,Jewish immigrants from Krasnosielc, Poland. The Warners revolutionized cinema by producing The Jazz Singer (1927), starring Al Jolson, the first feature-length "talking picture," which ended the silent film era. The studio became known for gritty, socially conscious films including gangster movies, musicals, and war films. Warner Bros. was also the first studio to explicitly take on Nazi Germany in films like Confessions of a Nazi Spy (1939). Harry Warner was fiercely anti-Nazi and used the studio as a vehicle for anti-fascist messaging. The studio's legacy represents the foundational role of Jewish immigrants in creating Hollywood.

United States.name: Warner Music Group
United States.description: One of the "Big Three" major record labels, owned by Access Industries, the conglomerate of Jewish-Ukrainian-American billionaire Len Blavatnik. Blavatnik, born in Soviet Ukraine and educated at Harvard, acquired Warner Music for $3.3 billion in 2011 and took it public again in 2020. Warner Music Group encompasses Atlantic Records, Warner Records, Elektra, and numerous other labels, representing artists from Ed Sheeran to Cardi B. Blavatnik is one of the wealthiest people in the UK and a major philanthropist, donating to Jewish causes, Oxford University (Blavatnik School of Government), and the arts. Warner Music's Jewish founding and current ownership reflects decades of Jewish involvement in the music industry.

United States.description: Led by Ari Emanuel (Jewish, Israeli-American), CEO of Endeavor/WME. Ari is the brother of Rahm Emanuel (former Obama Chief of Staff, Chicago mayor, US Ambassador to Japan). WME formed from the 2009 merger of Endeavor and the historic William Morris Agency (founded 1898). Endeavor owns UFC ($4B acquisition), IMG, and Professional Bull Riders. One of the most powerful talent agencies in the world.

United States.name: Calvin Klein (PVH Corp)
United States.description: Global fashion house known for its minimalist aesthetic, founded in 1968 by Calvin Klein, a Jewish-American designer from the Bronx. Klein revolutionized American fashion with his clean lines and provocative advertising campaigns, including iconic jeans ads featuring Brooke Shields and Mark Wahlberg. The brand, now part of PVH Corp (led by Jewish CEO Stefan Larsson until 2021), generates billions in annual revenue across fashion, fragrance, and home products. Calvin Klein's innovations in designer jeans, underwear, and fragrance marketing transformed the fashion industry and established the model for modern lifestyle branding.

United States.name: Donna Karan / DKNY
United States.description: Iconic American fashion brand founded in 1984 by Donna Karan (ne Faske), a Jewish-American designer from Queens, New York. Karan revolutionized women's professional fashion with her "Seven Easy Pieces" system of interchangeable basics. She launched the more affordable DKNY line in 1989, bringing high fashion sensibility to a broader market. Karan's designs dressed multiple First Ladies and defined the power-dressing era of the 1980s and 1990s. She sold her company to LVMH in 2001, and the brand is now owned by G-III Apparel Group. Karan has been a major philanthropist, founding the Urban Zen Foundation focused on wellness, education, and preserving cultures.

The Lauder family remains in control: Leonard Lauder (chairman emeritus, $30B+ fortune, major art donor to the Met) and Ronald Lauder (World Jewish Congress president). United States.name: Levi Strauss & Co.
United States.description: Founded by Levi Strauss (Jewish, Bavarian immigrant) in 1853 in San Francisco. Strauss and Jacob Davis (Jewish, Latvian immigrant) invented and patented riveted blue jeans. Blue jeans became one of the most iconic American cultural exports. Levi Strauss & Co. is now a $6B+ public company. The founding of Levi's represents one of the most successful immigrant entrepreneurship stories in American history.

United States.name: Revlon
United States.description: Founded in 1932 by Charles Revson (Jewish) and his brother Joseph. Revlon revolutionized the cosmetics industry by matching nail polish to lipstick colors. In 1985, Ronald Perelman (Jewish) acquired Revlon in a famous hostile takeover for $2.7 billion. The company struggled financially and filed for bankruptcy in 2022. At its peak, Revlon was one of the most recognized beauty brands in the world.

United States.name: Hagen-Dazs
United States.description: Premium ice cream brand founded in 1960 by Reuben and Rose Mattus, Jewish-Polish immigrants in the Bronx, New York. The name "Hagen-Dazs" is entirely fabricated - the Mattuses created a Scandinavian-sounding name to convey an image of Old World craftsmanship and purity, even including a map of Denmark on early packaging. The brand pioneered the super-premium ice cream category, using only the finest natural ingredients. Reuben Mattus was a committed Zionist, and the brand's early growth was supported by Jewish community networks. Hagen-Dazs was sold to Pillsbury in 1983 and is now owned by General Mills. The brand generates over $2 billion in annual global sales.

United States.name: Kind Snacks
United States.description: Founded by Daniel Lubetzky (Jewish, Mexican-born, son of a Holocaust survivor from Dachau) in 2004. KIND grew into a billion-dollar snack brand. Mars Inc. acquired a majority stake. Lubetzky also founded PeaceWorks to promote Israeli-Palestinian economic cooperation and Empatico for global classroom connections. His father's Holocaust survival deeply influenced his mission of kindness and tolerance.

United States.name: Manischewitz
United States.description: Producer of kosher foods since 1888, best known for matzo and Passover products. Founded by Rabbi Dov Behr Manischewitz, a Lithuanian-Jewish immigrant, in Cincinnati, Ohio. Manischewitz became the largest matzo manufacturer in the world, with its matzo-baking facility in Jersey City producing millions of pounds annually. The brand name has become virtually synonymous with Passover in American culture. The company also produces Manischewitz wine, one of the most recognizable kosher wines despite its reputation as overly sweet. The brand has been sold multiple times and is now owned by the Kayco/Kedem food conglomerate. Manischewitz represents one of America's oldest Jewish consumer brands.

United States.name: Nathan's Famous
United States.description: Iconic hot dog company founded in 1916 by Nathan Handwerker, a Jewish immigrant from Galicia (modern-day Poland), who opened a nickel hot dog stand on Coney Island, Brooklyn. Handwerker, who had worked for Charles Feltman's restaurant, undercut Feltman's ten-cent hot dog with his five-cent version, using a recipe reportedly seasoned by his wife Ida. Nathan's Famous became an American institution, and the annual Nathan's Hot Dog Eating Contest on July 4th is one of the most-watched competitive eating events in the world. The company went public in 1993 and now has over 250 restaurants and a major retail division selling products in supermarkets nationwide.

United States.name: Sabra Hummus
United States.description: Leading hummus brand in the United States, originally a joint venture between PepsiCo and the Strauss Group, an Israeli food conglomerate. Sabra was founded in 1986 by a Jewish family in Queens, New York, and takes its name from the Hebrew term for a Jewish person born in Israel. The brand controls approximately 60% of the U.S. hummus market, helping transform hummus from an ethnic specialty into a mainstream American snack. Sabra has been a frequent target of BDS (Boycott, Divestment, Sanctions) campaigns due to its Israeli connections, particularly the Strauss Group's past support of the IDF. In 2023, PepsiCo acquired full ownership.

United States.name: Starbucks
United States.description: Global coffeehouse chain and coffee company founded in 1971 in Seattle. While not founded by Jewish individuals, Starbucks was transformed into a global phenomenon by Howard Schultz, a Jewish American businessman who joined the company in 1982 and served as CEO (1986-2000, 2008-2017, 2022-2023). Schultz, the son of a World War II veteran who grew up in a Brooklyn housing project, built Starbucks from 11 stores to over 35,000 locations in 80 countries. He introduced the Italian espresso bar concept and pioneered employee benefits including health coverage for part-time workers and stock options. Schultz has been a prominent Jewish-American business leader, briefly exploring a presidential run in 2019, and has been a supporter of Israel and Jewish causes.

individuals.name: Howard Schultz

United States.name: Taro Pharmaceutical Industries (US)

Taro became a subsidiary of Sun Pharmaceutical Industries in 2010 after a protracted acquisition battle. The company specializes in dermatological products, generic pharmaceuticals, and OTC medications, with manufacturing facilities in Israel, the U.S., and Canada. Taro represents a key example of Israeli pharmaceutical innovation expanding into the American market. The company has been involved in price-fixing litigation in the U.S. generic drug industry.

United States.name: Bain Capital
United States.description: Private investment firm founded in 1984 by Mitt Romney, T. Coleman Andrews III, and Eric Kriss, among others. While Romney is not Jewish, several of Bain's most prominent partners and co-founders are, including Joshua Bekenstein (co-chairman) and Marc Wolpow. The firm manages approximately $180 billion in assets across private equity, ventures, public equity, credit, real estate, and other strategies. Bain Capital has invested in major companies including Domino's Pizza, Staples, Burlington Coat Factory, and Clear Channel (now iHeartMedia). The firm became politically prominent during Romney's 2012 presidential campaign, sparking national debates about private equity's role in the economy.

United States.name: Goldman Sachs
United States.description: Major global investment bank and financial services company, founded in 1869 by Marcus Goldman, a German-Jewish immigrant, and later joined by his son-in-law Samuel Sachs. Goldman Sachs has been one of the most powerful financial institutions in the world, with enormous influence on global markets, government economic policy, and corporate finance. The firm has produced multiple U.S. Treasury Secretaries, including Robert Rubin, Hank Paulson, and Steven Mnuchin. CEO Lloyd Blankfein (2006-2018) and current CEO David Solomon are both Jewish. The firm manages over $2.5 trillion in assets and has been central to virtually every major financial event of the modern era, from IPOs of tech giants to the 2008 financial crisis. Goldman's culture of alumni in government has earned it the nickname "Government Sachs."

He purchased the New York Mets in 2020 and is a major art collector and philanthropist.

United States.description: Joseph Flom (Jewish) joined tiny Skadden Arps and built it into the world's most profitable law firm. Flom essentially invented the modern M&A legal practice and pioneered hostile takeover defense. Revenue exceeds $3 billion annually. The firm represents the pinnacle of Jewish achievement in American law - Flom rose from the immigrant Lower East Side to dominating Wall Street law.

United States.name: Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz
United States.description: Elite New York law firm founded in 1965 by Herbert Wachtell, Martin Lipton, Leonard Rosen, and George Katz - all Jewish attorneys. Wachtell Lipton is consistently ranked as the most prestigious and highest-grossing law firm per lawyer in the world, with partners earning multi-million dollar annual compensation. Martin Lipton invented the "poison pill" corporate defense mechanism in 1982, fundamentally changing the landscape of mergers and acquisitions law. The firm exclusively handles the largest and most complex corporate transactions, advising on deals worth trillions of dollars. Despite having only about 270 lawyers (compared to thousands at other major firms), Wachtell commands extraordinary influence in corporate America and has shaped modern takeover law.

United States.name: Notable Jewish Entertainers (US)
United States.description: Jewish Americans have shaped American entertainment from its earliest days. Every major Hollywood studio was founded by Jewish immigrants (Warner, Paramount's Zukor, Universal's Laemmle, Fox's William Fox, MGM's Mayer). Broadway was defined by Jewish composers (Gershwin, Rodgers, Hammerstein, Sondheim, Berlin). American comedy was built by Jewish comedians (Marx Brothers, Mel Brooks, Jerry Seinfeld, Larry David). Television's golden age was created by Jewish writers and producers.

United States.name: Notable Jewish Media Executives (US)
United States.description: Prominent Jewish figures who have led major American media companies and shaped the information landscape. This includes Bob Iger (Disney CEO), Jeff Zucker (CNN president), Jeff Shell (former NBCUniversal CEO), David Zaslav (Warner Bros. Discovery CEO), Shari Redstone (Paramount Global), the Sulzberger family (New York Times owners for generations), the Newhouse family (Cond Nast/Advance Publications), Mort Zuckerman (U.S. News & World Report, New York Daily News), and many others. Jewish leadership in American media has been a subject of both academic study and antisemitic conspiracy theories, though it reflects the community's historical emphasis on education, communication, and cultural participation.

United States.name: Notable Jewish Philanthropists (US)
United States.description: Prominent Jewish philanthropists who have shaped American charitable giving and Jewish communal life. This includes figures like Michael Bloomberg ($11.8B in total giving), George Soros (over $32 billion given away through Open Society Foundations), Sheldon Adelson (massive political and Israel-related donations), the Lauder family (cosmetics fortune supporting Jewish heritage), the Marcus family (Home Depot co-founder Bernie Marcus's billions for medical research, veterans, and Israel), and Lynn Schusterman (Jewish education and youth engagement). Jewish Americans, who comprise roughly 2% of the U.S. population, are estimated to account for over 25% of total charitable giving in the country.

United States.name: Durst Organization
United States.description: Family-owned New York City real estate company founded in 1915 by Joseph Durst, a Jewish immigrant from Austria-Hungary. The Durst family has built and owned some of Manhattan's most significant commercial towers, including One World Trade Center (which the Dursts co-developed with the Port Authority) and the Bank of America Tower. The family gained notoriety through Robert Durst, the black sheep of the family who was convicted of murder in 2021. Douglas Durst, who leads the company, has been a pioneer in green building practices. The organization owns or manages over 13 million square feet of prime Manhattan office space valued at billions of dollars.

United States.description: Co-founded by Adam Neumann (Israeli Jewish, born on a kibbutz) and Miguel McKelvey in 2010. Neumann served in the Israeli Navy. WeWork was once valued at $47 billion before its dramatic collapse. SoftBank invested over $10 billion. Neumann's wife Rebekah (Jewish, cousin of Gwyneth Paltrow) was chief brand officer. Neumann later started Flow, backed by Andreessen Horowitz.

United States.description: Founded in 1922, Agudath Israel is the primary advocacy organization for the Haredi (ultra-Orthodox) Jewish community in America. Guided by the Moetzes Gedolei HaTorah (Council of Torah Sages). Advocates for government funding for religious schools, religious liberty, and community interests. Popularized the Daf Yomi program (daily Talmud study). The 2020 Siyum HaShas at MetLife Stadium drew 90,000+ attendees.

United States.name: Central Conference of American Rabbis (CCAR)
United States.description: Founded in 1889 by Rabbi Isaac Mayer Wise, CCAR is the oldest and largest rabbinical organization in North America with over 2,000 members. Publishes the Reform movement's official liturgy including Mishkan T'filah. In 1972, CCAR member Sally Priesand became the first woman ordained as a rabbi in America. CCAR has issued responsa (Jewish legal opinions) on contemporary issues including LGBTQ+ inclusion.

United States.name: Chabad-Lubavitch
United States.description: Founded in 1775 in Russia by Rabbi Schneur Zalman of Liadi. Under the 7th Rebbe, Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson (1902-1994), Chabad became the largest Jewish outreach organization in the world with 3,500+ emissary families in 100+ countries. Operates Chabad houses on hundreds of college campuses. Congress has proclaimed "Education and Sharing Day" in the Rebbe's honor since 1978. Annual budget estimated at $1 billion+. Headquarters at 770 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

United States.name: Congregation Shearith Israel (NYC)
United States.description: The first Jewish congregation in North America, founded in 1654 by 23 Sephardic Jews who arrived from Brazil. Known as the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue. Members fought in the American Revolution and prayed for George Washington. Located on Central Park West. The congregation maintains the Sephardic liturgical tradition and has been in continuous operation for over 370 years. A cornerstone of American Jewish history.

The congregation is known for its sophisticated, educated membership and its role as a standard-bearer for Modern Orthodox life in New York City.

United States.name: Reconstructing Judaism
United States.description: The smallest of the four major Jewish denominations in the US, with approximately 100 congregations. Founded on the philosophy of Rabbi Mordecai Kaplan (1881-1983), who viewed Judaism as an evolving religious civilization rather than just a religion. The movement pioneered egalitarianism - the first bat mitzvah in America was Kaplan's daughter Judith in 1922. Reconstructionist Rabbinical College (founded 1968) trains the movement's rabbis.

Its Romanesque-Moorish sanctuary at Fifth Avenue and 65th Street seats 2,500 - larger than St. Patrick's Cathedral. Historic membership includes the great German-Jewish families of New York: Lehman, Goldman, Schiff, Warburg, Straus. The synagogue is a New York City landmark and repository of American Jewish history.

United States.name: Touro Synagogue (Newport, RI)
United States.description: Built in 1763, it is the oldest surviving synagogue building in the United States and a National Historic Site. George Washington wrote his famous 1790 letter to the congregation promising that the US government "gives to bigotry no sanction, to persecution no assistance." Built by Sephardic Jews who came from the Caribbean. Named after benefactor Judah Touro. A symbol of American religious freedom.

United States.name: HIAS (Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society)

United States.name: American Enterprise Institute (AEI)
United States.description: Conservative think tank founded in 1938, focused on government, politics, economics, and social welfare. AEI has had significant Jewish intellectual leadership, including prominent neoconservative scholars who were instrumental in shaping post-9/11 U.S. foreign policy. Key Jewish figures have included Irving Kristol (the "godfather of neoconservatism"), his wife Gertrude Himmelfarb, Michael Ledeen, Joshua Muravchik, David Frum (who coined "Axis of Evil"), and current scholars like Frederick Kagan. AEI has been strongly supportive of Israel and has advocated for aggressive U.S. policy in the Middle East. The think tank receives funding from major conservative and Jewish philanthropists.

individuals.bio: President of AEI, a major conservative think tank influential in US policy.

connections.description: AEI has been a key intellectual home for neoconservative policy thinkers.

connections.name: US foreign policy
connections.description: AEI scholars have significantly influenced US foreign and economic policy.

United States.name: Brookings Institution
United States.description: Prominent American research and policy institution founded in 1916, one of Washington's most influential think tanks. Brookings has had extensive Jewish leadership, including presidents Strobe Talbott and current president Cecilia Rouse. The institution's Saban Center for Middle East Policy, founded with a $13 million gift from Israeli-American media mogul Haim Saban, was a major center for Middle East policy research before merging into the Foreign Policy program. Martin Indyk, former U.S. Ambassador to Israel and a key figure in Israeli-American diplomacy, directed the Saban Center. Brookings researchers have been highly influential in shaping U.S. foreign policy toward Israel and the Middle East.

United States.name: Council on Foreign Relations
United States.description: Non-partisan think tank and publisher founded in 1921, one of the most influential foreign policy organizations in the United States. While not a Jewish organization, CFR has had significant Jewish leadership and membership. Richard Haass (Jewish) served as president from 2003 to 2023. The council publishes Foreign Affairs, the preeminent journal of international relations. CFR's membership has included nearly every Secretary of State, CIA Director, and senior foreign policy official. The organization has been a key venue for debate on U.S.-Israel relations, Middle East policy, and global affairs, with members including prominent Jewish diplomats, academics, and business leaders.

United States.name: Foundation for Defense of Democracies (FDD)
United States.description: Non-partisan policy institute founded in 2001 by Clifford May, focusing on national security and foreign policy. FDD has been one of the most hawkish think tanks on Iran and a strong advocate for U.S.-Israel security cooperation. Key Jewish figures include executive director Mark Dubowitz, who has been instrumental in designing Iran sanctions, and board members including Jewish-American philanthropists and former government officials. FDD has been influential in shaping the Trump administration's "maximum pressure" campaign against Iran and opposition to the JCPOA nuclear deal. Critics characterize it as a pro-Israel advocacy group, while supporters credit it with rigorous security analysis.

United States.name: Hudson Institute
United States.description: Founded in 1961 by Herman Kahn (Jewish), a nuclear strategist and futurist. The Hudson Institute is a conservative think tank focusing on defense, foreign policy, technology, and economics. Has become increasingly influential in pro-Israel policy circles. Fellows have included senior government officials. Based in Washington, D.C. Kahn was a model for the character of Dr. Strangelove.

United States.name: Jewish Institute for National Security of America (JINSA)
United States.description: Non-partisan think tank founded in 1976, focusing on strengthening the U.S.-Israel security relationship and broader American defense policy. JINSA runs programs bringing retired U.S. military generals and admirals to Israel, creating a network of senior military voices supportive of the bilateral relationship. The organization has been led by prominent figures including Michael Makovsky (CEO) and has a board including former senior U.S. military and intelligence officials. JINSA's Gemunder Center publishes analyses on Middle East security, Iran, and U.S. defense policy. The institute's programs have been credited with deepening U.S.-Israel military-to-military ties.

United States.name: Middle East Forum
United States.description: Think tank founded in 1994 by Daniel Pipes, a prominent Jewish-American Middle East scholar and commentator. The Forum promotes American interests in the Middle East through research, advocacy, and public education. Pipes has been a controversial figure, criticized by some as Islamophobic and praised by others as a clear-eyed analyst of radical Islam. The Forum publishes the Middle East Quarterly journal, runs Campus Watch (monitoring Middle East studies programs), and operates the Legal Project defending free speech about Islam. The organization has been influential in conservative and neoconservative Middle East policy circles and maintains close ties to pro-Israel advocacy networks.

United States.name: Middle East Media Research Institute (MEMRI)
United States.description: Founded in 1998 by Yigal Carmon (Jewish, Israeli), a former Israeli military intelligence colonel, and Meyrav Wurmser. MEMRI translates and analyzes Arabic, Farsi, Turkish, and Urdu media for Western audiences. Its translations are widely used by US policymakers, journalists, and academics. Provides insight into Middle Eastern political discourse, extremism, and antisemitism.

United States.name: Washington Institute for Near East Policy (WINEP)
United States.description: Policy research institute focused on U.S. Middle East policy, founded in 1985 by Martin Indyk with the support of AIPAC. WINEP has been one of the most influential think tanks shaping American policy toward Israel and the broader Middle East. Its founders and fellows include many prominent figures who have moved between the institute and senior government positions, including Dennis Ross, David Makovsky, and Robert Satloff (executive director since 1993). The institute has been both praised for its scholarly rigor and criticized by those who see it as advancing a pro-Israel agenda. WINEP regularly hosts Israeli and Arab officials and produces detailed policy analyses.

United States.name: YIVO Institute for Jewish Research
United States.description: Founded in 1925 in Vilna (now Vilnius, Lithuania), YIVO is the preeminent center for Eastern European Jewish and Yiddish studies. Its archives - 24 million items - were partially rescued from Nazi destruction in a dramatic wartime operation. Relocated to New York in 1940. YIVO's collection includes irreplaceable documents of Jewish life in Eastern Europe, the Yiddish theater, and immigrant communities.

individuals.name: Max Weinreich
individuals.bio: Co-founder of YIVO (1925) and pioneering Yiddish linguist. Author of 'History of the Yiddish Language.' Coined the phrase 'a language is a dialect with an army and a navy.'

United States.name: Bed Bath & Beyond (historic)
United States.description: Co-founded in 1971 by Warren Eisenberg (Jewish) and Leonard Feinstein (Jewish) as Bed 'n Bath. Grew to 1,500+ stores and became a cultural icon - its "Big Blue" 20%-off coupons were ubiquitous. Became a meme stock in 2022 when Ryan Cohen (Jewish, GameStop chairman) invested. Filed for bankruptcy in 2023. At its peak, the company was valued at $17 billion.

His brother Nathan Straus donated his fortune to public health, saving thousands of children through pasteurized milk programs. The Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade (since 1924) is an American institution. Herald Square flagship is one of the world's largest stores.

Staples grew to 2,000+ stores worldwide and became the largest office products company. United States.name: Toys 'R' Us (historic)
United States.description: Founded in 1957 by Charles Lazarus (Jewish), who created the toy superstore concept. At its peak, Toys 'R' Us operated 1,600+ stores worldwide and was every American child's wonderland. A $6.6 billion leveraged buyout in 2005 by KKR (Henry Kravis, Jewish), Bain Capital, and Vornado loaded it with fatal debt. Filed for bankruptcy in 2017. Lazarus died in 2018, the same week the stores began closing.

United States.name: Atlanta Hawks (Tony Ressler)
United States.description: NBA franchise owned by Tony Ressler, a Jewish-American billionaire who co-founded Ares Management, one of the world's largest alternative investment managers with over $300 billion in assets. Ressler, who is married to actress Jami Gertz (also Jewish), purchased the Hawks in 2015 for $850 million. He has overseen the team's move to the renovated State Farm Arena and development of the Centennial Yards mixed-use project around the arena. Ressler previously co-founded Apollo Global Management with Leon Black and Josh Harris, connecting him to a network of Jewish private equity billionaires who collectively own multiple professional sports franchises.

United States.name: Boston Celtics (Wyc Grousbeck)
United States.description: NBA franchise with lead owner Wyc Grousbeck, a Jewish-American private equity executive who led the ownership group that purchased the Celtics in 2002. Under his ownership, the Celtics won the 2008 NBA Championship and the 2024 NBA Championship. Grousbeck, a Harvard Law graduate and former partner at Highland Capital Partners, has been an active and visible owner in a franchise with 17 championships - the most in NBA history. In 2024, Grousbeck announced the planned sale of the Celtics at a valuation expected to exceed $5 billion, which would be the highest price ever paid for an NBA team.

The bank operates over 200 branches in Israel and has international subsidiaries. In 2020, Bank Hapoalim paid $874 million to U.S. authorities to settle charges of helping American clients evade taxes - one of the largest such penalties ever. The bank manages assets exceeding $100 billion and is listed on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange.

Israel.name: Habima National Theatre
Israel.description: Israel's national theater, founded in 1917 in Moscow by Nahum Zemach as a Hebrew-language theater company during a time when Hebrew was barely a spoken language. Habima (meaning "The Stage" in Hebrew) operated under the patronage of the Moscow Art Theater's Stanislavsky before relocating to Palestine in 1928. The theater played a crucial role in the revival of the Hebrew language and Israeli cultural identity. Its 1922 production of The Dybbuk, directed by Yevgeny Vakhtangov, is considered one of the most important theatrical productions of the 20th century. Habima received national theater status in 1958 and performs in its modernist Tel Aviv home on Habima Square, one of the cultural hearts of the city.

Israel.name: Israel Museum
Israel.description: Israel's national museum located in Jerusalem, housing the Dead Sea Scrolls in the iconic Shrine of the Book. Founded in 1965, the museum holds nearly 500,000 objects spanning 5,000 years of art and archaeology, from prehistoric artifacts to contemporary art. The Shrine of the Book, with its distinctive white dome, contains the oldest known biblical manuscripts. The museum's collections include Judaica, ethnography, Israeli art, and European masters. The campus features the Billy Rose Art Garden designed by Isamu Noguchi and a model of ancient Jerusalem. The Israel Museum is one of the leading archaeological and art museums in the world, attracting over 800,000 visitors annually and serving as a key institution in Israeli cultural identity.

Israel.description: Founded in 1936 by Bronislaw Huberman (Jewish, Polish violinist) to provide employment to Jewish musicians fleeing Nazi persecution in Europe. Arturo Toscanini conducted its inaugural concert. Zubin Mehta served as music director for nearly 50 years. One of the world's premier orchestras. The founding of the IPO is itself a Holocaust rescue story.

individuals.bio: Indian-born conductor who served as Music Director of the Israel Philharmonic Orchestra for nearly 50 years (1969-2019), a deeply beloved figure.

Israel.name: Tel Aviv Museum of Art
Israel.description: Founded in 1932, the Tel Aviv Museum of Art is Israel's leading museum of modern and contemporary art. Israel's Declaration of Independence was signed in the museum's original building (Meir Dizengoff's home on Rothschild Boulevard) on May 14, 1948. The museum's collection includes works by Picasso, Monet, Chagall, Kandinsky, and Israeli masters. The striking Herta and Paul Amir Building opened in 2011.

individuals.bio: Director of the Tel Aviv Museum of Art, one of Israel's leading art museums with extensive Israeli and international collections.

Israel.name: Candiru (Saito Tech)
Israel.description: An Israeli cyber-espionage company (also known as Saito Tech) that develops spyware for government clients. Exposed by Microsoft and the University of Toronto's Citizen Lab in 2021 for deploying "DevilsTongue" spyware targeting journalists and dissidents. Blacklisted by the US Commerce Department in 2021 alongside NSO Group. Part of Israel's controversial but lucrative cyber-offense industry.

Israel.name: Cellebrite
Israel.description: Provider of digital intelligence solutions for law enforcement and intelligence agencies, founded in 1999 in Petah Tikva, Israel. Cellebrite is best known for its Universal Forensic Extraction Device (UFED), which can extract data from locked mobile phones - a capability that has made it both essential to criminal investigations and controversial for civil liberties implications. The FBI reportedly used Cellebrite technology to unlock the San Bernardino shooter's iPhone in 2016. The company sells to law enforcement in over 150 countries, raising concerns about use by authoritarian regimes. Cellebrite went public on NASDAQ in 2021 through a SPAC merger. The company represents Israel's complex position at the intersection of security technology and human rights debates.

Israel.name: Elbit Systems
Israel.description: International defense electronics company headquartered in Haifa, Israel, and one of the world's largest defense technology companies. Elbit develops and supplies a broad portfolio of airborne, land, and naval systems and homeland security products including drones (UAVs), electro-optic systems, electronic warfare suites, signals intelligence, and military aircraft avionics. The company has been a key supplier to the Israel Defense Forces and exports to militaries worldwide, including the United States, where it operates through its subsidiary Elbit Systems of America. Elbit has been a frequent target of BDS campaigns and pro-Palestinian protests for its role in supplying surveillance and military technology used in the West Bank and Gaza. Revenue exceeds $5.5 billion annually.

IAI develops the Arrow missile defense system (with Boeing), military drones/UAVs, satellites, and the Shavit space launcher. Also produces radar systems, cyber defense, and commercial aviation components. Employs 15,000+ people. IAI has made Israel one of the world's top defense exporters.

Israel.name: Israel Defense Forces (IDF)
Israel.description: Israel's military (Tzva HaHagana LeYisrael), formed in 1948 from pre-state militias including the Haganah. One of the most technologically advanced militaries in the world. Mandatory conscription (32 months men, 24 women). Elite units include Sayeret Matkal, Shayetet 13, and Unit 8200. The Iron Dome system has intercepted thousands of rockets. The IDF has fought major wars in 1948, 1956, 1967, 1973, 1982, 2006, and 2014. Receives $3.8B annual US military aid.

Israel.description: Originally state-owned, IMI Systems was acquired by Elbit Systems in 2018 for $495 million. Famous for developing the Uzi submachine gun (designed by Major Uzi Gal), one of the most iconic firearms in history, adopted by 90+ countries. Also produced the Galil assault rifle, ammunition, and rocket propulsion systems. IMI's products have been used by militaries worldwide since the 1950s.

Israel.name: Mossad (Institute for Intelligence and Special Operations)
Israel.description: Israel's legendary foreign intelligence agency, responsible for intelligence collection, covert operations, and counterterrorism worldwide. Famous operations include the capture of Adolf Eichmann (1960), intelligence for the Entebbe rescue (1976), assassination of Black September operatives (Operation Wrath of God), and reportedly the Stuxnet cyberattack on Iran. Led by a director who reports directly to the PM. Motto: "Where there is no counsel, the people fall; but in the multitude of counsellors there is safety" (Proverbs 11:14).

individuals.name: Meir Dagan

Israel.description: Founded by Shalev Hulio and Omri Lavie (Israeli Jewish, Unit 8200 alumni). NSO Group developed Pegasus, the most powerful spyware ever created, capable of infiltrating any smartphone. Sold to governments worldwide for counter-terrorism but controversially used to surveil journalists, dissidents, and political opponents. Blacklisted by the US Commerce Department in 2021. Represents the controversial side of Israel's cyber-intelligence industry.

Israel.name: Rafael Advanced Defense Systems
Israel.description: Israeli defense technology company and developer of the Iron Dome missile defense system, one of the most successful military technologies in modern history. Founded in 1948 as part of the Israel Ministry of Defense, RAFAEL (originally an acronym for "Armament Development Authority") was corporatized in 2002. Iron Dome, developed with significant U.S. funding, has intercepted thousands of rockets fired at Israeli population centers. RAFAEL also produces the Trophy active protection system for tanks, Spike anti-tank missiles (exported to over 30 countries), and advanced guided munitions. The company employs over 8,000 people, primarily scientists and engineers, and generates over $3 billion in annual revenue. RAFAEL represents the cutting edge of Israeli defense innovation.

Israel.name: Shin Bet (Israel Security Agency)
Israel.description: Israel's internal security service (Sherut HaBitachon HaKlali), responsible for counterterrorism, counterintelligence, VIP protection, and intelligence in the Palestinian territories. Six former directors spoke in the Oscar-nominated documentary "The Gatekeepers" (2012). Shin Bet failed to prevent the assassination of PM Yitzhak Rabin in 1995. Employs sophisticated surveillance and human intelligence networks.

Israel.name: Talpiot Program
Israel.description: The IDF's most elite training program, selecting ~50 recruits per year from thousands of applicants. Cadets undergo 40 months of intensive study in physics, mathematics, and computer science at Hebrew University while also completing military training. Talpiot alumni ("Talpions") have founded dozens of tech companies and serve in senior defense and intelligence positions. The program is considered a key driver of Israel's technological superiority.

Israel.name: Unit 8200
Israel.description: Israel Defense Forces' premier signals intelligence (SIGINT) unit, equivalent to the U.S. National Security Agency (NSA). Unit 8200 is known as the world's most prolific tech startup incubator, with alumni founding companies including Check Point, Waze, NSO Group, CyberArk, and hundreds of other firms. The unit recruits Israel's most talented young people (ages 18-21) at conscription and trains them in advanced cybersecurity, data analysis, and intelligence gathering. Unit 8200's surveillance capabilities against Palestinian communications have made it controversial, with 43 veterans signing a public refusal letter in 2014 citing moral concerns. The unit's influence on Israel's $20+ billion tech sector is so significant that "8200 alumni" has become a shorthand for tech talent in the Israeli innovation ecosystem.

Israel.description: An Israeli-American company providing intelligence solutions, surveillance technology, and customer engagement software. Spun off from Comverse Technology (founded by Kobi Alexander, Jewish, Israeli). Verint's intelligence division provides mass surveillance equipment to governments worldwide. Israel.name: Bar-Ilan University
Israel.description: Public research university in Ramat Gan, Israel, founded in 1955 by the American Mizrachi movement to combine secular academic studies with Jewish identity and values. Named after Rabbi Meir Bar-Ilan (Berlin), a leader of Religious Zionism, the university has grown to become Israel's second-largest academic institution with over 26,000 students. Bar-Ilan is known for its Responsa Project, the world's largest electronic database of Jewish law, and strong programs in brain research (the Gonda Multidisciplinary Brain Research Center), nanotechnology, and criminology. The university has been associated with the religious-Zionist community and has campuses in Safed, Ashkelon, and the Jordan Valley, including a controversial campus in the Ariel settlement in the West Bank.

Israel.name: Ben-Gurion University of the Negev
Israel.description: Research university in Beersheba founded in 1969, central to the development of Israel's Negev desert and its transformation into a thriving tech and scientific hub. Named after David Ben-Gurion, Israel's founding prime minister who championed Negev development, the university has become a global leader in desert research, water technology, solar energy, and cybersecurity. BGU's Cyber Security Research Center is at the heart of Beersheba's emerging "cyber capital" status, housing Israel's National Cyber Directorate and tech giants including Deutsche Telekom and PayPal. The university operates the Sede Boqer campus adjacent to Ben-Gurion's desert home and burial site, and has established an innovation district attracting multinational companies and military intelligence units.

Israel.description: Founded in 1999 by Michael Steinhardt and Charles Bronfman to provide free 10-day trips to Israel for young Jews aged 18-26. Over 800,000 participants from 68 countries. Sheldon Adelson donated $410 million - the largest single philanthropic gift in Jewish history. Israel's government co-funds the program. Studies show Birthright alumni are significantly more likely to marry Jewish, raise Jewish children, and support Israel.

Israel.description: Founded in 1994 by Prof. Uriel Reichman as IDC Herzliya, rebranded as Reichman University. Israel's first private university. Houses the Lauder School of Government (named for Ronald Lauder, Jewish, Este Lauder heir), the Arison School of Business, and the Sammy Ofer School of Communications. Israel.name: Technion - Israel Institute of Technology
Israel.description: Israel's oldest university, founded in 1912 in Haifa during the Ottoman period, and the country's premier science and technology research institution. The Technion has produced three Nobel Prize laureates in chemistry and innumerable tech entrepreneurs. Often called "Israel's MIT," the Technion has been instrumental in creating Israel's reputation as the "Startup Nation," with alumni founding companies like Waze, Mobileye, and numerous defense technology firms. Albert Einstein was a strong advocate for the institution and served on its first Board of Governors. The campus spans 300 acres on Mount Carmel and maintains research partnerships with top universities worldwide. Technion graduates are estimated to lead over a quarter of Israel's high-tech companies and account for a large portion of the nation's engineering and scientific workforce.

Israel.name: Tel Aviv University
Israel.description: Israel's largest university and a major center of teaching and research, founded in 1956 in Tel Aviv. TAU encompasses nine faculties covering arts, sciences, engineering, medicine, and law, with over 30,000 students. The university's Blavatnik School of Computer Science and Sackler Faculty of Medicine are world-renowned. TAU has produced five Nobel laureates and numerous leaders in Israeli society, technology, and military. The campus features the Diaspora Museum (ANU), one of the world's most important Jewish cultural institutions. TAU has extensive research partnerships with institutions globally and is a leading center for Middle East studies, cybersecurity research, and biotechnology innovation. Its alumni include prominent Israeli politicians, military leaders, and tech entrepreneurs.

Located on Mount Carmel with views of the Mediterranean. Home to the Leon H. Charney School of Marine Sciences, the Hecht Museum of archaeology and art, and leading programs in Mediterranean studies. The Eshkol Tower, designed by Oscar Niemeyer, is a local landmark.

Israel.name: Galei Zahal (IDF Radio)
Israel.description: The Israel Defense Forces' radio station, broadcasting since 1950. Despite being a military station, Galei Zahal is one of Israel's most popular radio stations, known for music programming and news. Many famous Israeli musicians and broadcasters launched their careers on IDF Radio. Soldiers serve as producers, DJs, and journalists. A unique cultural institution where military service and media culture intersect.

individuals.name: Ilana Dayan
individuals.bio: Israeli journalist (Jewish) who presented on Galei Zahal before becoming one of Israel's most prominent investigative journalists.

Israel.name: Haaretz
Israel.description: Israel's oldest daily newspaper, founded in 1918. Owned by the Schocken family (Jewish, German-origin) since 1935. Known for independent, left-leaning editorial positions and investigative journalism. Publishes both Hebrew and English editions. Its English edition is widely read by international policy makers and journalists covering Israel.

Israel.name: i24NEWS
Israel.description: International 24-hour multilingual news and current affairs television channel based in Tel Aviv and Jaffa, Israel. Founded in 2013 by French-Israeli businessman Patrick Drahi (a Sephardic Jew born in Morocco), i24NEWS broadcasts in English, French, and Arabic, aiming to present Israeli and Middle Eastern perspectives to a global audience. The channel is available in over 150 million households worldwide, including on major U.S. cable systems. Drahi, who also controls Altice (a global telecoms and media conglomerate), invested heavily in creating a CNN-style international news operation from Israel. The channel has been praised for providing diverse voices and criticized as a soft-power tool for the Israeli government.

Israel.name: Israel Hayom
Israel.description: Free daily newspaper founded by Sheldon Adelson (Jewish, American casino billionaire) in 2007. Now owned by his widow Miriam Adelson (Jewish, Israeli-American). Became Israel's most-read newspaper due to free distribution. Widely viewed as supportive of Benjamin Netanyahu, earning the nickname "Bibiton" (Bibi's paper). Funded from Adelson's casino fortune.

Israel.name: Playtika
Israel.description: Mobile gaming entertainment company founded in 2010 in Israel by Robert Antokol and Uri Shahak. Playtika pioneered the use of data science and AI to optimize casual mobile gaming experiences, operating hit games including Slotomania, Bingo Blitz, and Caesars Slots. The company was acquired by a Chinese consortium led by Giant Interactive for $4.4 billion in 2016, one of the largest acquisitions of an Israeli company. Playtika went public on NASDAQ in 2021, valuing the company at over $11 billion. With over 4,000 employees in offices across Israel, Ukraine, Belarus, and other countries, Playtika is one of the largest gaming companies to emerge from Israel.

Israel.name: The Jerusalem Post
Israel.description: English-language Israeli newspaper founded in 1932 as the Palestine Post during the British Mandate. The paper covered the founding of the State of Israel and is one of the most widely read English-language sources for news about Israel and the Middle East. Originally centrist, the Jerusalem Post shifted to the right under the ownership of Hollinger International (Conrad Black) in the 1980s and the current ownership of Eli Azur. The paper's editors have included legendary figures like Gershon Agron and Ted Lurie. The Jerusalem Post has been a critical link connecting the English-speaking Jewish diaspora with events in Israel and has influenced international perceptions of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict for over nine decades.

Backed by investor Seth Klarman (Jewish, US). Features professional journalism alongside a massive community blogs platform with thousands of contributors. Covers Israeli news, Jewish world, Middle East, and has Arabic and French editions.

Walla became central to Israeli politics when PM Netanyahu's Case 4000 corruption trial alleged that he sought favorable coverage on Walla in exchange for regulatory benefits for Bezeq (then Walla's parent company). The case highlighted the intersection of media, telecoms, and politics in Israel.

Israel.name: Yedioth Ahronoth
Israel.description: One of Israel's most widely read daily newspapers, founded in 1939, with the name meaning "Latest News" in Hebrew. Owned by the Moses family (Arnon "Noni" Mozes), Yedioth Ahronoth has been at the center of Israeli media and political life for decades. The paper's editorial stance is generally centrist to center-left, and its Ynet news website is one of Israel's most visited. The paper was central to the corruption trial of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who was charged with media bribery - allegedly offering regulatory favors to Mozes in exchange for favorable coverage. Yedioth Ahronoth's rivalry with Israel Hayom (Sheldon Adelson's free daily) has shaped Israeli media dynamics in the 21st century.

AHAVA was a BDS target due to its factory in Mitzpe Shalem (West Bank settlement); now relocated. Acquired by Chinese interests. AHAVA products are sold in 50+ countries. The brand represents Israel's commercialization of the Dead Sea's natural resources.

Israel.name: Israeli Wine Industry
Israel.description: Israel's wine industry was revived by Baron Edmond de Rothschild, who founded Carmel Winery in 1882. Today, 200+ wineries operate across Israel, with the best wines from the Golan Heights, Galilee, and Judean Hills. Golan Heights Winery's Yarden brand and Domaine du Castel consistently win international awards. Israel has emerged as a "New World" wine region, with ancient winemaking traditions dating back 5,000 years.

Israel.name: Osem-Nestl
Israel.description: Israel's largest food manufacturer, now wholly owned by Swiss giant Nestl. Founded in 1942 during the British Mandate. Osem makes Bamba (Israel's beloved peanut-flavored puffs - credited with reducing peanut allergies in Israeli children), Bissli, soup powders, pasta, and hundreds of other products. Bamba is so iconic that Israeli parents abroad have it shipped to them. Osem is a pillar of Israeli food culture.

Israel.name: Strauss Group
Israel.description: One of Israel's largest food and beverage companies, founded in 1933 by Richard and Hilda Strauss as a small dairy farm in Nahariya. The Strauss family built the company into a multinational conglomerate with revenues exceeding $2 billion, operating across Israel, Brazil, and other markets. Strauss owns major brands including Sabra Hummus (in partnership with PepsiCo), Elite coffee, and Obela dips. Ofra Strauss, granddaughter of the founders, chairs the company and is one of Israel's most prominent businesswomen. The Strauss Group has faced BDS boycott campaigns due to its past support of the IDF Golani Brigade, which it discontinued in 2014.

Israel.name: Tnuva
Israel.description: Israel's largest food manufacturer and dairy company, controlling approximately 70% of the Israeli dairy market. Founded in 1926 as a cooperative by Jewish agricultural settlements during the British Mandate, Tnuva was the flagship enterprise of the kibbutz and moshav movements and became synonymous with Israeli food culture. The company was controversially privatized and sold to the Chinese Bright Food Group in 2014 for $2.5 billion, sparking a national debate about foreign ownership of strategic Israeli assets. Tnuva produces milk, cheese, yogurt, and other dairy and food products that are staples of the Israeli diet. The brand name has become a generic term for dairy products in Israeli Hebrew.

Israel.description: Israeli government body responsible for tax collection and enforcement. Administers corporate, income, VAT, and customs taxes. Israel.name: Jewish Agency for Israel
Israel.description: Organization founded in 1929 responsible for facilitating Jewish immigration (aliyah) to Israel and supporting absorption of new immigrants. The Jewish Agency was instrumental in establishing the State of Israel, functioning as a quasi-governmental body in pre-state Palestine under the leadership of David Ben-Gurion and Chaim Weizmann. After 1948, the agency continued to manage global Jewish immigration, bringing millions of Jews from Europe, the Middle East, North Africa, Ethiopia, and the former Soviet Union to Israel. The organization operates in over 80 countries, running programs including Birthright Israel, Masa Israel Journey, and various educational initiatives. Recent chairman Isaac Herzog left to become Israel's 11th president in 2021.

Israel.name: Knesset (Israeli Parliament)
Israel.description: The Knesset is Israel's unicameral parliament, with 120 members elected by proportional representation. Located in Jerusalem, it serves as the legislative branch. Named after the Knesset HaGedolah (Great Assembly) of ancient Israel. The building, designed by Joseph Klarwein, features Chagall tapestries. Israel's multi-party system typically requires coalition governments. The Knesset has been the arena for Israel's most consequential political battles.

Israel.name: BioNTech-Pfizer Israel Partnership
Israel.description: Israel became the world's fastest country to vaccinate its population with the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine in early 2021. A landmark agreement saw Israel share anonymized health data with Pfizer in exchange for priority vaccine supply. Pfizer CEO Albert Bourla (Jewish, born in Thessaloniki, Greece - his parents survived the Holocaust) led the global vaccination effort. The partnership demonstrated Israel's advanced healthcare data infrastructure and universal health system.

Israel.name: Masada National Park
Israel.description: An ancient fortress atop a plateau overlooking the Dead Sea, built by King Herod (73-31 BCE). In 73 CE, 960 Jewish zealots held out against the Roman X Legion, ultimately choosing mass suicide over slavery - one of history's most dramatic last stands. UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2001. IDF soldiers take their oath here: "Masada shall not fall again." Excavated by Prof. Yigael Yadin (1963-1965). Israel's most iconic archaeological site.

Virtually every foreign head of state visiting Israel pays respects at Yad Vashem.
