Belgium.name: Antwerp Jewish Community
Belgium.description: Antwerp is home to one of Europe's largest and most visibly Orthodox and Hasidic Jewish communities (~15,000-20,000). The community is centred around the diamond district near the Central Station. Home to multiple Hasidic groups including Satmar, Belz, and Lubavitch, as well as non-Hasidic Orthodox Jews. Supports an extensive network of Jewish schools (cheders, yeshivot), synagogues, mikvaot, and welfare organizations.

Belgium.name: Jewish Museum of Belgium (Brussels)
Belgium.description: The Jewish Museum of Belgium in Brussels documents Jewish life in Belgium. Tragically, on May 24, 2014, a French-Algerian ISIS-affiliated gunman killed four people inside the museum in a terrorist attack - the first deadly attack on a European Jewish institution since the 1980s. The museum houses collections spanning Belgian Jewish history from the medieval period to the present and continues to serve as a centre for education and remembrance.

individuals.name: Pascale Falek
individuals.bio: Director of the Jewish Museum of Belgium, which was targeted in a deadly terror attack in 2014.

Belgium.name: Kazerne Dossin Memorial (Mechelen)
Belgium.description: Kazerne Dossin in Mechelen (Malines) is Belgium's national memorial to the 25,000+ Jews and Roma deported from Belgium to Auschwitz between 1942 and 1944. The Dossin Barracks served as the transit camp. The modern museum and documentation centre, opened in 2012, examines not only the deportations but also the broader themes of collaboration, resistance, and mass violence. Addresses Belgian governmental complicity in the persecution.

Belgium.name: Antwerp Diamond District
Belgium.description: Antwerp's Diamond District processes approximately 80% of the world's rough diamonds. The trade has been dominated by the Orthodox and Hasidic Jewish community for centuries. Located around the Hoveniersstraat near Antwerp Central Station, the district is the heart of one of Europe's largest Orthodox Jewish communities. Jewish diamond traders have operated here since the 15th century, making it one of the most enduring Jewish economic niches in the world.

Switzerland.description: B'nai B'rith International's Geneva office represents the world's oldest Jewish service organization (founded 1843 in New York) at the United Nations and other international organizations headquartered in Geneva. Advocates for Jewish rights, combats antisemitism, and engages in humanitarian and human rights work. B'nai B'rith has special consultative status at the United Nations.

Switzerland.name: Bergier Commission legacy
Switzerland.description: The Bergier Commission (Independent Commission of Experts: Switzerland - Second World War, 1996-2002) investigated Switzerland's wartime conduct, including trade with Nazi Germany, acceptance/rejection of Jewish refugees, and dormant bank accounts of Holocaust victims. Found that Switzerland turned away approximately 25,000 refugees. Led to the landmark $1.25 billion settlement between Swiss banks (UBS, Credit Suisse) and Holocaust survivors.

individuals.name: Jean-Franois Bergier
individuals.bio: Swiss historian who chaired the Independent Commission of Experts (1996-2002) investigating Switzerland's WWII-era dealings with Nazi Germany and dormant Jewish accounts.

Switzerland.name: International Committee of the Red Cross (Jewish relationship)
Switzerland.description: The ICRC's relationship with Jewish victims during WWII remains deeply controversial. The Red Cross was criticized for failing to publicly denounce the Holocaust or effectively protect Jews. Its 1944 visit to Theresienstadt, where the Nazis staged a Potemkin-village "model camp," resulted in a positive report that unwittingly aided Nazi propaganda. The ICRC later acknowledged its failures and opened its WWII archives for research.

individuals.name: Peter Maurer
individuals.bio: Former president of the ICRC. The ICRC's controversial WWII role - failing to intervene for Jews - led to formal apologies and study.

Switzerland.description: The SIG/FSCI (Schweizerischer Israelitischer Gemeindebund / Fdration Suisse des Communauts Isralites) represents Swiss Jewry (~18,000), concentrated in Zurich, Geneva, and Basel. Played a significant role in the Swiss bank Holocaust assets controversy of the 1990s, which led to a $1.25 billion settlement. Swiss Jewish history includes the complex legacy of wartime neutrality, where Switzerland turned away Jewish refugees while sheltering others.

Switzerland.name: World Health Organization - Israeli connections
Switzerland.description: Israel's significant contributions to global health through partnerships with the World Health Organization and international health institutions. Israeli medical innovations adopted by WHO include emergency trauma protocols developed from treating conflict casualties, mobile field hospital expertise (IDF field hospitals were deployed in Haiti, Nepal, and other disaster zones), and pharmaceutical breakthroughs. Israeli researchers have contributed to global disease eradication efforts, cancer research, and medical technology that saves lives worldwide. The Hadassah Medical Center in Jerusalem and Sheba Medical Center in Tel Hashomer regularly collaborate with WHO on pandemic preparedness, infectious disease research, and medical training for developing nations. Israel was among the first countries to sequence COVID-19 variants during the pandemic.

individuals.name: Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus

Founded in 1936, it played a crucial role in Holocaust restitution under President Edgar Bronfman Sr. Since 2007, led by Ronald Lauder (Jewish, billionaire heir to Este Lauder Companies). The WJC has permanent observer status at the United Nations.

Italy.name: Community of Sant'Egidio - Jewish dialogue
Italy.description: The Community of Sant'Egidio, a Catholic lay community founded in Rome in 1968, has been a key facilitator of Catholic-Jewish dialogue. Building on the legacy of Vatican II's Nostra Aetate declaration (1965), Sant'Egidio has organized major interfaith encounters and peace initiatives. Its work represents the dramatic transformation of Catholic-Jewish relations from centuries of hostility to contemporary partnership.

Italy.name: Jewish Museum of Bologna
Italy.description: The Jewish Museum of Bologna (Museo Ebraico di Bologna) documents the history of Jewish life in Bologna and the Emilia-Romagna region of Italy. Jewish scholars contributed to the University of Bologna, one of the world's oldest universities (founded 1088). The museum explores the complex history of tolerance and persecution, including Bologna's own ghetto and the impact of WWII.

individuals.name: Vincenza Maugeri
individuals.bio: Director of the Jewish Museum of Bologna, documenting Jewish life in the Emilia-Romagna region since medieval times.

Italy.name: Jewish Museum of Rome
Italy.description: The Jewish Museum of Rome documents the oldest Jewish community in Europe, dating to 161 BCE when Judean ambassadors first arrived in Rome. Located in the Great Synagogue complex in Rome's former Ghetto - the neighbourhood where Jews were confined from 1555 to 1870. Houses artifacts spanning over 2,000 years including ritual objects, textiles, and historical documents.

individuals.name: Alessandra Di Castro
individuals.bio: Director of the Jewish Museum of Rome, documenting Europe's oldest continuous Jewish community (since 161 BCE).

Italy.name: Venice Ghetto
Italy.description: The Venice Ghetto, established in 1516 by the Venetian Republic, is the world's first Jewish ghetto - the very word "ghetto" originates here, from the Venetian word for "foundry" (getto) as the area had been an iron foundry. Jews were confined here until Napoleon's liberation in 1797. Contains five historic synagogues (Schola Grande Tedesca, Canton, Italiana, Levantina, Spagnola) serving Ashkenazi, Italian, and Sephardi communities. High-rise buildings due to space constraints.

individuals.name: Shaul Bassi
individuals.bio: Scholar and director of the Venice Center for Humanities and Social Change (Jewish), who has studied the Venice Ghetto - the world's first Jewish ghetto (1516).

connections.name: Origin of the word 'ghetto'
connections.description: The Venice Ghetto, established in 1516, is where the word 'ghetto' originates (from the Venetian word for 'foundry').

connections.name: First Jewish ghetto in history
connections.description: The first systematically designated Jewish quarter in European history.

Italy.name: Great Synagogue of Rome
Italy.description: The Great Synagogue of Rome (Tempio Maggiore), built in 1904 in eclectic Assyrian-Babylonian style, serves Europe's oldest Jewish community. Pope John Paul II made a historic visit in 1986 - the first pope to enter a synagogue since antiquity. In 1982, Palestinian terrorists attacked the synagogue, killing 2-year-old Stefano Gaj Tach and injuring 37. The synagogue's distinctive square dome dominates the Tiber riverbank skyline.

individuals.name: Riccardo Di Segni
individuals.bio: Chief Rabbi of Rome (Jewish), spiritual leader at the Great Synagogue (Tempio Maggiore), built in 1904.

Italy.name: Synagogue of Florence (Tempio Maggiore)
Italy.description: The Synagogue of Florence (Tempio Maggiore), built in 1882, is one of the most beautiful synagogues in Europe. Its striking Moorish Revival architecture with a distinctive green copper dome dominates the neighborhood of San Marco. Built after the Emancipation brought Jews equal rights in unified Italy. Houses a Jewish museum and remains an active prayer house for Florence's small but historic Jewish community.

individuals.name: Joseph Levi
individuals.bio: Rabbi of the Jewish community of Florence (Jewish), overseeing the Moorish Revival-style Tempio Maggiore (1882).

Italy.name: Union of Italian Jewish Communities (UCEI)
Italy.description: UCEI (Unione delle Comunit Ebraiche Italiane) represents Italian Jewry (~25,000), one of the oldest Jewish communities in the world - Jews have lived in Italy continuously for over 2,000 years, since the Roman Republic era. Has a concordat (Intesa) with the Italian state. Italian Jews suffered under Mussolini's 1938 racial laws and subsequent Nazi deportations. The community spans from Rome (the oldest in Europe) to Milan, Turin, Florence, and Venice.

individuals.name: Noemi Di Segni
individuals.bio: President of the Union of Italian Jewish Communities (UCEI) (Jewish), representing approximately 25,000 Italian Jews.

Italy.name: Benetton Group
Italy.description: Global fashion brand headquartered in Treviso, Italy. Founded by the Benetton family. Known for provocative United Colors of Benetton advertising campaigns.

Italy.name: Luxottica
Italy.description: World's largest eyewear producer, headquartered in Milan. Founded by Leonardo Del Vecchio. Makes Ray-Ban, Oakley, and licensed luxury brands. Merged with Essilor in 2018.

Italy.description: The world's first 'ghetto' - the word itself comes from the Venetian word for foundry (getto). Jews were confined to this area from 1516 to 1797. Today a living neighborhood with synagogues, a museum, and a kosher restaurant.

Spain.name: Federation of Jewish Communities of Spain (additional)
Spain.description: Spain's Jewish community numbers approximately 40,000-50,000 and has experienced a revival. In 2015, Spain passed a landmark law offering citizenship to descendants of Sephardic Jews expelled in 1492 - over 130,000 applied. The Red de Juderas (Network of Jewish Quarters) promotes heritage tourism across historic sites in Toledo, Crdoba, Girona, and Segovia. Spain's Golden Age (10th-12th centuries) saw Jewish scholars like Maimonides and Judah Halevi flourish alongside Muslim and Christian thinkers.

individuals.name: Isaac Querub
individuals.bio: President of FCJE (Jewish), advocating for Spain's Sephardic heritage and the 2015 citizenship law for Sephardic descendants.

Spain.name: Casa Sefarad-Israel (Madrid)
Spain.description: Casa Sefarad-Israel in Madrid is a cultural centre promoting the relationship between Spain, the Sephardi diaspora, and Israel. Hosts exhibitions, lectures, and cultural events exploring Sephardi heritage and the historic Jewish presence in Spain. Serves as a bridge between Spain and the global Sephardi communities who trace their roots to the Iberian Peninsula, from Istanbul to Thessaloniki to Latin America.

individuals.name: Esther Bendahan
individuals.bio: Director general of Casa Sefarad-Israel (Jewish), promoting Sephardic culture and Spain-Israel relations.

Spain.name: Museum of Sephardic Heritage (Toledo)
Spain.description: The Sephardic Museum in Toledo is housed in the El Trnsito Synagogue, a masterpiece of 14th-century Mudjar architecture built by Samuel ha-Levi Abulafia, treasurer to King Peter I of Castile. Documents the extraordinary Golden Age of Sephardi Jewish civilization in medieval Spain, when Jews excelled in philosophy, medicine, poetry, and science. Tells the story of the 1492 Alhambra Decree that expelled all Jews from Spain, scattering the Sephardi diaspora worldwide.

individuals.name: Samuel ha-Levi Abulafia
individuals.bio: 14th-century treasurer to King Peter I of Castile (Jewish) who built the Synagogue of El Trnsito (1357), now the Sephardic Museum.

Spain.name: Crdoba Synagogue
Spain.description: The Crdoba Synagogue, built in 1315, is one of only three medieval synagogues surviving in Spain. Located in the old Jewish quarter (Judera) of Crdoba, the birthplace of Maimonides (Moses ben Maimon, 1138-1204), the greatest Jewish philosopher, physician, and legal authority of the Middle Ages. The synagogue's Mudjar (Islamic-influenced) architecture reflects the cultural blending that characterized the Convivencia period.

individuals.name: Moses Maimonides
individuals.bio: Born in Crdoba in 1138, Maimonides was the greatest medieval Jewish philosopher. A statue stands near the synagogue in the old Jewish quarter.

Spain.name: Federation of Jewish Communities of Spain
Spain.description: The Federation of Jewish Communities of Spain represents Spain's Jewish community (~40,000-50,000). Spain was the heartland of Sephardi Jewish civilization - the Golden Age of Spanish Jewry produced Maimonides, Judah Halevi, and Ibn Ezra. The 1492 Alhambra Decree expelled all Jews, ending 1,500 years of presence. In 2015, Spain passed a law offering citizenship to descendants of expelled Sephardi Jews, an act of historical recognition.

Spain.description: Cultural center dedicated to preserving and promoting Sephardic heritage in Barcelona. Spain's 1492 expulsion of Jews was one of the largest forced migrations in history.

Poland.name: Jewish Community Centre of Krakow (JCC Krakw)
Poland.description: Located in the Kazimierz district, the historic Jewish quarter of Krakw. Serves as the hub of Jewish life in southern Poland, offering educational programs, holiday celebrations, and cultural events. The Krakw Jewish Culture Festival, held annually since 1988, is one of the largest in the world. Kazimierz was the setting for scenes in Schindler's List (1993).

Poland.description: Founded in 2004 by photographer Chris Schwarz in Krakw's Kazimierz district. The museum's core exhibition, 'Traces of Memory,' documents the remnants of Jewish civilization in the former Austrian region of Galicia through photographs. Hosts rotating exhibitions, lectures, and educational programs. Located in a restored Jewish-owned factory. Schwarz passed away in 2007 but his vision continues.

Reaches hundreds of schools across Poland and collaborates with diaspora communities worldwide.

Poland.description: Opened in 2013 on the site of the former Warsaw Ghetto. The core exhibition, designed by Barbara Kirshenblatt-Gimblett, tells the 1,000-year history of Polish Jews. Won the European Museum of the Year Award in 2016. Co-founded by the Polish government, the City of Warsaw, and the Association of the Jewish Historical Institute. Located at Anielewicza 6, facing the Monument to the Ghetto Heroes.

Poland.name: Auschwitz-Birkenau Memorial and Museum
Poland.description: The largest Nazi concentration and extermination camp, where approximately 1.1 million people were murdered, including 1 million Jews. Located near Owicim, Poland. UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1979. Over 2 million visitors annually. The camp was liberated by the Soviet Red Army on January 27, 1945 - now commemorated as International Holocaust Remembrance Day. Preserves original barracks, gas chambers, and personal effects of victims.

individuals.name: Piotr Cywiski
individuals.bio: Director of the Auschwitz-Birkenau Memorial and Museum since 2006. Oversees preservation and education programs.

Poland.name: Majdanek State Museum
Poland.description: Nazi German concentration and extermination camp on the outskirts of Lublin. Approximately 78,000 people were murdered here, including 59,000 Jews. One of the best-preserved camps because it was captured nearly intact by the Red Army in July 1944. The first major concentration camp to be liberated. Features original gas chambers, crematorium, and a massive dome-shaped mausoleum containing victims' ashes.

individuals.name: Tomasz Kranz
individuals.bio: Director of the Majdanek State Museum, where approximately 78,000 people were murdered including 59,000 Jews.

Poland.name: Treblinka Memorial
Poland.description: Memorial at the site of Treblinka II extermination camp, where approximately 900,000 people - mostly Jews - were murdered between July 1942 and October 1943. The Nazis demolished the camp to hide evidence. The memorial, designed by Adam Haupt and Franciszek Duszenko, features 17,000 rough granite stones representing the destroyed Jewish communities of Poland and Europe. A monument marks the location of the gas chambers.

individuals.name: Edward Kopwka
individuals.bio: Director of the Museum of Struggle and Martyrdom in Treblinka, where approximately 800,000 Jews were murdered.

Poland.name: Warsaw Ghetto Memorial
Poland.description: The Monument to the Ghetto Heroes, unveiled in 1948, commemorates the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising of April-May 1943 - the largest single revolt by Jews during WWII. Led by 24-year-old Mordechai Anielewicz and the Jewish Combat Organization (OB), approximately 750 fighters held off German forces for nearly a month. In 1970, West German Chancellor Willy Brandt knelt before the memorial in a historic gesture of reconciliation. The POLIN Museum was built facing this monument.

individuals.name: Mordechai Anielewicz
individuals.bio: Commander of the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising (April 1943, Jewish), the largest Jewish revolt against the Nazis. Killed at age 24.

Poland.name: Tykocin Synagogue
Poland.description: Built in 1642, the Great Synagogue of Tykocin is one of the best-preserved Baroque synagogues in Europe. The town had a thriving Jewish community from the 16th century. In August 1941, nearly 2,000 Jews from Tykocin were murdered in the opuchowo forest by Nazi Einsatzgruppen. The synagogue now serves as a museum with restored original frescoes and Judaica collection.

Poland.description: The official representative body of Jewish communities in Poland, recognized by the Polish state. Oversees Jewish religious life, community affairs, and property restitution claims. Works closely with POLIN Museum and international Jewish organizations. Poland had 3.3 million Jews before WWII - the largest Jewish community in Europe. Today approximately 10,000-20,000 Jews live in Poland.

Poland.description: Institute and museum documenting the history and culture of Polish Jews. Houses the Ringelblum Archive - a collection of documents from the Warsaw Ghetto hidden during WWII. UNESCO Memory of the World.

individuals.bio: Polish-Jewish historian who organized the secret Oyneg Shabes archive in the Warsaw Ghetto.

Czech Republic.name: Jewish Museum in Prague
Czech Republic.description: One of the oldest and largest Jewish museums in the world, founded in 1906. Ironically expanded during WWII when the Nazis intended to create a "Museum of an Extinct Race." Manages six historic sites in Prague's Josefov quarter including the Old Jewish Cemetery, Pinkas Synagogue, Spanish Synagogue, Maisel Synagogue, Klausen Synagogue, and Ceremonial Hall. Houses 40,000 objects and 100,000 books - one of the world's largest Judaica collections. Receives over 600,000 visitors annually.

individuals.name: Leo Pavlt
individuals.bio: Former director of the Jewish Museum in Prague (Jewish), one of the oldest and most visited Jewish museums in the world.

connections.name: Czech Republic Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Czech Republic.

connections.name: Czech Ministry of Culture
connections.description: One of the most-visited museums in the Czech Republic, supported by the Ministry of Culture.

connections.name: Nazi documentation
connections.description: Ironically, the Nazis expanded the collection, intending to create a 'Museum of an Extinct Race.'

connections.name: Six historic sites

connections.name: World's largest Judaica collection

Czech Republic.name: Old Jewish Cemetery (Prague)
Czech Republic.description: Used from the 15th century to 1787, one of the most remarkable Jewish burial grounds in Europe. Contains approximately 12,000 visible tombstones packed closely together, with estimates of up to 100,000 burials in multiple layers. Notable burials include Rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel (the Maharal of Prague, famous for the Golem legend, d. 1609), David Gans (astronomer and historian), and Mordecai Maisel (financier and mayor of the Jewish quarter).

individuals.name: Rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel
individuals.bio: The Maharal of Prague (c. 1520-1609, Jewish), legendary rabbi buried in the Old Jewish Cemetery, associated with the Golem legend.

Czech Republic.name: Pinkas Synagogue (Prague Holocaust Memorial)
Czech Republic.description: One of Prague's oldest synagogues, dating to 1479. Since 1954, it has served as a memorial to the Czech and Moravian victims of the Holocaust. The walls are inscribed with the names of 77,297 Jewish men, women, and children who perished. The upper floor houses a deeply moving exhibition of drawings by children imprisoned at the Terezn concentration camp, most of whom did not survive.

individuals.name: Ji Fiedler
individuals.bio: Czech researcher and documenter of Jewish heritage sites, whose work helped catalog the 77,297 names inscribed on the synagogue walls.

connections.name: 15th century origins
connections.description: One of the oldest synagogues in Prague, dating to 1479.

Czech Republic.name: Terezn Memorial
Czech Republic.description: Memorial at the site of Theresienstadt, a former fortress town the Nazis converted into a hybrid ghetto-concentration camp (1941-1945). Over 150,000 Jews were sent there; 33,000 died in the ghetto and 88,000 were deported to extermination camps. Despite conditions, inmates created remarkable cultural works including the children's opera Brundibr. The Nazis staged a Red Cross visit in 1944, filming propaganda portraying it as a "model Jewish settlement." Now a major memorial and museum.

individuals.name: Jan Munk
individuals.bio: Director of the Terezn Memorial, commemorating the ghetto/transit camp where 33,000 Jews died and 88,000 were deported to death camps.

connections.name: Terezn concentration camp
connections.description: Memorial at the site of Theresienstadt, which the Nazis used as a transit camp and propaganda tool.

connections.name: Czech Ministry of Culture

connections.name: Red Cross deception
connections.description: Nazis staged a Red Cross visit in 1944, creating a propaganda film showing Terezn as a 'model Jewish settlement.'

connections.name: Yad Vashem
connections.description: Collaborates with Yad Vashem on documentation and research.

connections.name: Cultural life under persecution
connections.description: Despite horrific conditions, Terezn inmates created art, music, opera, and literature - including the children's opera Brundibr.

Czech Republic.name: Federation of Jewish Communities in the Czech Republic
Czech Republic.description: Umbrella organization representing 10 Jewish communities across the Czech Republic. Re-established after the Velvet Revolution of 1989. The Czech Jewish community was devastated during the Holocaust - of approximately 118,000 Jews in the Bohemian lands before WWII, only about 14,000 survived. Today approximately 3,000-4,000 Jews live in the Czech Republic. The federation oversees religious life, cultural events, and property restitution.

individuals.name: Petr Papouek
individuals.bio: President of the Federation of Jewish Communities in the Czech Republic, leading community development and interfaith dialogue.

Czech Republic.description: Federation of Jewish Communities in the Czech Republic, representing approximately 3,000 members across 10 communities.

Czech Republic.name: Old-New Synagogue (Altneuschul)
Czech Republic.description: The oldest active synagogue in Europe, located in Prague's Jewish Quarter (Josefov). Built in Gothic style. Associated with the legend of the Golem of Prague created by Rabbi Loew.

individuals.name: Rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel
individuals.bio: The Maharal of Prague, renowned Talmudist and philosopher, creator of the legendary Golem.

Czech Republic.name: Jewish Quarter of Prague (Josefov)
Czech Republic.description: Historic Jewish quarter of Prague containing the Old Jewish Cemetery, the Old-New Synagogue (oldest active synagogue in Europe, 1270), and several other synagogues now serving as museums.

Ukraine.name: Menorah Center (Dnipro)
Ukraine.description: The world's largest menorah-shaped building, a seven-towered structure in Dnipro (formerly Dnepropetrovsk), Ukraine. Built by Jewish-Ukrainian billionaire Gennadiy Bogolubov, it houses a Jewish community center, museum, synagogue, hotel, kosher restaurants, and offices. Dnipro has one of Ukraine's largest Jewish communities, historically a major center of Jewish life. The center is closely affiliated with Chabad of Dnipro, led by Chief Rabbi Shmuel Kaminezki.

individuals.name: Gennadiy Bogolubov
individuals.bio: Ukrainian-Jewish billionaire, co-owner of PrivatBank, who funded the construction of the Menorah Center in Dnipro.

connections.description: Serves as the cultural and community hub for Dnipro's large Jewish population.

Ukraine.name: United Jewish Community of Ukraine
Ukraine.description: Represents Jewish communities across Ukraine, working on community development, welfare, and cultural preservation. Following Russia's 2022 invasion, played a crucial role in coordinating evacuation and humanitarian assistance for Ukrainian Jews. Partners with the Jewish Agency for Israel, JDC, and Israeli government on community support. Ukraine's Jewish community numbers approximately 50,000-200,000 depending on criteria used.

individuals.name: Meylakh Sheykhet
individuals.bio: Representative of the Union of Jewish Religious Organizations of Ukraine, active in heritage preservation.

Ukraine.name: Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial Center
Ukraine.description: Memorial center at the ravine in Kyiv where Nazi Einsatzgruppen massacred 33,771 Jews on September 29-30, 1941 - one of the largest single mass shootings of the Holocaust. Over the following months, an estimated 100,000-150,000 people were killed there. Soviet authorities suppressed the Jewish identity of victims for decades. The modern memorial center, supported by Ronald Lauder and others, uses cutting-edge technology to document the tragedy. Damaged by Russian missile strike in 2022.

individuals.name: Natan Sharansky
individuals.bio: Former Soviet dissident, Israeli politician (Jewish), and chairman of the Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial Center supervisory board.

connections.name: Ukraine Jewish community

connections.name: Babi Yar massacre
connections.description: At Babi Yar in Kyiv, Nazis massacred 33,771 Jews in just two days - September 29-30, 1941.

connections.name: Ukrainian government
connections.description: Supported by the Ukrainian government as a national memorial site.

connections.name: Ilya Ehrenburg
connections.description: Soviet-Jewish writer Ilya Ehrenburg and Vasily Grossman documented the massacre in The Black Book.

connections.name: Yad Vashem

connections.name: Ronald Lauder
connections.description: Ronald Lauder (Jewish, Este Lauder heir) has been a major supporter of the memorial center.

Ukraine.name: Golden Rose Synagogue (Lviv, ruins)
Ukraine.description: Ruins of the Golden Rose Synagogue (Turei Zahav), built in 1582 in Lviv's Jewish quarter. One of the finest Renaissance synagogues in Eastern Europe, it was destroyed by the Nazis in 1941. Lviv (known historically as Lemberg) was home to approximately 110,000 Jews before WWII - nearly all were murdered in the Holocaust. The ruins are now part of the "Space of Synagogues" memorial project, designed by German architect Franz Reschke, preserving the memory of three destroyed synagogues.

individuals.name: Isaac ben Nachman
individuals.bio: Builder of the original Golden Rose Synagogue (1582) in Lviv, one of the earliest stone synagogues in Eastern Europe. Destroyed by Nazis in 1943.

connections.name: Lviv Jewish community
connections.description: Lviv (Lemberg) was a major center of Jewish culture, home to approximately 110,000 Jews before WWII.

Ukraine.name: Uman (Breslov pilgrimage)
Ukraine.description: Annual mass pilgrimage of Breslov Hasidim to the grave of Rabbi Nachman of Breslov (1772-1810) in Uman, Ukraine. Rabbi Nachman, great-grandson of the Baal Shem Tov (founder of Hasidism), requested that followers visit his grave on Rosh Hashanah. The pilgrimage has grown from hundreds to 30,000-50,000 annually, making it one of the largest Jewish pilgrimages in the world. Requires major Ukrainian-Israeli diplomatic coordination for security and logistics.

individuals.name: Rabbi Nachman of Breslov

Ukraine.name: Jewish Confederation of Ukraine
Ukraine.description: Umbrella organization representing Jewish communities across Ukraine. Ukraine has deep Jewish roots - it was the birthplace of Hasidism (founded by the Baal Shem Tov in the 1740s). Before WWII, Ukraine had approximately 2.7 million Jews; over 1.5 million were murdered in the Holocaust. President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is Jewish. The community has faced additional challenges since Russia's 2022 invasion, with Jewish organizations providing humanitarian aid.

Ukraine.description: Memorial and museum complex at Babi Yar in Kyiv, site of one of the largest mass shootings of the Holocaust. On September 29-30, 1941, Nazi forces murdered 33,771 Jews in a single operation.

Turkey.name: Turkish Jewish Community
Turkey.description: Sephardic Jewish community descended primarily from Jews expelled from Spain and Portugal in 1492, who were welcomed into the Ottoman Empire by Sultan Bayezid II. The community once numbered over 100,000 and played a significant role in Ottoman commerce, diplomacy, and culture. Istanbul's Neve Shalom Synagogue, which has been the target of multiple terrorist attacks (1986, 2003), serves as the community's main house of worship. Turkish Jews preserved Ladino (Judeo-Spanish) for centuries, maintaining a unique linguistic and cultural heritage. Today approximately 15,000-20,000 Jews remain, centered in Istanbul and Izmir. Despite Turkey's increasingly strained relations with Israel under President Erdogan, the community has maintained a delicate balance between Turkish patriotism and Jewish identity. The Quincentennial Foundation celebrated the community's 500th anniversary in 1992.

individuals.name: shak Haleva
individuals.bio: Hakham Bashi (Chief Rabbi) of Turkey (Jewish), leading approximately 15,000 Jews, mostly in Istanbul.

connections.name: Israel-Turkey relations
connections.description: Turkey was the first Muslim-majority country to recognize Israel (1949).

Turkey.name: Quincentennial Foundation Museum (Istanbul)
Turkey.description: Established in 2001 to commemorate 500 years of Jewish presence in Turkey, dating to Sultan Bayezid II welcoming Jews expelled from Spain in 1492. The museum, housed in a restored synagogue in Karaky, Istanbul, documents the rich Sephardic heritage of Turkish Jews, including the Ladino language, customs, and contributions to Ottoman society. Turkey's Jewish community today numbers approximately 15,000, mostly in Istanbul.

individuals.name: Naim Gleryz
individuals.bio: Historian and author (Jewish, Turkish) who documented the 500-year history of Turkish Jewry since the 1492 Spanish expulsion.

Turkey.name: Ahrida Synagogue (Istanbul)
Turkey.description: One of the oldest synagogues in Istanbul, dating to the 15th century and possibly earlier. Founded by Romaniote Jews from Ohrid (now North Macedonia). Famous for its unique ship-shaped wooden bimah, possibly symbolizing Noah's Ark or the ships that brought Jews to the Ottoman Empire. Located in the historic Balat neighborhood on the Golden Horn, once the center of Istanbul's Jewish quarter. Still an active place of worship.

individuals.name: Bayezid II
individuals.bio: Ottoman Sultan who welcomed Sephardic Jews expelled from Spain in 1492, famously saying Ferdinand of Spain made his own country poor.

Turkey.name: Chief Rabbinate of Turkey
Turkey.description: The Chief Rabbi (Hakham Bashi) of Turkey leads the country's Jewish community, a position dating to the Ottoman Empire. The current chief rabbi oversees approximately 15,000 Jews, primarily in Istanbul with smaller communities in Izmir and Ankara. The community follows Sephardic traditions brought from Spain after 1492. The Chief Rabbinate navigates the complex relationship between Turkey, Israel, and the Jewish diaspora.

Turkey.name: Neve Shalom Synagogue (Istanbul)
Turkey.description: The main synagogue of Istanbul's Jewish community, located in the Beyolu district. Founded in 1951, it has been the target of multiple terrorist attacks: in 1986, Abu Nidal's group killed 22 worshippers during Shabbat services; in 2003, a suicide bombing killed 6 people. Despite these tragedies, the congregation has persevered and the synagogue remains an active center of Jewish worship in Istanbul. Under heavy security protection.

Turkey.description: Turkish Jewish community, tracing roots to the arrival of Sephardic Jews expelled from Spain. Approximately 15,000 Jews live in Turkey, mostly in Istanbul. Maintains 16 synagogues.

Morocco.name: Bayt Dakira (House of Memory, Essaouira)
Morocco.description: Heritage center and museum inaugurated by King Mohammed VI in January 2020, located in the restored Slat Al Fassiyine Synagogue in Essaouira (formerly Mogador). Essaouira's Jewish community once comprised nearly 40% of the town's population. Andr Azoulay, senior adviser to the King and Essaouira native, was instrumental in creating the center. Includes a synagogue, genealogical research center, and exhibition space documenting Jewish-Muslim coexistence in Morocco.

individuals.name: Andr Azoulay
individuals.bio: Senior advisor to King Mohammed VI (Jewish, Moroccan), champion of interfaith dialogue and the Bayt Dakira heritage project.

connections.name: Essaouira Jewish heritage

Morocco.name: Museum of Moroccan Judaism (Casablanca)
Morocco.description: The only Jewish museum in the Arab world, opened in 1997 in Casablanca. Houses a rich collection of Sephardic and Moroccan Jewish artifacts including Torah scrolls, menorahs, traditional garments, and photographs documenting centuries of Jewish life in Morocco. Morocco's Jewish community once numbered over 250,000 and contributed significantly to the country's commerce, culture, and governance. The museum is a powerful symbol of Morocco's commitment to preserving its multicultural heritage.

individuals.name: Zhor Rehihil
individuals.bio: Curator of the Museum of Moroccan Judaism (Muslim), the only Jewish museum in the Arab world, demonstrating Moroccan interfaith respect.

Morocco.name: Casablanca Jewish Heritage Trail
Morocco.description: Heritage trail in Casablanca connecting sites of Jewish significance including the Museum of Moroccan Judaism, historic synagogues, the mellah (Jewish quarter), and Jewish cemeteries. Casablanca had a large and prosperous Jewish community in the 20th century, contributing to banking, commerce, and industry. Tourism from Israel has increased significantly following the 2020 Abraham Accords. The trail showcases centuries of Jewish-Muslim coexistence.

Morocco.name: Rabbi Haim Pinto Synagogue (Essaouira)
Morocco.description: Synagogue in Essaouira named after Rabbi Haim Pinto (1748-1845), one of Morocco's most venerated rabbis and kabbalists. The annual Hilulah pilgrimage to his shrine draws thousands of Jewish visitors from Israel and the diaspora. Part of a unique Moroccan-Jewish tradition of venerating holy rabbis (tzaddikim) at their tombs - a practice shared with and respected by Moroccan Muslims. The synagogue has been restored with support from the Moroccan government.

individuals.name: Rabbi Haim Pinto
individuals.bio: 18th-century Moroccan rabbi (Jewish) revered as a miracle worker; his yahrzeit draws thousands of pilgrims to Essaouira.

Morocco.name: Council of Jewish Communities of Morocco
Morocco.description: Represents Morocco's Jewish community, which numbered over 250,000 in the 1940s and today numbers approximately 2,000-3,000 - one of the largest remaining Jewish communities in the Arab world. Morocco's King Mohammed VI has actively supported Jewish heritage preservation, including renovating synagogues and cemeteries. Andr Azoulay (Jewish), senior adviser to both King Mohammed VI and his father, has been instrumental in promoting coexistence. Morocco normalized relations with Israel in 2020.

Morocco.description: Jewish heritage center in Essaouira, Morocco. Inaugurated by King Mohammed VI. Houses a synagogue, museum, and research center dedicated to Morocco's Jewish heritage.

Iran.name: Tehran Jewish Committee
Iran.description: Represents Iran's Jewish community - one of the oldest in the world, dating back over 2,700 years to the Babylonian exile. Iran's constitution guarantees Jews one seat in the Majlis (parliament). The community maintains synagogues, schools, and a hospital in Tehran. From approximately 80,000 before the 1979 Islamic Revolution, the community has declined to 8,000-10,000 - still the largest Jewish population in the Middle East outside Israel. The Tomb of Esther and Mordechai in Hamadan is a major heritage site.

individuals.name: Homayoun Sameyah Najafabadi
individuals.bio: Jewish member of the Iranian Majlis (parliament), holding the constitutionally guaranteed seat for the Jewish community.

connections.name: Iran Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Iran.

connections.name: Iranian parliament seat
connections.description: Iranian Jews have one guaranteed seat in the Majlis (parliament) under Iran's constitution.

connections.name: Ancient community
connections.description: Jews have lived in Iran for over 2,700 years, making it one of the oldest Jewish communities in the world.

connections.name: Esther and Mordechai tomb
connections.description: The Tomb of Esther and Mordechai in Hamadan is one of Iran's most important Jewish heritage sites.

connections.name: Post-revolution decline
connections.description: From 80,000 Jews before the 1979 revolution, the community has declined to approximately 8,000-10,000.

Ethiopia.name: Beta Israel Community Organizations
Ethiopia.description: Beta Israel (House of Israel) - the Ethiopian Jewish community - maintained Jewish practice for centuries in isolation. Their traditions include unique holidays like Sigd. Two dramatic Israeli airlifts rescued them: Operation Moses (1984, ~8,000 Jews through Sudan) and Operation Solomon (1991, 14,325 in 36 hours - a world record). Approximately 170,000 Ethiopian-origin Jews now live in Israel. Remaining communities in Ethiopia include Falash Mura (descendants who converted to Christianity).

individuals.name: Avraham Neguise
individuals.bio: Ethiopian-born Israeli politician (Jewish), first Ethiopian-born member of the Knesset, advocate for Ethiopian Jewish rights.

connections.name: Ethiopia Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Ethiopia.

connections.name: Operation Solomon
connections.description: In May 1991, Operation Solomon airlifted 14,325 Ethiopian Jews to Israel in 36 hours.

connections.name: Operation Moses
connections.description: In 1984, Operation Moses covertly airlifted approximately 8,000 Ethiopian Jews through Sudan.

connections.name: Israeli government
connections.description: The Israeli government recognizes Beta Israel as Jews and supports their integration.

connections.name: Absorption challenges
connections.description: Ethiopian-Israelis have faced significant challenges in integration, education, and combating discrimination.

Ethiopia.name: Operation Solomon Memorial
Ethiopia.description: Commemorates Operation Solomon (May 24-25, 1991), when Israeli Air Force and El Al flights airlifted 14,325 Ethiopian Jews to Israel in just 36 hours as the Mengistu regime collapsed. A world record was set when a single Boeing 747 carried 1,122 passengers (two babies were born during the flight). The operation was followed by smaller subsequent airlifts. Combined with Operation Moses (1984), these airlifts brought most of Ethiopia's Jewish community to Israel.

individuals.name: Uri Lubrani
individuals.bio: Israeli diplomat (Jewish) who coordinated Operation Solomon, the dramatic 36-hour airlift of 14,325 Ethiopian Jews in 1991.

connections.name: Ethiopia Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Ethiopia.

connections.name: Israeli Air Force
connections.description: Israeli Air Force planes carried out the airlift, with a world record 1,122 passengers on a single Boeing 747.

connections.name: Mengistu regime collapse
connections.description: The airlift was carried out as the Mengistu regime collapsed and rebel forces advanced on Addis Ababa.

connections.name: 14,325 rescued in 36 hours
connections.description: 14,325 Ethiopian Jews were airlifted to Israel in just 36 hours on May 24-25, 1991.

Ethiopia.name: North Shewa Synagogue
Ethiopia.description: Synagogue serving the Beta Israel community in North Shewa, Ethiopia. Beta Israel practiced an ancient form of Judaism centered on the Torah and the Book of Jubilees, without knowledge of the Talmud or post-biblical rabbinic traditions. Their prayer houses (mesgids) were led by religious leaders called kessim. Most of the North Shewa Jewish community emigrated to Israel during the Operations Moses (1984) and Solomon (1991) airlifts.

individuals.name: Qes Hadane
individuals.bio: One of the last kessim (Bete Israel religious leaders) who served the North Shewa community before emigration.

connections.name: Ethiopia Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Ethiopia.

connections.name: Beta Israel community
connections.description: Served the Beta Israel community in the North Shewa zone of Ethiopia.

connections.name: Ancient Jewish practice
connections.description: Beta Israel practiced an ancient form of Judaism based on the Torah, without Talmudic traditions.

connections.name: Aliyah
connections.description: Most of the congregation emigrated to Israel during Operations Moses and Solomon.

Ethiopia.name: Ethiopian Jewish Community (Beta Israel)
Ethiopia.description: The Beta Israel, or Ethiopian Jews, are one of the world's oldest Jewish communities. Most were airlifted to Israel during Operations Moses (1984), Joshua (1985), and Solomon (1991). About 135,000 Ethiopian Jews now live in Israel.

connections.name: State of Israel
connections.description: Mass immigration of Ethiopian Jews to Israel through dramatic airlifts.

Ethiopia.name: North Shewa Zone Heritage Center
Ethiopia.description: Center documenting Beta Israel (Ethiopian Jewish) history and culture. Most Ethiopian Jews (approximately 95,000) were airlifted to Israel in Operations Moses (1984) and Solomon (1991). Approximately 8,000 Falash Mura remain.

connections.name: Yad Vashem
connections.description: Both preserve Jewish history and memory

Japan.name: Jewish Community of Japan
Japan.description: Small but active Jewish community in Japan numbering approximately 1,000-2,000 people, centered in Tokyo with smaller groups in Osaka and Kobe. The Tokyo Jewish Community Center serves as the hub. During WWII, Japan had a complex relationship with Jews - the "Fugu Plan" proposed settling Jewish refugees in Manchuria, and diplomats like Chiune Sugihara saved thousands. Today the community includes Israeli expats, American residents, and businesspeople.

individuals.name: Binyamin Edery
individuals.bio: Chabad rabbi serving the Jewish community of Japan, based in Tokyo.

connections.name: Japan Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Japan.

connections.name: Tokyo JCC
connections.description: The Tokyo Jewish Community Center serves as the hub of Jewish life in Japan.

connections.name: Chabad Japan
connections.description: Chabad-Lubavitch operates community centers in Tokyo and other Japanese cities.

connections.name: Israeli embassy
connections.description: Works closely with the Israeli embassy in Tokyo on community affairs.

connections.name: Fugu Plan
connections.description: During WWII, some Japanese officials proposed the 'Fugu Plan' to settle Jewish refugees in Manchuria.

Japan.name: Kobe Jewish Community
Japan.description: Historic Jewish community in Kobe, Japan, significant as a transit point for Jewish refugees during WWII. In 1940-1941, approximately 4,500 Jewish refugees - many carrying Sugihara visas - passed through Kobe before continuing to Shanghai or the Americas. The local community and the Jewcom (Jewish Committee) of Kobe provided crucial assistance. The Ohel Shelomo Synagogue served the community from 1912 to 1970.

individuals.name: Anatole Ponevejsky
individuals.bio: Leader of the Kobe Jewish community (Jewcom) during WWII who helped coordinate aid for Jewish refugees transiting through Japan.

connections.name: Japan Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Japan.

connections.name: WWII transit point
connections.description: Kobe was a key transit point for Jewish refugees fleeing Europe via Japan in 1940-1941.

connections.name: Sugihara refugees
connections.description: Many Jews saved by Sugihara passed through Kobe before continuing to Shanghai or the Americas.

connections.name: Ohel Shelomo Synagogue
connections.description: The former Ohel Shelomo Synagogue served the community until 1970.

Japan.name: Sugihara Museum (Yaotsu)
Japan.description: Museum in Yaotsu, Gifu Prefecture, honoring Chiune Sugihara - the Japanese diplomat who saved over 6,000 Jews by issuing transit visas in Kaunas, Lithuania in 1940, defying government orders. Among those saved was the entire Mir Yeshiva - the only European yeshiva that survived the Holocaust intact. Recognized as Righteous Among the Nations by Yad Vashem in 1985. Called the "Japanese Schindler," Sugihara was largely forgotten in Japan until decades after WWII.

individuals.name: Chiune Sugihara
individuals.bio: Japanese diplomat who issued visas saving thousands of Jews.

connections.name: Japan Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Japan.

connections.name: Chiune Sugihara
connections.description: Chiune Sugihara is a key figure associated with Sugihara Museum (Yaotsu).

connections.name: Yad Vashem
connections.description: Sugihara was recognized as Righteous Among the Nations by Yad Vashem in 1985.

connections.name: Lithuanian consul
connections.description: As Japanese vice-consul in Kaunas, Lithuania, Sugihara issued visas against government orders.

connections.name: Mir Yeshiva
connections.description: Among those saved was the entire Mir Yeshiva, the only European yeshiva to survive the Holocaust intact.

Japan.name: Jewish Community of Kobe
Japan.description: Historic Jewish community in Kobe, which sheltered thousands of Jewish refugees during WWII, including those who received transit visas from Chiune Sugihara.

individuals.name: Chiune Sugihara
individuals.bio: Japanese diplomat who saved 6,000 Jews during the Holocaust by issuing transit visas, recognized as Righteous Among the Nations.

Japan.name: SoftBank Group
Japan.description: Japanese multinational holding company headquartered in Tokyo. Founded by Masayoshi Son. Operates the $100 billion Vision Fund, the world's largest technology-focused venture capital fund. Investments include Alibaba, ARM Holdings, WeWork, DoorDash.

individuals.name: Masayoshi Son
individuals.bio: Japanese-Korean billionaire who founded SoftBank. One of the world's most prolific tech investors.

Japan.name: Sony Group
Japan.description: Japanese multinational conglomerate. Businesses include PlayStation, Sony Pictures, Sony Music, electronics, and financial services. One of the world's largest entertainment companies.

individuals.name: Akio Morita
individuals.bio: Japanese businessman who co-founded Sony and was instrumental in making it a global brand.

Japan.name: Toyota Motor Corporation
Japan.description: World's largest automaker by volume. Headquartered in Toyota City, Aichi. Pioneer of lean manufacturing and the Toyota Production System. Revenue exceeds $300 billion.

individuals.name: Akio Toyoda
individuals.bio: Great-grandson of founder Sakichi Toyoda, led Toyota as president and now serves as chairman.

Japan.name: Makuya
Japan.description: Japanese pro-Israel and philo-Semitic movement. Members learn Hebrew, celebrate Jewish holidays, and have strong connections to Israel. Founded by Abraham Ikuro Teshima.

individuals.name: Abraham Ikuro Teshima
individuals.bio: Japanese Christian leader who founded the Makuya movement and fostered deep ties with Israel.

China.name: Shanghai Jewish Refugees Museum
China.description: Located in the former Ohel Moishe Synagogue in Shanghai's Hongkou district. Documents the story of approximately 20,000 Jewish refugees who found haven in Shanghai during WWII - one of the few places in the world accepting Jews without visas. Despite Japanese restrictions confining Jews to the "Restricted Sector" from 1943, the Shanghai Jewish community survived the war. The museum is a powerful symbol of Chinese-Jewish friendship and has been expanded and renovated by the Chinese government.

individuals.name: Chen Jian
individuals.bio: Former curator of the Shanghai Jewish Refugees Museum, documenting the stories of 20,000 Jewish refugees.

connections.name: China Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in China.

connections.name: Shanghai Ghetto
connections.description: Documents the story of approximately 20,000 Jewish refugees who found haven in Shanghai during WWII.

connections.name: Ohel Moishe Synagogue
connections.description: Located in the former Ohel Moishe Synagogue in the Hongkou district.

connections.name: Japanese occupation
connections.description: Under Japanese occupation, Jews were confined to the Restricted Sector for Stateless Refugees.

connections.name: Chinese-Israeli relations
connections.description: The museum has become a symbol of Chinese-Jewish friendship and Chinese-Israeli diplomacy.

China.name: Kaifeng Jewish Community
China.description: One of the most remarkable diaspora communities in Jewish history. Jews arrived in Kaifeng, China via the Silk Road as early as the 7th century CE. Stone inscriptions from 1489-1663 and Jesuit documentation from 1605 confirm a thriving community with a synagogue, Torah scrolls, and rabbis. The community gradually assimilated over centuries after the last rabbi died in the early 1800s. In recent decades, some descendants have reconnected with Judaism, and a few have made aliyah to Israel. DNA studies confirm Middle Eastern ancestry.

individuals.name: Shi Lei
individuals.bio: One of the Kaifeng Jewish descendants who reconnected with Judaism and made aliyah to Israel.

connections.name: China Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in China.

connections.name: Ancient Silk Road
connections.description: Jews arrived in Kaifeng via the Silk Road as early as the 7th century CE.

connections.name: Matteo Ricci
connections.description: Jesuit priest Matteo Ricci documented the community in 1605 after meeting a Kaifeng Jew in Beijing.

connections.name: Kaifeng stone inscriptions
connections.description: Stone inscriptions from 1489, 1512, and 1663 document the community's history.

connections.name: Modern reconnection
connections.description: In recent decades, some Kaifeng descendants have reconnected with Judaism and made aliyah to Israel.

China.name: Sassoon House (Shanghai)
China.description: Art Deco landmark on Shanghai's famous Bund waterfront, built in 1929 by Sir Victor Sassoon (Jewish, of Baghdadi origin). Originally the Cathay Hotel - the most luxurious hotel in Asia - it is now the Fairmont Peace Hotel. The Sassoon family, known as "the Rothschilds of the East," built a vast business empire spanning from Baghdad to Bombay to Shanghai. Victor Sassoon also helped refugee Jews during WWII, providing housing in properties he owned.

individuals.name: Sir Victor Sassoon
individuals.bio: Jewish businessman of Baghdadi origin, built the Cathay Hotel (now Fairmont Peace Hotel) and was one of the wealthiest men in Asia.

connections.name: China Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in China.

connections.name: The Bund

connections.name: Cathay Hotel

China.name: Ohel Rachel Synagogue (Shanghai)
China.description: The largest synagogue in East Asia, built in 1920 by Sir Jacob Elias Sassoon (Jewish, Baghdadi origin) and named after his wife Rachel. Located in Shanghai's former French Concession, it served the Sephardic/Baghdadi Jewish community. The Greek Revival-style building seats 700 people. Currently used by the Shanghai Municipal Education Commission but occasionally opens for Jewish services. A key landmark of Shanghai's Jewish heritage.

individuals.name: Sir Jacob Elias Sassoon
individuals.bio: Jewish businessman of Baghdadi origin who built the Ohel Rachel Synagogue (1920), the largest synagogue in East Asia.

connections.description: The largest synagogue in East Asia, capable of seating 700 people.

China.name: Ohel Rachel Synagogue
China.description: Historic synagogue in Shanghai built by Sir Jacob Elias Sassoon. One of the last remaining synagogues in China, located on North Shaanxi Road. Now protected as a cultural heritage site.

individuals.name: Jacob Elias Sassoon
individuals.bio: Baghdadi Jewish businessman who built the Ohel Rachel Synagogue in memory of his wife.

China.name: Tencent
China.description: Chinese multinational technology company. One of the world's most valuable companies. Operates WeChat (1.3 billion users), QQ, and extensive gaming divisions including majority ownership of Riot Games. Market cap exceeds $400 billion.

individuals.bio: Chinese billionaire entrepreneur who co-founded Tencent.

China.name: Alibaba Group
China.description: Chinese multinational technology company specializing in e-commerce, retail, and cloud computing. Founded by Jack Ma. Operates Taobao, Tmall, AliExpress, and Alibaba Cloud.

individuals.name: Jack Ma
individuals.bio: Chinese billionaire entrepreneur who founded Alibaba Group.

Singapore.name: United Hebrew Congregation of Singapore
Singapore.description: Represents Singapore's Jewish community of approximately 2,500 people. The community has roots in 19th-century Baghdadi Jewish merchants, including the Sassoon family. The Maghain Aboth Synagogue (1878) is the oldest synagogue in Southeast Asia. David Marshall (Jewish, Baghdadi origin) served as Singapore's first Chief Minister (1955-1956). Today the community is diverse, including expats from Israel, the US, Australia, and elsewhere.

individuals.name: David Marshall
individuals.bio: Singapore's first Chief Minister (1955-1956), Jewish politician of Baghdadi-Iraqi origin. Champion of Singapore's independence movement.

connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Singapore.

connections.name: Baghdadi Jewish origins
connections.description: Founded by Baghdadi Jewish merchants including the Sassoon family in the 19th century.

connections.name: Maghain Aboth Synagogue

connections.name: David Marshall

Singapore.name: Singapore Jewish Welfare Board
Singapore.description: Central body serving Singapore's Jewish community of approximately 2,500 members. Manages communal affairs, welfare services, and cultural programs. Oversees the historic Maghain Aboth Synagogue (1878) and Chesed-El Synagogue (1905), both national monuments.

individuals.name: David Marshall
individuals.bio: Singapore's first Chief Minister (1955-1956), a Sephardic Jew from a Baghdadi Jewish family who played a crucial role in Singapore's path to independence.

connections.name: World Jewish Congress
connections.description: Affiliated member representing Southeast Asian Jewry.

Singapore.name: Maghain Aboth Synagogue
Singapore.description: Oldest synagogue in Southeast Asia, located in Singapore. Built by the Baghdadi Jewish community, particularly the Sassoon family. A national monument of Singapore.

Singapore.name: Jewish Welfare Board Singapore
Singapore.description: Serves the Jewish community of Singapore, which numbers approximately 2,500. Operates educational programs and community events.

Panama.name: Kol Shearith Israel
Panama.description: The main synagogue serving Panama's Jewish community of approximately 10,000-15,000 people. The community grew alongside the construction of the Panama Canal. Panama has one of the most Sephardic-leaning Jewish communities in Latin America, with members tracing roots to Syria, Turkey, and Caribbean islands like Curaao. Panamanian Jews have been prominent in business, politics, and professional life.

individuals.name: Gustavo Kraselnik
individuals.bio: Former president of the Panama Jewish community, editor of Shalom Panama magazine.

connections.description: Serves Panama's Jewish community of approximately 10,000-15,000.

Panama.name: Colegio Instituto Alberto Einstein
Panama.description: Jewish day school in Panama City serving the Jewish community of Panama.

Uruguay.name: Comit Central Israelita del Uruguay
Uruguay.description: Central representative body of Uruguay's Jewish community, based in Montevideo. Uruguay has approximately 12,000-17,000 Jews, one of the largest Jewish communities per capita in Latin America. The community includes descendants of Eastern European immigrants who arrived in the early 20th century. Uruguay was one of the first countries to vote in favor of the UN Partition Plan for Palestine in 1947. Maintains synagogues, schools, and cultural institutions.

individuals.name: Ricardo Lackner
individuals.bio: Former president of the Comit Central Israelita del Uruguay (Jewish).

Uruguay.name: Comunidad Israelita del Uruguay
Uruguay.description: Main Ashkenazi Jewish community organization in Uruguay, operating synagogues, cultural programs, and social services.

Chile.name: Comunidad Juda de Chile
Chile.description: Represents Chile's Jewish community of approximately 18,000, centered in Santiago. The community arrived primarily from Eastern Europe in the early 20th century. Chile uniquely has both the world's largest Palestinian diaspora and a significant Jewish community, creating complex interfaith dynamics. The Estadio Israelita Maccabi is a major community center. Chilean Jews have contributed to business, politics, and culture.

individuals.name: Gerardo Gorodischer
individuals.bio: President of the Comunidad Juda de Chile (Jewish), representing 18,000 Chilean Jews.

Chile.name: Comunidad Juda de Chile
Chile.description: Central representative body for Chile's Jewish community of approximately 18,000. Manages community affairs, education, and cultural programming. Chile has the third-largest Jewish population in South America, with most members concentrated in Santiago.

individuals.name: Gerardo Gorodischer
individuals.bio: Leader of the Chilean Jewish community working on interfaith dialogue and community development.

connections.name: World Jewish Congress
connections.description: Chilean affiliate of the World Jewish Congress.

Chile.description: Prestigious Jewish day school in Santiago, Chile. Named after Israel's first president, Chaim Weizmann. One of the top-rated schools in Chile.

Colombia.name: Confederacin de Comunidades Judas de Colombia
Colombia.description: Umbrella organization representing approximately 4,000-5,000 Jews in Colombia, centered in Bogot with smaller communities in Medelln, Cali, and Barranquilla. Some trace ancestry to Sephardic conversos (crypto-Jews) who arrived during the Spanish colonial period. The modern community grew with 20th-century immigration from Eastern Europe, Syria, and Lebanon. Operates synagogues, schools (Colegio Colombo Hebreo), and social institutions.

individuals.name: Marco Peckel
individuals.bio: Former president of the Confederacin de Comunidades Judas de Colombia (Jewish).

connections.name: Colombia Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Colombia.

connections.description: Most of Colombia's 4,000-5,000 Jews live in Bogot.

connections.name: Sephardic heritage
connections.description: Some Colombian Jews trace ancestry to Sephardic conversos who came during the colonial period.

Colombia.name: Confederacin de Comunidades Judas de Colombia
Colombia.description: Umbrella organization for Colombia's approximately 5,000 Jews. Coordinates activities among communities in Bogot, Medelln, Cali, and Barranquilla. The community includes Ashkenazi, Sephardic, and Syrian Jewish congregations, each maintaining distinct traditions.

individuals.name: Isaac Lee
individuals.bio: Colombian-Jewish media executive who served as chief content officer at Univision, notable member of the Colombian Jewish community.

connections.name: DAIA

Colombia.name: Colegio Colombo Hebreo
Colombia.description: Jewish day school in Bogot, one of the most prestigious private schools in Colombia. Provides trilingual education (Spanish, Hebrew, English).

New Zealand.name: New Zealand Jewish Council
New Zealand.description: Official representative body of approximately 7,500 Jews in New Zealand, with communities in Auckland, Wellington, Christchurch, and Dunedin. The Auckland Hebrew Congregation, founded in 1840, is one of the oldest in Australasia. New Zealand Jewish community showed remarkable solidarity following the 2019 Christchurch mosque shooting. Notable New Zealand Jews include former Prime Minister John Key and nuclear physicist Ernest Rutherford's collaborators.

individuals.name: Juliet Moses
individuals.bio: Spokesperson for the New Zealand Jewish Council (Jewish), prominent advocate against antisemitism.

connections.name: New Zealand Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in New Zealand.

connections.description: Jewish community showed strong solidarity after the 2019 Christchurch mosque shooting.

connections.description: The Auckland Hebrew Congregation (founded 1840) is the oldest Jewish community in New Zealand.

New Zealand.name: Auckland Hebrew Congregation
New Zealand.description: Main Jewish congregation in Auckland, New Zealand's largest city. Serves several hundred families.

New Zealand.name: Wellington Hebrew Congregation
New Zealand.description: Oldest Jewish congregation in New Zealand, established just three years after formal European settlement began. Wellington's Jewish community played a significant role in the city's development.

Sweden.name: Jewish Museum Stockholm
Sweden.description: Documents the history of Jews in Sweden from 1774, when Aaron Isaac became the first Jew permitted to settle in the country, to the present day. Located in Stockholm, the museum features exhibits on Swedish-Jewish culture, Holocaust survivors who found refuge in Sweden, and the contributions of Jews to Swedish society including science, culture, and business. Houses artifacts, photographs, and oral histories.

individuals.name: Petra Kahn Nord
individuals.bio: Director of the Jewish Museum in Stockholm, documenting Jewish life in Sweden since the 18th century.

connections.name: Sweden Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Sweden.

Sweden.name: Great Synagogue of Stockholm
Sweden.description: The Great Synagogue of Stockholm, consecrated in 1870, is the main synagogue of Stockholm's Jewish community. Designed by architect Fredrik Wilhelm Scholander in an ornate Moorish Revival style with Neo-Romanesque elements. Located on Wahrendorffsgatan, it seats about 800 people. The congregation follows Conservative/Masorti tradition. The Swedish royal family has participated in interfaith events here. A center of Jewish community life for over 150 years.

individuals.name: Ute Steyer
individuals.bio: Rabbi of the Great Synagogue of Stockholm (Jewish), serving Sweden's largest Jewish community.

Sweden.name: Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities
Sweden.description: Official representative body of approximately 15,000-20,000 Jews living in Sweden. Members include communities in Stockholm, Gothenburg, Malm, and other cities. Sweden has a significant Jewish heritage including the legacy of Raoul Wallenberg, who saved tens of thousands of Hungarian Jews during the Holocaust. The council addresses antisemitism, supports religious life, and engages in interfaith dialogue. Sweden was one of the first countries to establish a national Holocaust remembrance program.

individuals.name: Aron Verstndig
individuals.bio: Chairman of the Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities (Jewish), representing approximately 15,000 Swedish Jews.

Sweden.name: Raoul Wallenberg Institute
Sweden.description: Human rights institute at Lund University named after Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg (1912-disappeared 1947), who saved an estimated 30,000-100,000 Hungarian Jews during the Holocaust by issuing protective Swedish passports. Wallenberg was arrested by Soviet forces in 1945 and his fate remains one of the 20th century's great mysteries. The institute focuses on human rights research, education, and training worldwide. Funded partly by the Swedish government.

Sweden.description: Jewish Community of Stockholm, the largest Jewish congregation in Scandinavia with approximately 4,500 members. Operates the Great Synagogue of Stockholm, schools, and community services.

Sweden.description: Jewish Museum in Stockholm documenting the history of Jews in Sweden since the 18th century. Exhibits personal stories, ritual objects, and cultural artifacts.

Denmark.name: Jewish Community of Denmark
Denmark.description: Represents approximately 6,000-8,000 Jews in Denmark. Denmark holds a unique place in Holocaust history: in October 1943, the Danish resistance and ordinary citizens smuggled nearly all 7,500 Danish Jews to safety in neutral Sweden. This remarkable rescue - the only such case in occupied Europe - saved 95% of Danish Jews. Physicist Niels Bohr (Jewish mother, Nobel laureate) was among those rescued. The community maintains the Great Synagogue of Copenhagen (1833).

individuals.bio: Chairman of the Jewish Community of Denmark (Jewish), representing approximately 6,000 Danish Jews.

Denmark.name: Danish Jewish Museum (Copenhagen)
Denmark.description: Designed by world-renowned architect Daniel Libeskind (Jewish, also designed the Jewish Museum Berlin and the 9/11 Memorial master plan), opened in 2004 within the 17th-century Royal Library building. The museum's striking interior uses angled walls and floors symbolizing the Hebrew word "mitzvah." Core exhibitions focus on the remarkable 1943 rescue of Danish Jews. Libeskind called the design "an exploration of the Danish-Jewish experience - a culture of learning, adaptation, and contribution."

individuals.name: Daniel Libeskind

Denmark.name: Rescue of Danish Jews (1943)
Denmark.description: In October 1943, when the Nazis planned to deport Denmark's 7,500 Jews, German diplomat Georg Ferdinand Duckwitz warned Danish political leaders. In a remarkable three-week effort, Danish resistance fighters and ordinary citizens organized fishing boats to smuggle nearly the entire Jewish population across the resund strait to neutral Sweden. Over 7,200 Jews were saved - 95% of Danish Jewry. This stands as the most successful national rescue effort during the Holocaust. Many participants were later honored as Righteous Among the Nations.

individuals.name: Georg Ferdinand Duckwitz
individuals.bio: German diplomat who warned Danish Jews of the planned Nazi roundup in October 1943, enabling the rescue of 7,200 Jews by boat to Sweden.

Denmark.name: Great Synagogue of Copenhagen
Denmark.description: Built in 1833, the Great Synagogue of Copenhagen is the oldest functioning synagogue in Denmark and one of the finest in Scandinavia. Designed by Gustav Friedrich Hetsch in Neoclassical style with Egyptian motifs. King Christian X attended the centennial celebration in 1933. In February 2015, a gunman attacked a synagogue bat mitzvah party, killing security guard Dan Uzan. The building remains a symbol of Danish-Jewish heritage and resilience.

Norway.name: Jewish Community of Oslo
Norway.description: Known formally as Det Mosaiske Trossamfunn (The Mosaic Religious Community), representing approximately 750 Jews in Oslo. Norway's Jewish history includes the dark chapter of WWII deportations: in November 1942, 532 Jews were loaded onto the SS Donau and shipped to Auschwitz. Of 773 Norwegian Jews deported total, only 34 survived. In 2012, Norway formally apologized at a ceremony marking the 70th anniversary. The Oslo synagogue, built in 1920, remains the center of community life.

individuals.name: Ervin Kohn
individuals.bio: President of the Jewish Community of Oslo (Jewish), representing Norway's approximately 1,500 Jews.

Norway.name: Center for Studies of the Holocaust and Religious Minorities (HL-senteret)
Norway.description: Norwegian national center for Holocaust and minority studies, located in Villa Grande - the former wartime residence of Vidkun Quisling, Norway's Nazi collaborator. This powerful symbolic choice transforms a site of betrayal into a center of education and remembrance. Funded by the Norwegian government, the center conducts research on the Holocaust in Norway, antisemitism, and the rights of religious minorities. Partners with Universities and the European Holocaust Research Infrastructure (EHRI).

Norway.name: Jewish Museum Trondheim
Norway.description: Located in the world's northernmost synagogue in Trondheim, Norway. The museum documents the history of Jews in Norway, including the Norwegian Constitution's 1814 ban on Jewish settlement (repealed 1851), the development of small communities in Trondheim and Oslo, and the devastating WWII deportations. Trondheim's entire Jewish community was arrested and deported in 1942 - most perished at Auschwitz.

Finland.name: Central Council of Jewish Communities in Finland
Finland.description: Represents approximately 1,300 Jews in Finland, one of Europe's smallest Jewish communities. Finland's Jewish history is unique: during WWII, Finnish Jews served in the Finnish army alongside Nazi Germany (as co-belligerents against the Soviet Union) while keeping full civil rights - the only such case in Axis-allied Europe. Finland refused Nazi demands to deport its Jews. The community maintains synagogues in Helsinki and Turku.

individuals.bio: Chairman of the Central Council of Jewish Communities in Finland (Jewish), representing approximately 1,300 Finnish Jews.

Finland.description: One of the northernmost established Jewish communities, serving approximately 1,100 Jews in Finland. Unique for being the only Jewish community to fight on the same side as Nazi Germany (as Finnish citizens) while protecting their own Jewish members. Operates the Helsinki Synagogue built in 1906.

Greece.name: Romaniote Jewish Community
Greece.description: The Romaniote Jews are one of the oldest Jewish communities in Europe, present in Greece since at least the 3rd century BCE - predating both Ashkenazi and Sephardic traditions. They spoke Greek (not Yiddish or Ladino) and developed their own distinct liturgy, customs, and music. Ioannina was historically the center of Romaniote life. The community was devastated in the Holocaust. Today, the only Romaniote synagogue in the Western Hemisphere is Kehila Kedosha Janina on the Lower East Side of New York City, founded in 1927.

individuals.name: Marcia Haddad Ikonomopoulos
individuals.bio: Founder of Kehila Kedosha Janina (Jewish), the only Romaniote synagogue in the Western Hemisphere, in New York.

Greece.name: Jewish Museum of Greece
Greece.description: Located in Athens, documenting over 2,300 years of Jewish presence in Greece - from Hellenistic times to the present. Houses important collections from both Romaniote Jews (one of Europe's oldest Jewish communities, speaking Greek since antiquity) and Sephardic Jews who arrived after 1492. The museum preserves artifacts, textiles, documents, and ritual objects. Greece's Jewish community was devastated during the Holocaust, making preservation of these materials critical.

individuals.bio: Director of the Jewish Museum of Greece in Athens, documenting 2,300 years of Greek Jewish (Romaniote) history.

Greece.name: Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki
Greece.description: Documents the extraordinary history of Thessaloniki's Jewish community, which at its peak made up over 50% of the city's population. Known as "La Madre de Israel" (the Mother of Israel) in Ladino, Thessaloniki was the world's largest Sephardic city. In 1943, nearly 50,000 Jews were deported to Auschwitz-Birkenau - 96% of the community perished. The Nazis destroyed the vast Jewish cemetery; Aristotle University was later built on the site. The museum preserves what remains of this lost world.

individuals.name: Erika Perahia-Zemour
individuals.bio: Director of the Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki (Jewish), documenting the city once known as 'Mother of Israel' for its vast Jewish population.

Greece.name: Holocaust Memorial of Thessaloniki
Greece.description: Memorial on Freedom Square (Plateia Eleftherias) in Thessaloniki, the very spot where on July 11, 1942, 9,000 Jewish men were forced to perform exercises and humiliations by Nazi soldiers. The memorial commemorates the nearly 50,000 Thessaloniki Jews who were deported and murdered at Auschwitz in 1943. The city's Jewish community - which had shaped Thessaloniki's character for 450 years - was almost entirely annihilated in just a few months.

individuals.name: Yitzchak Kerem
individuals.bio: Scholar of Greek Jewish history. The memorial honors 50,000 Thessaloniki Jews deported to Auschwitz in 1943 - 96% of the community.

Greece.name: Central Board of Jewish Communities in Greece
Greece.description: Known as KIS (Kentriko Israelitiko Symvoulio), representing approximately 5,000 Jews in Greece. Greece had one of the most devastating Holocaust experiences: approximately 87% of Greek Jews were murdered. Thessaloniki alone lost 50,000 Jews - the city was known as "the Jerusalem of the Balkans." Greece's Jewish heritage includes both Romaniote Jews (present since antiquity) and Sephardic Jews (arrived after 1492 Spanish expulsion). The board oversees community affairs and Holocaust remembrance.

Romania.name: Federation of Jewish Communities in Romania
Romania.description: Represents approximately 3,000 Jews in Romania. Romania once had over 850,000 Jews and was a cradle of Zionism and Yiddish theater. The Holocaust devastated the community - over 280,000 Romanian Jews perished. In 2004, the Elie Wiesel International Commission formally acknowledged Romania's role. Many survivors emigrated to Israel. The Coral Temple (1866) in Bucharest remains active. Notable Romanian-origin Jews include Elie Wiesel, Paul Celan, Tristan Tzara, and filmmaker Radu Mihileanu.

Hong Kong.name: Jewish Historical Society of Hong Kong
Hong Kong.description: Preserves and documents the rich Jewish heritage of Hong Kong, dating to the founding of the colony in the 1840s. Jewish merchants - particularly the Sassoon and Kadoorie families - played instrumental roles in Hong Kong's development as a global trading center. The society documents the community's history including the Baghdadi Jewish traders, European refugees during WWII, and the modern community of approximately 5,000-6,000 people.

Hong Kong.name: Ohel Leah Synagogue
Hong Kong.description: Historic Sephardic synagogue in Hong Kong, built in 1901 by Sir Jacob Sassoon and named after his mother Leah. One of the oldest surviving synagogues in East Asia, declared a Hong Kong monument. Located on Robinson Road in the Mid-Levels. The Kadoorie family (Jewish, Baghdadi origin) has been central to its preservation. Still an active place of worship serving Hong Kong's Jewish community. The building combines Moorish and Classical architectural styles.

Cuba.name: Patronato de la Casa de la Comunidad Hebrea de Cuba
Cuba.description: The main Jewish community center in Havana, serving Cuba's approximately 1,500 Jews - down from 15,000 before the 1959 revolution. Cuba's Jewish history includes the tragic 1939 SS St. Louis affair, when 937 Jewish refugees were turned away and many later perished in the Holocaust. After the revolution, most Jews emigrated. Those remaining maintained practice with support from Canadian Jewish organizations and JDC. The Patronato operates a synagogue, pharmacy, and Sunday school.

individuals.name: Adela Dworin
individuals.bio: Longtime president of Havana's Jewish community (Jewish), keeping the community alive through decades of the Castro era.

Cuba.description: Historic Jewish community that once numbered 15,000 before the Cuban Revolution. Today approximately 1,200 Jews remain, primarily in Havana. Despite decades of Communist rule, the community has maintained three synagogues, kosher butcher services, and Jewish education. Experienced a revival since the 1990s with international Jewish support.

individuals.name: Adela Dworin
individuals.bio: Legendary leader of Cuban Jewry who kept the community alive through decades of isolation and was honored internationally for her dedication.

Kenya.name: Nairobi Hebrew Congregation
Kenya.description: The main Jewish congregation in East Africa, serving Kenya's small Jewish community of approximately 400 people. The Nairobi Synagogue has served the community since 1913. Kenya's Jewish history connects to the British Uganda Scheme (1903), when the British proposed Jewish settlement in nearby Uganda. Jewish families have been part of Kenya's history since the colonial era, contributing to agriculture, commerce, and conservation. The community maintains an active synagogue and cemetery.
