Founded by Semei Kakungulu, the community has grown to over 2,000 members practicing Conservative Judaism, with members receiving formal conversion through the Conservative movement.

United Arab Emirates.name: Abrahamic Family House (Abu Dhabi)
United Arab Emirates.description: Interfaith complex on Saadiyat Island in Abu Dhabi, opened in 2023, containing a mosque, church, and synagogue on one shared campus - a first of its kind. Designed by Sir David Adjaye. The synagogue, named after Moses Ben Maimon (Maimonides), is the first purpose-built synagogue in the Gulf. Inspired by the 2019 Document on Human Fraternity signed by Pope Francis and Grand Imam Ahmed el-Tayeb during a papal visit to Abu Dhabi. Built by the UAE government as a symbol of Abrahamic unity.

Coordinates between Jewish communities in the UAE, Bahrain, and other Gulf states. Promotes interfaith dialogue, cultural exchange, and builds institutional infrastructure for Jewish life in a region where open Jewish communities are a new phenomenon. connections.description: Promotes interfaith dialogue and regional Jewish-Muslim cooperation.

United Arab Emirates.name: Jewish Community of the UAE
United Arab Emirates.description: A rapidly growing Jewish community established in the United Arab Emirates, accelerated by the 2020 Abraham Accords normalizing Israel-UAE relations. Led by Ross Kriel and others, the community now numbers approximately 1,000+ people. Dubai has multiple kosher restaurants, a Jewish community center, and Chabad operations. The UAE has publicly embraced religious tolerance, making it one of the most welcoming Gulf states for Jewish life. Israeli tourists and businesspeople have flooded in since normalization.

individuals.name: Ross Kriel
individuals.bio: South African-born businessman who has led the development of organized Jewish community life in the UAE.

connections.name: United Arab Emirates Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in United Arab Emirates.

connections.name: Abraham Accords
connections.description: The community grew significantly following the 2020 Abraham Accords normalizing Israel-UAE relations.

connections.name: Ross Kriel
connections.description: Ross Kriel (South African-born) has led efforts to build organized Jewish life in the UAE.

connections.name: Chabad UAE
connections.description: Chabad operates in Dubai and Abu Dhabi providing religious services.

connections.name: Kosher dining
connections.description: Dubai now has multiple kosher restaurants and a growing Jewish infrastructure.

United Arab Emirates.name: Kosher restaurants and community in Dubai
United Arab Emirates.description: Dubai's kosher dining scene expanded rapidly following the 2020 Abraham Accords, serving the growing Jewish community and hundreds of thousands of annual Israeli tourists. Multiple kosher restaurants now operate in the city. Elli's Kosher Kitchen was a pioneer in the market. The availability of kosher food, along with a Jewish community center and synagogue, has made Dubai one of the most vibrant new Jewish communities in the Middle East.

individuals.name: Elli Kriel
individuals.bio: South African-born chef (Jewish) who pioneered Dubai's kosher dining scene, creating 'Elli's Kosher Kitchen.'

connections.name: United Arab Emirates Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in United Arab Emirates.

connections.name: Abraham Accords
connections.description: Kosher dining and Jewish community infrastructure in Dubai expanded rapidly after the 2020 Abraham Accords.

connections.name: Israeli tourism
connections.description: Hundreds of thousands of Israeli tourists visit Dubai annually, driving demand for kosher food.

connections.name: Elli's Kosher Kitchen
connections.description: Elli's Kosher Kitchen was one of the first kosher restaurants to open in Dubai.

United Arab Emirates.name: Jewish Council of the Emirates
United Arab Emirates.description: Officially recognized Jewish community in the UAE. Grew significantly after the Abraham Accords (2020). The community has over 1,000 members and operates communal facilities including kosher restaurants.

individuals.name: Ross Kriel
individuals.bio: South African-born businessman and president of the Jewish Council of the Emirates.

United Arab Emirates.name: Abrahamic Family House
United Arab Emirates.description: Interfaith complex on Saadiyat Island, Abu Dhabi, containing a mosque, church, and synagogue (Moses Ben Maimon Synagogue). Designed by David Adjaye. Inspired by the Document on Human Fraternity.

Bahrain.name: Jewish Community of Bahrain
Bahrain.description: Small Jewish community in Bahrain numbering approximately 36 people - one of the few remaining indigenous Jewish communities in the Gulf. Jews have been in Bahrain since at least the 1880s. Houda Nonoo (Jewish) made history as Bahrain's ambassador to the US (2008-2013). Bahrain normalized relations with Israel in 2020 through the Abraham Accords. King Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa has promoted religious tolerance and preservation of the Jewish community.

individuals.name: Houda Nonoo
individuals.bio: First Jewish ambassador from any Arab country, serving as Bahrain's ambassador to the US (2008-2013).

connections.name: Bahrain Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Bahrain.

connections.name: Abraham Accords
connections.description: Bahrain normalized relations with Israel in 2020 as part of the Abraham Accords.

connections.name: Ancient presence
connections.description: Jews have lived in Bahrain since at least the 1880s, initially Baghdadi merchants.

connections.name: Ambassador Houda Nonoo

connections.name: King Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa
connections.description: King Hamad has promoted religious tolerance and Jewish community rights.

Bahrain.name: Ambassador Houda Nonoo legacy
Bahrain.description: Houda Nonoo (Jewish) made history as the first Jewish ambassador from any Arab country, serving as Bahrain's ambassador to the United States from 2008 to 2013. Appointed by King Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa, she had previously served in Bahrain's Shura Council. Her appointment was a groundbreaking demonstration of Arab-Jewish coexistence and foreshadowed the broader Abraham Accords normalization. She has advocated for tolerance and interfaith dialogue internationally.

individuals.name: Houda Nonoo
individuals.bio: Jewish Bahraini woman who served as Bahrain's ambassador to the US.

connections.name: Bahraini parliament
connections.description: Previously served in Bahrain's Shura Council (upper house of parliament).

Bahrain.name: The Synagogue of Bahrain
Bahrain.description: Synagogue serving the small Jewish community of Bahrain, one of the few remaining in the Gulf region. Bahrain's Jewish community has produced notable figures including a former ambassador.

individuals.name: Houda Nonoo
individuals.bio: First Jewish ambassador from any Arab country, served as Bahrain's ambassador to the United States (2008-2013).

Bahrain.name: House of Ten Commandments
Bahrain.description: Synagogue in Manama, Bahrain. One of the few remaining synagogues in the Arabian Gulf. Bahrain's Jewish community is tiny but has been present since the early 20th century. The Abraham Accords have brought renewed interest.

Portugal.name: Jewish Community of Lisbon
Portugal.description: The Jewish Community of Lisbon represents Portugal's small Jewish population. Portuguese Jewish history is marked by the 1497 forced conversion decree and the brutal Portuguese Inquisition that lasted until 1821. Many Jews became crypto-Jews (Marranos/B'nei Anusim), secretly maintaining Jewish practices for centuries. In 2015, Portugal passed a law offering citizenship to descendants of Sephardi Jews expelled during the Inquisition.

individuals.name: Jos Oulman Carp
individuals.bio: President of the Jewish Community of Lisbon (Jewish), representing Portugal's approximately 3,000 Jews.

connections.name: Portugal Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Portugal.

connections.name: Portuguese Inquisition legacy
connections.description: Portuguese Jewish history is dominated by the forced conversion and Inquisition beginning in 1497.

connections.name: Crypto-Jews (Marranos)
connections.description: Many Portuguese Jews became crypto-Jews (Marranos) who secretly maintained Jewish practices.

connections.name: Portuguese citizenship law
connections.description: Portugal passed a law in 2015 offering citizenship to Sephardi Jewish descendants.

Portugal.name: Museu Judaico de Belmonte
Portugal.description: The Museu Judaico de Belmonte tells the extraordinary story of the Belmonte crypto-Jews, who secretly maintained Jewish practices for over 500 years after the Portuguese Inquisition. Polish-Jewish mining engineer Samuel Schwarz rediscovered the community in 1917, finding women who still lit Shabbat candles in hiding. The community officially returned to Judaism in the 1990s. One of the most remarkable stories of Jewish survival in history.

individuals.name: Samuel Schwarz
individuals.bio: Jewish-Polish mining engineer who in 1917 discovered the crypto-Jewish community of Belmonte, which had secretly practiced Judaism for 500 years.

connections.name: Portugal Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Portugal.

connections.name: Crypto-Jewish community
connections.description: Documents the extraordinary story of the Belmonte crypto-Jews who secretly maintained Judaism for 500 years.

connections.name: Samuel Schwarz

connections.name: Return to Judaism
connections.description: The Belmonte community officially returned to Judaism in the 1990s.

Portugal.name: Sinagoga Kadoorie Mekor Haim (Porto)
Portugal.description: The Sinagoga Kadoorie Mekor Haim in Porto is the largest synagogue on the Iberian Peninsula, completed in 1938 with support from the Kadoorie family (Sephardi Jews of Baghdadi origin, based in Hong Kong). It symbolizes the revival of Jewish life in Portugal after centuries of Inquisition and suppression. Porto has experienced a remarkable Jewish revival, particularly after the 2015 citizenship law for Sephardi descendants.

individuals.name: Captain Barros Basto
individuals.bio: Portuguese army officer (Jewish) who led the 'Rescue' movement to reconnect crypto-Jews (Bnei Anusim) with Judaism in the 1920s-30s.

connections.name: Portugal Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Portugal.

connections.name: Kadoorie family
connections.description: Built with support from the Kadoorie family (Sephardi Jews from Baghdad, based in Hong Kong).

connections.name: Largest synagogue in Iberia

Portugal.name: Comunidade Israelita de Lisboa
Portugal.description: Jewish Community of Lisbon. Operates the Shaare Tikva Synagogue, the largest synagogue on the Iberian Peninsula. Portugal passed a 2015 law granting citizenship to descendants of Sephardic Jews expelled in 1497.

Portugal.name: Sinagoga de Tomar
Portugal.description: Medieval synagogue in Tomar, one of the best-preserved medieval synagogues in Portugal. Now houses the Abrao Zacuto Luso-Hebrew Museum.

Ireland.name: Irish Jewish Museum (Dublin)
Ireland.description: Located in the former Walworth Road Synagogue in Dublin's Portobello neighborhood. Documents the history of Jews in Ireland from the medieval period to present. Notable exhibits include material on Chaim Herzog, the 6th President of Israel (1983-1993), who was born in Belfast and raised in Dublin - his father was Chief Rabbi of Ireland. The museum preserves the synagogue interior and kitchen, giving visitors an intimate view of Dublin Jewish domestic and religious life.

individuals.name: Chaim Herzog
individuals.bio: 6th President of Israel (1983-1993, Jewish), born in Belfast and raised in Dublin; his father was Chief Rabbi of Ireland.

connections.name: Ireland Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Ireland.

connections.name: Walworth Road Synagogue
connections.description: Located in the former Walworth Road Synagogue in Dublin's Portobello neighborhood.

connections.name: Chaim Herzog
connections.description: Chaim Herzog, the 6th President of Israel (1983-1993), was born in Belfast and raised in Dublin.

connections.name: Irish Jewish heritage
connections.description: Documents the history of Jews in Ireland from the medieval period to present.

Ireland.name: Jewish Representative Council of Ireland
Ireland.description: Representative body of Ireland's small Jewish community of approximately 2,500 people, centered in Dublin. Dublin's "Little Jerusalem" along the South Circular Road was historically the center of Jewish life. Robert Briscoe (Jewish) served as Lord Mayor of Dublin in 1956-57. Leopold Bloom in James Joyce's Ulysses is Ireland's most famous literary Jew. Ireland's critical stance on Israeli policies toward Palestinians creates unique dynamics for the community.

individuals.name: Maurice Cohen
individuals.bio: Former president of the Jewish Representative Council of Ireland, representing approximately 2,500 Irish Jews.

connections.name: Ireland Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Ireland.

connections.name: James Joyce's Ulysses
connections.description: Leopold Bloom, the protagonist of James Joyce's Ulysses, is Dublin's most famous fictional Jew.

connections.name: Dublin Jewish community
connections.description: Centers on Dublin's 'Little Jerusalem' neighborhood along the South Circular Road.

connections.name: Robert Briscoe
connections.description: Robert Briscoe (Jewish) served as Lord Mayor of Dublin in 1956-57 and was a Fianna Fil TD.

connections.name: Irish-Israeli relations
connections.description: Ireland has been critical of Israeli policies toward Palestinians, creating complex dynamics.

Ireland.name: Jewish Representative Council of Ireland
Ireland.description: Representative body for Ireland's approximately 2,500 Jews. The Irish-Jewish community has punched above its weight, producing a Chief Rabbi who served for 40 years, and being immortalized in James Joyce's Ulysses through the character of Leopold Bloom. Manages the Dublin Jewish Museum.

individuals.name: Maurice Cohen
individuals.bio: Active leader in the Irish Jewish community working to preserve heritage and strengthen community bonds.

connections.name: Board of Deputies of British Jews
connections.description: Coordinates with UK Jewish organizations on shared issues.

Croatia.name: Jewish Community of Zagreb
Croatia.description: Represents approximately 1,500 Jews in Croatia, centered in Zagreb. Croatia's Jewish history includes the devastating Ustasha period during WWII, when the Zagreb synagogue (an ornate Moorish Revival structure) was demolished and tens of thousands were murdered at the Jasenovac concentration camp. The community has revived since independence in 1991, operating a community center, cultural programs, and maintaining Holocaust remembrance. Zagreb's "Bet Israel" community center serves as the hub.

individuals.name: Ognjen Kraus
individuals.bio: President of the Jewish community of Zagreb and the Coordination of Jewish Communities in Croatia (Jewish).

connections.name: Croatia Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Croatia.

connections.name: Croatian government
connections.description: Official representative body of Croatia's approximately 1,500 Jews.

connections.name: Jasenovac memorial
connections.description: Connected to the memory of Jasenovac, where tens of thousands of Serbs, Jews, and Roma were murdered during WWII.

connections.name: Zagreb synagogue
connections.description: The magnificent Zagreb synagogue was demolished by the Ustasha regime in 1941-42.

Croatia.name: Jewish Community of Zagreb
Croatia.description: Historic Jewish community in the Croatian capital with roots dating to the early 19th century. Before WWII, approximately 25,000 Jews lived in Zagreb. Today about 1,700 members maintain the community, operating a synagogue, cultural center, and the Miroslav alom Freiberger Jewish Film Festival.

individuals.name: Ognjen Kraus
individuals.bio: Long-serving president of the Croatian Jewish community and head of Coordination of Jewish Communities in Croatia.

connections.name: European Jewish Congress
connections.description: Member of the European Jewish Congress.

Serbia.name: Federation of Jewish Communities in Serbia
Serbia.description: Represents approximately 1,500-2,000 Jews in Serbia, centered in Belgrade. Belgrade had a centuries-old Sephardic community alongside Ashkenazi Jews. The Holocaust devastated Serbian Jewry - approximately 90% perished. The Art Nouveau Subotica Synagogue (1902), restored with significant Hungarian and EU funding, is one of the most architecturally stunning synagogues in Europe. The community maintains cultural programs and Holocaust remembrance.

individuals.name: Robert Sabado
individuals.bio: President of the Federation of Jewish Communities in Serbia (Jewish).

connections.name: Serbia Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Serbia.

connections.name: Serbian government
connections.description: Recognized representative body of Serbia's approximately 1,500-2,000 Jews.

connections.name: Belgrade Sephardic heritage
connections.description: Belgrade had a centuries-old Sephardic community, largely destroyed in the Holocaust.

connections.name: Subotica synagogue
connections.description: The Art Nouveau Subotica Synagogue (1902) is one of the most beautiful synagogues in Europe.

Serbia.name: Federation of Jewish Communities of Serbia
Serbia.description: Central body for Serbia's approximately 3,000 Jews. Belgrade once had a thriving Jewish population before the Holocaust. The federation operates the Subotica Synagogue (one of Europe's largest), cultural centers, and preserves the memory of Serbian Jewry including the site of the Sajmite concentration camp.

individuals.name: Robert Singer
individuals.bio: Serbian-born Jewish leader who served as CEO of the World Jewish Congress, embodying the Serbian Jewish diaspora.

connections.name: World Jewish Congress
connections.description: Serbian federated member of the World Jewish Congress.

Serbia.name: Jewish Community of Belgrade
Serbia.description: One of the oldest Jewish communities in the Balkans. Sephardic Jews arrived after the 1492 Spanish expulsion. Before WWII, approximately 12,000 Jews lived in Serbia. Approximately 1,200 remain today.

Bulgaria.name: Organization of the Jews in Bulgaria
Bulgaria.description: Known as Shalom, representing approximately 2,000 Jews in Bulgaria. Bulgaria holds a unique place in Holocaust history: in 1943, Bulgarian parliamentarians, church leaders, and civic pressure prevented the deportation of nearly all 48,000 Bulgarian Jews to Nazi death camps - one of the Holocaust's most remarkable rescue stories. However, Bulgaria did allow the deportation of 11,343 Jews from occupied Thrace and Macedonia. The Sofia Synagogue (1909) is the largest Sephardic synagogue in Europe.

individuals.name: Oscar Asenov
individuals.bio: President of the Organization of the Jews in Bulgaria 'Shalom' (Jewish).

connections.name: Bulgaria Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Bulgaria.

connections.name: Bulgarian rescue of Jews
connections.description: Bulgaria famously saved nearly all of its 48,000 Jews from deportation during WWII.

connections.name: Bulgarian parliament
connections.description: In 1943, Bulgarian MPs and church leaders prevented the deportation of Bulgarian Jews to death camps.

connections.name: Sofia Synagogue
connections.description: The Sofia Synagogue (1909) is the largest Sephardic synagogue in Europe.

Bulgaria.name: Shalom Organization of Jews in Bulgaria
Bulgaria.description: Central organization of Bulgarian Jewry representing approximately 2,000 Jews. Bulgaria is celebrated for saving its 48,000 Jews from deportation during the Holocaust through unprecedented public and political resistance. The organization preserves this legacy and maintains Jewish cultural life.

individuals.name: Maxim Behar
individuals.bio: Bulgarian-Jewish PR mogul and community supporter who promotes Bulgaria's Holocaust rescue history internationally.

connections.name: World Jewish Congress
connections.description: Bulgarian affiliate of the World Jewish Congress.

Bulgaria.name: Jewish Community of Bulgaria
Bulgaria.description: Bulgaria is notable for saving nearly all of its 48,000 Jews during WWII through mass public protest and the intervention of Boris III. Approximately 2,000 Jews remain; most emigrated to Israel.

Tunisia.name: El Ghriba Synagogue (Djerba)
Tunisia.description: One of the oldest synagogues in the world, located on the island of Djerba, Tunisia. Tradition holds it was founded in 586 BCE by Jews fleeing the destruction of Solomon's Temple, who brought a door and stone from the Temple. The annual Lag BaOmer pilgrimage draws thousands of Jewish visitors from around the world. In 2002, an al-Qaeda truck bomb attack killed 21 people. The Tunisian government provides security and preservation support. Djerba's small Jewish community of approximately 1,000 is one of the oldest continuous Jewish communities in the world.

individuals.name: Perez Trabelsi
individuals.bio: Leader of the Jewish community of Djerba (Jewish), overseeing the annual El Ghriba pilgrimage.

connections.name: Tunisia Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Tunisia.

connections.name: One of the oldest synagogues in the world
connections.description: Tradition dates the synagogue to 586 BCE, when Jews fleeing the destruction of Solomon's Temple arrived in Djerba.

connections.name: Annual Lag BaOmer pilgrimage
connections.description: Thousands of Jewish pilgrims visit for the annual Lag BaOmer festival.

connections.name: 2002 terrorist attack
connections.description: An al-Qaeda truck bomb attack in April 2002 killed 21 people, including 14 German tourists.

connections.name: Tunisian government protection
connections.description: The Tunisian government provides security and has supported the synagogue's preservation.

Tunisia.name: El Ghriba Synagogue
Tunisia.description: Oldest synagogue in Africa and one of the oldest in the world, located on the island of Djerba. Annual pilgrimage site for Jews from across North Africa and Europe. Claims to contain stones from Solomon's Temple.

Azerbaijan.name: Mountain Jewish Community of Azerbaijan
Azerbaijan.description: The Mountain Jews (Juhuro) of Azerbaijan have lived in the Caucasus for over 2,500 years, making them one of the most ancient Jewish communities in the world. They speak Juhuri (Judeo-Tat), a unique Persian-based language. The Red Settlement (Qrmz Qsb) in Quba is the only all-Jewish town outside Israel and the US. Azerbaijan actively promotes its Jewish community as a model of tolerance, and President Aliyev has maintained warm Israel-Azerbaijan relations.

individuals.name: Milikh Yevdayev
individuals.bio: Leader of the Mountain Jewish community in Azerbaijan, based at the Red Settlement (Qrmz Qsb).

connections.name: Azerbaijan Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Azerbaijan.

connections.description: The Mountain Jews (Juhuro) have lived in the Caucasus for over 2,500 years.

connections.name: Red Settlement (Qrmz Qsb)
connections.description: The Red Settlement in Quba is the only majority-Jewish town outside Israel and the US.

connections.name: Azerbaijani government
connections.description: Azerbaijan promotes its Jewish community as a model of tolerance.

Azerbaijan.name: Mountain Jews of Azerbaijan
Azerbaijan.description: Community of Mountain Jews (Juhuro) centered in Quba's 'Red Village' (Krasnaya Sloboda), the only all-Jewish town outside Israel and the US. Speak Judeo-Tat language. Approximately 9,000 remain in Azerbaijan.

Georgia.name: Georgian Jewish Community
Georgia.description: One of the world's oldest Jewish communities, claiming 2,600 years of history in the Caucasus. Georgian Jews preserved unique traditions and maintained generally positive relations with their neighbors - Georgia is proud of never having had a pogrom. Most Georgian Jews emigrated to Israel in the 1970s-1990s; approximately 100,000 Israelis today are of Georgian origin. Approximately 3,000 Jews remain in Georgia, centered around the Tbilisi Great Synagogue.

individuals.name: Ariel Levin
individuals.bio: Chief Rabbi of Georgia (Jewish), serving the remaining Georgian Jewish community.

connections.name: Georgia Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Georgia.

connections.name: Ancient presence
connections.description: Georgian Jews claim a 2,600-year history, dating to the Babylonian exile.

connections.name: Georgian government
connections.description: Georgia promotes its tradition of religious tolerance and protection of Jewish heritage.

connections.name: Tbilisi Great Synagogue
connections.description: The Tbilisi Great Synagogue remains the center of Jewish life in Georgia.

connections.name: Mass aliyah
connections.description: Most Georgian Jews emigrated to Israel in the 1970s-90s; approximately 100,000 Israeli citizens are of Georgian origin.

Uzbekistan.name: Bukharan Jewish Community
Uzbekistan.description: Ancient Jewish community of Central Asia, present along the Silk Road for over 2,000 years. Bukharan Jews speak Bukhori (Judeo-Tajik), a Persian-based language. Historically centered in Bukhara and Samarkand, the community numbered 50,000+ before most emigrated in the 1990s. Today the largest Bukharan communities are in Queens, NY (approximately 60,000), Israel (approximately 150,000), and Vienna. Uzbekistan promotes its remaining Jewish heritage sites as part of Silk Road tourism.

individuals.name: Roshel Rubinov
individuals.bio: Last chief rabbi of the Bukharan Jewish community in Uzbekistan before mass emigration.

connections.name: Uzbekistan Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Uzbekistan.

connections.description: Bukharan Jews have lived in Central Asia for over 2,000 years along the ancient Silk Road.

connections.name: Bukhori language
connections.description: Speak Bukhori (Judeo-Tajik), a distinctive Judeo-Persian language.

connections.name: Queens, New York community
connections.description: The largest Bukharan Jewish diaspora is in Forest Hills and Rego Park, Queens, New York (approximately 60,000).

connections.name: Uzbekistan government
connections.description: Uzbekistan promotes its Jewish heritage as part of Silk Road cultural tourism.

Peru.name: Asociacin Juda del Per
Peru.description: Representative body of Peru's Jewish community of approximately 2,500, mostly in Lima. Peru has a complex Jewish history - the Lima Inquisition (1570-1820) specifically targeted crypto-Jews (conversos). The modern community grew with 20th-century immigration from Eastern Europe and the Middle East. The community maintains the Colegio Len Pinelo school and synagogue. Some Peruvians with converso ancestry have recently reconnected with Judaism.

individuals.name: Jaime Braun
individuals.bio: Former president of Asociacin Juda del Per (Jewish), leading Lima's approximately 2,500 Jews.

connections.description: Peru's Inquisition targeted crypto-Jews (conversos) during the colonial period.

connections.name: Len Pinelo Synagogue
connections.description: The community maintains the Len Pinelo Synagogue and school in Lima.

Peru.name: Asociacin Juda del Per
Peru.description: Central body for Peru's Jewish community of approximately 2,500, primarily based in Lima. Manages the Colegio Len Pinelo Jewish school, community centers, and synagogues. The community includes descendants of Sephardic crypto-Jews, Eastern European immigrants, and more recent arrivals.

individuals.name: Eduardo Bigio
individuals.bio: Longstanding leader in the Peruvian Jewish community involved in education and interfaith initiatives.

connections.name: Joint Distribution Committee
connections.description: Receives programmatic support from JDC for community development.

Peru.name: Colegio Len Pinelo
Peru.description: Jewish day school in Lima, Peru. Named after Antonio de Len Pinelo, a 17th-century scholar of Jewish descent. Considered one of the best private schools in Peru.

connections.name: Brandeis University
connections.description: Both are notable Jewish-affiliated educational institutions

Venezuela.name: Confederacin de Asociaciones Israelitas de Venezuela (CAIV)
Venezuela.description: Umbrella body for Venezuelan Jewish communities. Venezuela's Jewish population has declined dramatically from approximately 22,000 to under 6,000 due to political instability and antisemitic rhetoric under Hugo Chvez and Nicols Maduro. In 2009, a mob attacked the main synagogue in Caracas. Many Venezuelan Jews have emigrated to the US, Israel, and Panama. The Hebraica community center in Caracas remains a hub for those who stayed.

individuals.name: David Bittan
individuals.bio: Former president of CAIV (Jewish), leading the Venezuelan Jewish community during challenging political times.

connections.name: Venezuela Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Venezuela.

connections.name: Venezuelan Jewish community
connections.description: Represents Venezuela's declining Jewish community, once approximately 22,000.

connections.name: Hugo Chvez era
connections.description: Under Chvez and Maduro, anti-Israel rhetoric and attacks on Jewish institutions drove emigration.

connections.name: Hebraica community
connections.description: The Hebraica (Centro Social Cultural y Deportivo Hebraica) has been the community hub.

Venezuela.name: CAIV - Confederacin de Asociaciones Israelitas de Venezuela
Venezuela.description: Umbrella body for Venezuela's Jewish community, which has declined from 22,000 to under 6,000 due to political and economic instability. CAIV advocates for community rights and coordinates emigration assistance. Manages synagogues, schools, and social services in Caracas.

individuals.name: David Bittan
individuals.bio: Leader navigating the challenges facing Venezuelan Jewry including community preservation amid mass emigration.

connections.name: American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee
connections.description: JDC provides welfare assistance to remaining community members.

Costa Rica.name: Centro Israelita Sionista de Costa Rica
Costa Rica.description: Representative body of Costa Rica's Jewish community of approximately 2,500, centered in San Jos. The community includes descendants of Eastern European and Sephardic immigrants. Costa Rica has maintained warm relations with Israel. The community operates synagogues, a school (Instituto Dr. Jaim Weizmann), and social institutions.

individuals.name: Jaime Gutman
individuals.bio: Leader of the Centro Israelita Sionista de Costa Rica (Jewish), representing 2,500 Costa Rican Jews.

Costa Rica.name: Centro Israelita Sionista de Costa Rica
Costa Rica.description: Central Jewish community organization in Costa Rica serving approximately 3,000 community members. Operates the Chaim Weizmann Jewish Day School, synagogues, and community center. Costa Rica has been notably supportive of Israel, being among the first countries to recognize the Jewish state in 1948.

individuals.name: Jaime Daremblum
individuals.bio: Costa Rican-Jewish diplomat who served as ambassador to the United States, prominent figure in Costa Rican Jewish community.

connections.name: World Zionist Organization
connections.description: Affiliated with WZO representing Central American Zionist activities.

Guatemala.name: Comunidad Juda de Guatemala
Guatemala.description: Small but active Jewish community of approximately 900 people in Guatemala, centered in Guatemala City. Guatemala has a unique relationship with Israel - it was one of the first countries to vote for Israeli statehood in 1947, and in 2018 moved its embassy to Jerusalem. The community maintains several synagogues, including Magun David, and a Jewish school.

individuals.name: Yaffa Grazioso
individuals.bio: Community leader of the Comunidad Juda de Guatemala (Jewish).

connections.name: Guatemala Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Guatemala.

connections.name: Guatemala-Israel relations
connections.description: Guatemala was one of the first countries to recognize Israel and moved its embassy to Jerusalem in 2018.

connections.name: Guatemala City community
connections.description: Most of Guatemala's approximately 900 Jews live in Guatemala City.

Guatemala.name: Comunidad Juda de Guatemala
Guatemala.description: Jewish community organization serving approximately 1,200 Jews in Guatemala City. Maintains the Magun David synagogue, a Jewish school, and community center. Guatemala played a historic role in the creation of Israel, with Ambassador Jorge Garca Granados championing the UN partition plan in 1947.

individuals.name: Jorge Garca Granados
individuals.bio: Guatemalan diplomat who served as ambassador to the UN and was instrumental in the 1947 partition vote supporting Israel's creation.

connections.name: State of Israel
connections.description: Guatemala was the second country to recognize Israel in 1948.

Ecuador.name: Comunidad Juda del Ecuador
Ecuador.description: Represents approximately 800 Jews in Ecuador, split between Quito and Guayaquil. Many are descendants of German and Austrian Jewish refugees who arrived during WWII. The community maintains the Asociacin Israelita de Quito and Centro Israelita de Guayaquil with synagogues and cultural programs.

individuals.name: Samuel Benchoam
individuals.bio: Community leader of the Comunidad Juda del Ecuador (Jewish), based in Quito.

connections.name: Ecuador Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Ecuador.

connections.name: Quito community
connections.description: Most of Ecuador's approximately 800 Jews live in Quito and Guayaquil.

connections.name: WWII refugees
connections.description: Many Ecuadorian Jews are descendants of WWII refugees from Germany and Austria.

Ecuador.name: Comunidad Juda del Ecuador
Ecuador.description: Jewish community organization serving approximately 500 Jewish residents in Ecuador, primarily in Quito and Guayaquil. Founded by German Jewish refugees fleeing Nazism. Maintains synagogues, cultural programs, and connections with international Jewish organizations.

individuals.name: Heinz Moeller
individuals.bio: One of the founders of organized Jewish life in Ecuador, establishing key community institutions.

connections.name: World Jewish Congress
connections.description: Affiliated community member of WJC Latin American section.

Ecuador.name: Asociacin de Beneficencia Israelita de Quito
Ecuador.description: Jewish association of Quito, Ecuador, serving a community of approximately 800 Jews. Many families descend from European refugees who arrived in the 1930s.

Bolivia.name: Comunidad Israelita de Bolivia (Circulo Israelita)
Bolivia.description: One of South America's smallest Jewish communities with approximately 500 members, centered in La Paz with a smaller group in Santa Cruz. The community traces to immigration from Eastern Europe and Germany in the 1930s-40s. Relations with the government became strained under President Evo Morales, who severed diplomatic ties with Israel in 2009. The Crculo Israelita operates a synagogue, community center, and school in La Paz.

individuals.name: Ricardo Udler
individuals.bio: President of the Crculo Israelita de Bolivia (Jewish), leading La Paz's small Jewish community.

connections.name: Bolivia Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Bolivia.

connections.name: La Paz community
connections.description: Bolivia's tiny Jewish community is centered in La Paz.

connections.name: Morales government tensions
connections.description: Under President Evo Morales, Bolivia severed diplomatic ties with Israel in 2009.

Dominican Republic.name: Jewish Community of Sosa
Dominican Republic.description: Unique community founded when the Dominican Republic was the only country at the 1938 vian Conference to offer refuge to Jewish refugees from Nazi Europe. Dictator Rafael Trujillo accepted approximately 800 Jewish settlers to Sosa on the north coast, partly to whiten the population. The Dominican Republic Settlement Association (DORSA) and JDC funded the settlement. Refugees established a dairy cooperative. Most eventually moved to the US, but a small community and museum remain.

individuals.name: Luis Hess
individuals.bio: One of the original Jewish refugees who settled in Sosa in the 1940s and built the dairy cooperative.

connections.name: Dominican Republic Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Dominican Republic.

connections.name: Sosa refugee settlement
connections.description: In 1940, the Dominican Republic accepted 800 Jewish refugees from Nazi Europe - the only country to do so at the vian Conference.

connections.name: General Rafael Trujillo
connections.description: Dominican dictator Trujillo offered resettlement to whiten the population and improve international image.

connections.name: DORSA
connections.description: The Dominican Republic Settlement Association (DORSA) managed the Sosa Jewish settlement.

connections.name: JDC
connections.description: The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee helped organize and fund the Sosa settlement.

Dominican Republic.name: Museo Judo de Sosa
Dominican Republic.description: Museum in Sosa, Dominican Republic, documenting the remarkable story of Jewish refugees who found haven there during the Holocaust - the only concrete result of the 1938 vian Conference. Displays photographs, documents, and artifacts from the settlement era. Tells stories of refugees who established a dairy cooperative and new lives. A unique piece of Holocaust and Latin American history. The museum serves as both a memorial and a center for tolerance education in the Caribbean.

individuals.name: Luis Hess
individuals.bio: Descendant of original Sosa settlers involved in preserving the museum's story.

connections.name: Dominican Republic Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Dominican Republic.

connections.name: Sosa Jewish settlement
connections.description: Documents the history of the Jewish refugee settlement in Sosa.

connections.name: Holocaust education
connections.description: Serves as a center for Holocaust education in the Caribbean.

connections.name: vian Conference
connections.description: Tells the story of the 1938 vian Conference where the Dominican Republic alone offered refuge.

Jamaica.name: United Congregation of Israelites
Jamaica.description: Jamaica's sole remaining Jewish congregation, operating the historic Shaare Shalom Synagogue (1912) in Kingston - one of only two sand-floor synagogues in the world. Jamaica's Jewish history dates to the 1530s when Sephardic crypto-Jews arrived fleeing the Inquisition. The community played significant roles in island commerce, including the sugar industry. Today approximately 200 Jews remain. The sand floor tradition is said to commemorate the Jewish desert wanderings or to muffle the sound of prayer from Inquisition ears.

individuals.name: Ainsley Henriques
individuals.bio: Historian and leader of Jamaica's Jewish community (Jewish), expert on Caribbean Sephardic history.

connections.name: Jamaica Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Jamaica.

connections.name: Shaare Shalom Synagogue
connections.description: The Shaare Shalom Synagogue (1912) in Kingston is Jamaica's only remaining synagogue.

connections.name: Caribbean Jewish history
connections.description: Jamaica's Jewish community dates to the 1530s, making it one of the oldest in the Western Hemisphere.

connections.name: Sephardic origins
connections.description: Founded by Sephardic Jews fleeing the Spanish and Portuguese Inquisitions.

Jamaica.name: Shaare Shalom Synagogue
Jamaica.description: Synagogue in Kingston, Jamaica with a sand-covered floor. Jamaica's Jewish history dates to 1530 when Converso families arrived. United Congregation of Israelites is one of the oldest in the Western Hemisphere.

Thailand.name: Jewish Association of Thailand
Thailand.description: Oversees Jewish community life in Thailand, centered in Bangkok but extending to Chiang Mai, Phuket, and Ko Samui. Chabad operates 11 centers across Thailand - one of its largest Southeast Asian networks - serving residents, expats, and the massive influx of Israeli backpackers who visit post-military service. The Beth Elisheva Synagogue in Bangkok serves the residential community. Thai-Israeli relations have been warm, with significant bilateral trade.

individuals.name: Yosef Kantor
individuals.bio: Chabad rabbi serving Thailand (Jewish), operating one of the world's largest Chabad networks outside Israel.

connections.name: Thailand Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Thailand.

connections.name: Bangkok Jewish community
connections.description: Centers on Bangkok, serving approximately 1,000 Jews including expats and Israeli tourists.

connections.name: Chabad Thailand
connections.description: Chabad operates 11 centers across Thailand, among its largest networks in Southeast Asia.

connections.name: Israeli backpacker culture
connections.description: Thailand is a top post-military service destination for Israeli travelers.

Thailand.name: Jewish Community of Thailand
Thailand.description: Organized Jewish community serving approximately 1,000 permanent Jewish residents and thousands of Israeli tourists annually. Operates the Beth Elisheva Synagogue in Bangkok and supports Chabad houses across Thailand including popular centers in Bangkok, Chiang Mai, and Ko Samui.

individuals.name: Rabbi Yosef Kantor
individuals.bio: Chabad emissary who has served as the chief rabbi of Thailand since 1994, establishing Jewish infrastructure across the country.

connections.name: Chabad-Lubavitch
connections.description: Primary Jewish infrastructure provided through Chabad network.

Thailand.name: Jewish Community of Thailand
Thailand.description: Jewish community centered in Bangkok with approximately 1,000 permanent Jewish residents plus thousands of Israeli tourists and expats. Operates a community center and Chabad houses.

Philippines.name: Jewish Association of the Philippines
Philippines.description: Small Jewish community of approximately 100-200 people in the Philippines, centered in Manila. The Philippines has a remarkable Holocaust rescue story: President Manuel Quezon's "Open Door" policy sheltered approximately 1,300 Jewish refugees in Mindanao during WWII. The Beth Yaacov Synagogue in Makati, Manila, serves the community. Filipino soldiers were also among the liberators of concentration camps. The country has maintained strong ties with Israel.

individuals.name: Ilan Fluss
individuals.bio: Community leader of the Jewish Association of the Philippines, serving Manila's small Jewish community.

connections.name: Philippines Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Philippines.

connections.name: Manila Jewish community
connections.description: Small community centered in Manila with approximately 100-200 members.

connections.name: WWII rescue
connections.description: President Manuel Quezon sheltered 1,300 Jewish refugees in Mindanao during WWII through the 'Open Door' policy.

connections.name: Temple Emil congregation
connections.description: The Beth Yaacov Synagogue in Makati serves the community.

Philippines.name: Jewish Association of the Philippines
Philippines.description: Historic Jewish community that played a vital role during WWII when Philippine President Manuel Quezon opened the country to Jewish refugees, saving over 1,300 lives. Today the community of about 200 maintains the Jewish cemetery in Manila and cultural programs.

individuals.name: Frank Ephraim
individuals.bio: Author and historian who documented the rescue of Jewish refugees in the Philippines during World War II.

connections.name: Bnai Brith
connections.description: Historical connection through Manila B'nai B'rith lodge established in the 1920s.

Philippines.name: Temple Emil, Manila
Philippines.description: Synagogue serving the Jewish community in Metro Manila. The Philippine Jewish community includes about 200 people. The Philippines was one of the few countries to accept Jewish refugees during WWII.

South Korea.name: Jewish Community of South Korea
South Korea.description: Small community of approximately 1,000 Jews in South Korea, originating from American Jewish servicemembers stationed in Korea. Today includes diplomats, businesspeople, English teachers, and tech workers. Chabad operates in Seoul. Korean-Israeli tech and business ties have grown significantly, with Korean electronics giants partnering with Israeli startups. South Korea and Israel maintain warm diplomatic relations.

individuals.name: Osher Litzman
individuals.bio: Chabad rabbi serving South Korea (Jewish), based in Seoul.

connections.name: South Korea Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in South Korea.

connections.name: US military presence
connections.description: The community grew from American Jewish servicemembers stationed in South Korea.

connections.name: Chabad Seoul
connections.description: Chabad of Korea operates in Seoul, serving residents and visitors.

connections.name: Korean-Israeli tech ties
connections.description: Growing Korean-Israeli business and tech relationships have expanded the community.

South Korea.name: Jewish Community of South Korea
South Korea.description: Small Jewish community in South Korea rooted in the post-Korean War US military presence. The community operates a Chabad house in Seoul and hosts regular services. South Korea notably saved thousands of Jewish refugees during the Japanese occupation through diplomatic means.

individuals.name: Rabbi Osher Litzman
individuals.bio: Chabad rabbi serving the Jewish community in Seoul since 2008, providing kosher food, Shabbat services, and Jewish education.

connections.name: Chabad-Lubavitch
connections.description: Supported through Chabad's global network.

South Korea.name: Samsung Group
South Korea.description: South Korean multinational conglomerate. World's largest producer of smartphones and memory chips. Samsung Electronics alone generates over $230 billion in annual revenue. Accounts for roughly 20% of South Korea's GDP.

individuals.name: Lee Jae-yong
individuals.bio: Chairman of Samsung Electronics, grandson of Samsung founder Lee Byung-chul.

South Korea.name: Hyundai Motor Group
South Korea.description: South Korean multinational automotive group. Third-largest vehicle manufacturer in the world. Includes Hyundai, Kia, and Genesis brands. Revenue exceeds $100 billion.

individuals.name: Chung Eui-sun
individuals.bio: Chairman of Hyundai Motor Group, overseeing the company's push into electric and autonomous vehicles.

South Korea.name: Seoul Jewish Community
South Korea.description: Small Jewish community in Seoul established during the Korean War. Today approximately 1,000 Jews live in South Korea, mostly expats and military personnel.

Vietnam.name: Chabad Vietnam
Vietnam.description: Chabad-Lubavitch community center serving Jews in Vietnam, operating in Ho Chi Minh City (Saigon) and Hanoi. Vietnam is a popular destination for Israeli backpackers completing military service. Chabad Vietnam provides Shabbat dinners, holiday celebrations, and kosher food to travelers and the small resident Jewish community. The Jewish presence in Vietnam dates to French colonial-era Sephardic merchants.

individuals.name: Menachem Hartman
individuals.bio: Chabad rabbi serving Vietnam (Jewish), providing Jewish services in Ho Chi Minh City.

connections.name: Vietnam Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Vietnam.

connections.name: Chabad-Lubavitch
connections.description: Part of the global Chabad-Lubavitch network, operating in Ho Chi Minh City and Hanoi.

connections.name: Israeli travelers
connections.description: Serves Israeli backpackers and business travelers - Vietnam is a popular post-army destination.

connections.name: Jewish community of Vietnam
connections.description: Serves the small Jewish community and visitors in Vietnam.

Vietnam.name: Jewish Community of Ho Chi Minh City
Vietnam.description: Growing Jewish community in Vietnam serving expatriates, business travelers, and tourists. Operates a Chabad house providing Shabbat dinners, holiday celebrations, and kosher food. The community has grown alongside Vietnam's economic development and increasing Western business presence.

individuals.name: Rabbi Menachem Hartman
individuals.bio: Chabad emissary to Vietnam providing Jewish services and community building in Ho Chi Minh City.

connections.name: Chabad-Lubavitch
connections.description: Part of Chabad's Southeast Asian network.

Nigeria.name: Igbo Jewish Community
Nigeria.description: Community of approximately 30,000 practicing Jews among the Igbo people of southeastern Nigeria, centered in states like Anambra and Abia. Many Igbo Jews claim descent from ancient Israelites based on oral traditions, cultural practices, and naming conventions. Multiple synagogues operate in the region. The community practices Orthodox Judaism and has sought recognition from Israeli religious authorities. Some members have made aliyah to Israel. Scholars debate whether the Jewish connection is ancient heritage or modern adoption.

individuals.name: Howard Gorin
individuals.bio: Rabbi who has visited and supported the Igbo Jewish community in Nigeria, helping with education and formal conversion.

connections.name: Nigeria Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Nigeria.

connections.name: Igbo people
connections.description: The Igbo Jews, numbering an estimated 30,000, claim descent from ancient Israelites.

connections.name: Abayudaya community connection
connections.description: Similar to the Abayudaya in Uganda, the Igbo Jews practice Judaism and seek formal recognition.

connections.name: Gihon Heritage Center
connections.description: The Gihon Heritage Center in Abuja promotes Igbo-Jewish identity.

connections.name: Synagogues in southeast Nigeria
connections.description: Multiple synagogues operate in southeastern Nigeria's Igbo heartland.

Nigeria.name: Jewish Community of Nigeria (Igbo Jews)
Nigeria.description: The Igbo Jewish community in Nigeria traces its heritage to ancient Israelite migrations. Centered in southeastern Nigeria, the community has grown to thousands of members who practice Orthodox Judaism. They have established synagogues, schools, and mikvaot across Igbo land, with growing international recognition from the broader Jewish world.

individuals.name: Remy Ilona
individuals.bio: Nigerian-Jewish author and community leader who has written extensively on the Igbo-Jewish connection.

connections.name: Kulanu
connections.description: Supported by Kulanu organization for emerging Jewish communities.

Zimbabwe.name: Zimbabwe Jewish Community
Zimbabwe.description: Once one of southern Africa's significant Jewish communities, numbering approximately 7,000 in the 1960s during the Rhodesian era. Jews were prominent in business, agriculture, and politics. The community declined sharply from the 1980s onward, particularly after Robert Mugabe's land reform program. Today fewer than 200 Jews remain, split between Harare and Bulawayo. Both cities maintain synagogues, though services are infrequent. Many Zimbabwean Jews emigrated to South Africa, Israel, and Australia.

individuals.name: Moira Chipkin
individuals.bio: Community leader in the Zimbabwe Jewish community, managing affairs as the community has dwindled.

connections.name: Zimbabwe Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Zimbabwe.

connections.name: Bulawayo and Harare
connections.description: Small community split between Bulawayo and Harare, declining from 7,000 in the 1960s to under 200.

connections.name: Rhodesian era
connections.description: The community thrived during the Rhodesian period, with prominent Jewish businesspeople and politicians.

connections.name: Mugabe era emigration
connections.description: Most Jews emigrated during the Mugabe era, particularly after the land reform program.

Zimbabwe.name: Sephardi Hebrew Congregation of Harare
Zimbabwe.description: Historic synagogue in Harare. At its peak in the 1950s-70s, Zimbabwe's Jewish community numbered approximately 7,000. Most emigrated during political upheaval. Approximately 120 Jews remain.

Democratic Republic of Congo.name: Lubumbashi Jewish Community
Democratic Republic of Congo.description: Small Jewish community in Lubumbashi (formerly Elisabethville), capital of the mineral-rich Katanga province in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Established during the Belgian colonial era, many members were Sephardic Jews from Rhodes and other Mediterranean communities involved in the mining industry. Numbered several hundred at its peak. Most emigrated during post-independence upheavals. A synagogue still stands but the community is nearly extinct.

individuals.name: Simone Awerbach
individuals.bio: One of the last remaining members of the Lubumbashi Jewish community in the DRC.

connections.name: Democratic Republic of Congo Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Democratic Republic of Congo.

connections.name: Belgian colonial era
connections.description: Established during the Belgian colonial period in the mineral-rich Katanga province.

connections.name: Mining industry
connections.description: Jewish families were involved in Katanga's mining industry, particularly diamonds and copper.

connections.name: Sephardic roots
connections.description: Many members were Sephardic Jews from Rhodes and other Mediterranean communities.

Democratic Republic of Congo.name: Communaut Juive de Lubumbashi
Democratic Republic of Congo.description: Historic Jewish community in Lubumbashi (formerly Elisabethville), one of the oldest organized Jewish communities in sub-Saharan Africa.

Namibia.name: Windhoek Jewish Community
Namibia.description: Tiny Jewish community in Windhoek, Namibia, numbering approximately 50-100 people. Jews first arrived during the German colonial era (late 19th century), with more arriving from South Africa. The community maintains a small synagogue in Windhoek. Close ties with South Africa's larger Jewish community. Notable for being one of the most remote Jewish communities in the world.

individuals.name: Zvi Gorelick
individuals.bio: Community leader of the small Jewish community of Windhoek, Namibia.

connections.name: Namibia Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Namibia.

connections.name: German colonial era
connections.description: Jews first arrived in Namibia (then German South-West Africa) in the late 19th century.

connections.name: South African connections
connections.description: Close ties with South Africa's larger Jewish community.

connections.name: Windhoek synagogue
connections.description: The Windhoek Jewish community maintains a small synagogue.

Namibia.name: Windhoek Hebrew Congregation
Namibia.description: Small Jewish community in Namibia's capital. Jewish presence dates to German colonial period. Approximately 100 Jews live in Namibia today.

Ghana.name: House of Israel Ghana
Ghana.description: Community of approximately 200-300 people in the Sefwi Wiawso area of western Ghana who practice Judaism. Some claim ancestral connections to the ancient Israelite tribe of Judah through oral traditions. The community has built synagogues and received support from the organization Kulanu and visiting rabbis. Members observe Shabbat, keep kosher, and celebrate Jewish holidays. Represents part of a broader phenomenon of African communities connecting with Judaism.

individuals.name: Aaron Ahomtre Toakyirafa
individuals.bio: Spiritual leader of the House of Israel (Jewish), the practicing Jewish community in Ghana's Sefwi Wiawso area.

connections.name: Ghana Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Ghana.

connections.name: Sefwi Wiawso community
connections.description: Based in the Sefwi Wiawso area of western Ghana.

connections.name: Oral traditions
connections.description: Claim Jewish heritage through oral traditions and cultural practices.

connections.name: Kulanu organization
connections.description: The organization Kulanu has supported Jewish education and practice in the community.

Ghana.name: House of Israel Community
Ghana.description: Community of approximately 1,500 people in Sefwi Wiawso who practice Judaism. Believe they descend from Jews who migrated through the Sahara. Formally recognized by various Jewish organizations.

Egypt.name: Egyptian Jewish Community (historic)
Egypt.description: One of the oldest Jewish communities in the world, dating to the 3rd century BCE. Alexandria was a center of Hellenistic Jewish culture - home to philosopher Philo of Alexandria and the famous Septuagint translation. Moses Maimonides (1138-1204), the greatest medieval Jewish philosopher, lived and worked in Cairo. At its peak in the 1940s, approximately 80,000 Jews lived in Egypt. Most were expelled or fled after 1948 and especially after the 1956 Suez Crisis. Fewer than 10 Jews remain today.

individuals.name: Magda Haroun
individuals.bio: President of the Egyptian Jewish Community (Jewish), managing affairs for the fewer than 10 remaining Jews in Egypt.

connections.name: Egypt Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Egypt.

connections.name: Ancient Alexandria
connections.description: Jewish community in Egypt dates to the 3rd century BCE; Alexandria was a center of Hellenistic Jewish culture.

connections.name: Philo of Alexandria
connections.description: Philo of Alexandria (20 BCE-50 CE), a Jewish philosopher who influenced early Christian thought.

connections.name: 1956 Suez Crisis expulsion
connections.description: Most Egyptian Jews were expelled or fled after the 1956 Suez Crisis and subsequent nationalizations.

connections.name: Maimonides in Cairo
connections.description: Moses Maimonides (1138-1204), the greatest medieval Jewish philosopher, spent most of his life in Cairo.

Egypt.name: Ben Ezra Synagogue (Cairo)
Egypt.description: Ancient synagogue in Old Cairo, famous as the site of the Cairo Geniza - a repository of approximately 400,000 manuscript fragments spanning 1,000 years, discovered in 1896 by Solomon Schechter. The fragments, now mostly at Cambridge University, revolutionized understanding of medieval Jewish, Islamic, and Mediterranean history. Tradition holds that Maimonides prayed here. Restored and reopened by the Egyptian government in 2023 after a major $6.4 million renovation.

individuals.name: Solomon Schechter
individuals.bio: Rabbinical scholar (Jewish, Romanian-born) who discovered and removed the Cairo Geniza - 400,000 manuscript fragments - from Ben Ezra Synagogue in 1896.

connections.name: Egypt Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Egypt.

connections.name: Cairo Geniza
connections.description: The Cairo Geniza - a treasure trove of 400,000 manuscript fragments spanning 1,000 years - was discovered here in 1896.

connections.name: Solomon Schechter
connections.description: Rabbinical scholar Solomon Schechter removed and studied the Geniza fragments, now held at Cambridge University.

connections.name: Egyptian government restoration
connections.description: Restored by the Egyptian government and reopened in 2023 after a major $6.4 million renovation.

connections.name: Maimonides connection
connections.description: Tradition holds that Maimonides prayed at the synagogue.

Egypt.name: Sha'ar Hashamayim Synagogue
Egypt.description: Historic synagogue in Cairo, the largest in the Middle East. Once served a thriving community of 80,000 Egyptian Jews. Egypt's Jewish population has dwindled to fewer than 10. The Egyptian government has invested in restoring Jewish heritage sites.

Egypt.name: Eliyahu Hanavi Synagogue
Egypt.description: Ancient synagogue in Alexandria, Egypt. One of the largest synagogues in the Middle East. Was extensively restored by the Egyptian government in 2020 at a cost of $5.6 million.

Syria.name: Syrian Jewish Heritage (Aleppo/Damascus)
Syria.description: Syria's Jewish community was one of the oldest in the world, with roots in biblical times. Aleppo was custodian of the Aleppo Codex (c. 930 CE), the oldest near-complete Hebrew Bible manuscript. The Great Synagogue of Aleppo (Joab's Synagogue, 5th century) was damaged in the 1947 pogrom. Damascus had an equally ancient community. From approximately 30,000 Jews in the 1940s, nearly all emigrated - most to Brooklyn, NY (now 60,000+ community), Mexico City, and Buenos Aires. Fewer than 10 Jews remain in Syria.

individuals.name: Jack Saul
individuals.bio: Representative of the Syrian Jewish community in Brooklyn (Jewish), which has grown to over 60,000 and preserves Syrian traditions.

connections.name: Syria Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Syria.

connections.name: Aleppo Codex
connections.description: The Aleppo Codex (c. 930 CE), the oldest near-complete manuscript of the Hebrew Bible, was kept in Aleppo for 600 years.

connections.name: Great Synagogue of Aleppo
connections.description: The Great Synagogue of Aleppo (Joab's Synagogue), dating to the 5th century, was damaged in the 1947 Aleppo pogrom.

connections.name: 1947 Aleppo pogrom
connections.description: In 1947, anti-Jewish riots destroyed much of Aleppo's Jewish quarter.

connections.name: Brooklyn Syrian Jewish community
connections.description: Most Syrian Jews now live in Brooklyn, NY (60,000+), Mexico City, and Buenos Aires.

Iraq.name: Babylonian Jewry Heritage Center (Israel)
Iraq.description: Heritage center in Or Yehuda, Israel, preserving the 2,600-year legacy of Babylonian/Iraqi Jewry. Houses artifacts, photographs, and documents from Iraq's Jewish community. Approximately 600,000 Israelis trace their roots to Iraq. The center has been involved in efforts to secure the return of Iraqi Jewish archives - tens of thousands of documents seized by Saddam Hussein's regime, later found by US forces, and controversially returned to Iraq despite Jewish community objections.

individuals.name: Mordechai Ben-Porat
individuals.bio: Israeli politician (Jewish, Iraqi-born) who was involved in organizing the mass immigration of Iraqi Jews to Israel.

connections.name: Iraq Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Iraq.

connections.name: Iraqi Jewish diaspora in Israel
connections.description: Serves the large community of Iraqi-origin Jews in Israel, numbering approximately 600,000.

connections.name: Babylonian Talmud heritage
connections.description: Preserves the legacy of Babylonian Jewish scholarship and the Talmud.

connections.name: Iraqi Jewish archives
connections.description: Advocates for the return of Iraqi Jewish archives seized by the Iraqi government and later recovered by the US.

connections.name: Or Yehuda
connections.description: Located in Or Yehuda, a city near Tel Aviv with a large Iraqi-Jewish population.

Iraq.name: Iraqi Jewish Community (historic)
Iraq.description: One of the most ancient and distinguished Jewish communities, tracing to the Babylonian exile of 586 BCE. Iraqi Jews produced the Babylonian Talmud, the most authoritative text in Rabbinic Judaism. Baghdad was a center of Jewish learning for over 2,500 years. Sir Sassoon Eskell (Jewish) was Iraq's first finance minister. The Farhud pogrom of 1941 was a turning point. In 1950-1951, Operation Ezra and Nehemiah airlifted approximately 120,000 Jews to Israel, effectively ending 2,600 years of continuous Jewish presence. Fewer than 5 Jews remain in Iraq today.

individuals.name: Naim Dangoor
individuals.bio: Sir Naim Dangoor (1914-2015, Jewish), Iraqi-born British businessman and philanthropist who preserved Iraqi Jewish heritage.

connections.name: Iraq Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Iraq.

connections.name: Babylonian Talmud
connections.description: Iraq's Jewish community produced the Babylonian Talmud - the most authoritative text in Rabbinic Judaism.

connections.name: Farhud (1941)
connections.description: The Farhud pogrom of June 1941 killed approximately 180 Jews and injured 1,000 in Baghdad.

connections.name: Operation Ezra and Nehemiah
connections.description: In 1950-1951, approximately 120,000 Iraqi Jews emigrated to Israel in mass airlifts.

connections.name: Sassoon Eskell
connections.description: Sir Sassoon Eskell (Jewish) was Iraq's first minister of finance and helped draft Iraq's constitution.

Iraq.name: Iraqi Jewish Heritage
Iraq.description: The Babylonian Jewish community was one of the oldest and most important in the world, dating to the exile in 586 BCE. The Babylonian Talmud was composed here. In 1948, Iraq had 150,000 Jews; virtually all were expelled or fled in the 1950s.

connections.name: Yad Vashem
connections.description: Both preserve Jewish history and memory

Yemen.name: Yemeni Jewish Community (historic)
Yemen.description: One of the most ancient Jewish communities, claiming roots from the era of King Solomon and the Queen of Sheba. Yemeni Jews preserved unique traditions including the Baladi prayer rite, distinctive silverwork, and ancient Hebrew pronunciation. In 1949-1950, Operation Magic Carpet (On Wings of Eagles) airlifted approximately 49,000 Yemeni Jews to Israel. The "Missing Yemenite Children" affair - hundreds of children who disappeared from Israeli transit camps in the 1950s - remains a painful controversy. Fewer than 50 Jews remain in Yemen today.

individuals.name: Rabbi Yihya Yitzhak Halevi
individuals.bio: Former chief rabbi of Yemen (Jewish), one of the last religious leaders of the ancient Yemeni Jewish community.

connections.name: Yemen Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Yemen.

connections.name: Operation Magic Carpet
connections.description: In 1949-1950, Operation Magic Carpet airlifted approximately 49,000 Yemeni Jews to Israel.

connections.name: Ancient heritage
connections.description: Yemeni Jews claim their community dates to the time of King Solomon and the Queen of Sheba.

connections.name: Yemenite Jewish culture
connections.description: Preserved unique liturgy, music, silverwork traditions, and the Baladi prayer rite.

connections.name: Missing Yemenite children affair
connections.description: Controversy over hundreds of Yemenite Jewish children who disappeared after arriving in Israel in the 1950s.

Yemen.name: Yemenite Jewish Heritage
Yemen.description: One of the world's oldest Jewish communities with a unique liturgical tradition. Operation Magic Carpet (1949-1950) airlifted approximately 49,000 Yemenite Jews to Israel. Fewer than 50 Jews remain in Yemen today.

Libya.name: Libyan Jewish Community (historic)
Libya.description: Jews lived in Libya since at least the 3rd century BCE. Under Italian colonial rule, approximately 38,000 Jews lived there. The community suffered devastating pogroms in 1945 (over 130 killed in Tripoli) and 1948. Most emigrated to Israel in the early 1950s, and the remaining Jews fled during the 1967 Six-Day War. Under Gaddafi, the last Jews were expelled and properties confiscated. No Jews remain in Libya today. The largest Libyan-Jewish community now lives in Israel and Rome.

individuals.name: Raffaello Fellah
individuals.bio: Chairman of the World Organization of Libyan Jews (Jewish), preserving the memory and heritage of Libyan Jewry.

connections.name: Libya Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Libya.

connections.name: Ancient presence
connections.description: Jews lived in Libya since at least the 3rd century BCE under Greek and Roman rule.

connections.name: 1945 Tripoli pogrom
connections.description: In November 1945, over 130 Jews were killed in pogroms across Tripoli.

connections.name: 1967 exodus
connections.description: Nearly all remaining Jews fled Libya during the 1967 Six-Day War.

connections.name: Italian Libya period
connections.description: Under Italian colonial rule, the Jewish community numbered approximately 38,000.

Libya.name: Libyan Jewish Heritage
Libya.description: Jews lived in Libya since at least the 3rd century BCE. The community numbered 38,000 in 1948. All were expelled following anti-Jewish riots in 1945, 1948, and finally in 1967. No Jews remain in Libya.

Lebanon.name: Lebanese Jewish Community (historic)
Lebanon.description: Beirut was once home to a thriving Jewish community of approximately 22,000. Jews played important roles in Lebanese banking, commerce, and politics. The Magen Abraham Synagogue, built in 1926 in the Wadi Abu Jamil neighborhood, was the community's center. The community declined after 1948, and the 1975-1990 civil war drove virtually all remaining Jews out. The Magen Abraham Synagogue was damaged in the civil war and partially restored in 2010. Fewer than 30 Jews are believed to remain in Lebanon.

individuals.name: Isaac Arazi
individuals.bio: One of the last known remaining Jews in Lebanon, whose family once thrived in Beirut's vibrant Jewish quarter.

connections.name: Lebanon Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Lebanon.

connections.name: Beirut Jewish golden age
connections.description: In the 1950s-60s, Beirut's Jewish community thrived with synagogues, schools, and businesses.

connections.name: Magen Abraham Synagogue
connections.description: The Magen Abraham Synagogue in Beirut, built in 1926, was heavily damaged during the civil war.

connections.name: Lebanese civil war
connections.description: The 1975-1990 Lebanese Civil War drove virtually all remaining Jews out of Lebanon.

connections.name: Isaac Sasson
connections.description: The Jewish community once played a significant role in Beirut's banking and commerce.

Lebanon.name: Maghen Abraham Synagogue
Lebanon.description: Historic synagogue in Wadi Abu Jamil, the traditional Jewish quarter of Beirut. Damaged during the Lebanese Civil War. Restoration completed in 2010 though Lebanon's Jewish community has almost entirely emigrated.

Myanmar.name: Musmeah Yeshua Synagogue (Yangon)
Myanmar.description: The only functioning synagogue in Myanmar, built in 1896 in downtown Yangon by Baghdadi Jewish merchants during British colonial rule. Myanmar (Burma) once had a Jewish community of approximately 2,500. For decades, the synagogue was maintained by Moses Samuels, one of the last remaining Jews, who became its self-appointed caretaker and guide. Fewer than 20 Jews remain in Myanmar today. The synagogue is a Yangon heritage site, visited by tourists as a symbol of the country's multicultural past.

individuals.name: Moses Samuels
individuals.bio: Self-appointed caretaker of the Musmeah Yeshua Synagogue (Jewish), one of the last Jews in Myanmar, dedicated decades to preserving the synagogue.

connections.name: Myanmar Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Myanmar.

connections.name: Baghdadi Jewish community
connections.description: Built by Baghdadi Jewish merchants who arrived in Burma during British colonial rule.

connections.name: 1896 construction
connections.description: Built in 1896, it remains the only functioning synagogue in Myanmar.

connections.name: Moses Samuels
connections.description: For decades, the synagogue was maintained by Moses Samuels, one of the last Jews in Myanmar.

Myanmar.name: Musmeah Yeshua Synagogue
Myanmar.description: The last remaining synagogue in Myanmar, located in downtown Yangon. Built in 1896 by Baghdadi Jewish traders, it is an important heritage site reflecting the once-thriving Jewish community of Burma. The synagogue has been restored and serves as both a place of worship and a museum attracting tourists from around the world.

individuals.name: Moses Samuels
individuals.bio: Longtime caretaker and trustee of the Musmeah Yeshua Synagogue, preserving Jewish heritage in Myanmar.

connections.name: World Monuments Fund
connections.description: Received preservation support from international heritage organizations.

Myanmar.name: Musmeah Yeshua Synagogue
Myanmar.description: Historic synagogue in Yangon, Myanmar, the last functioning synagogue in the country. Built by Baghdadi Jewish traders. Only a handful of Jews remain in Myanmar.

Curaao.name: Mikv Israel-Emanuel Synagogue
Curaao.description: The oldest continuously functioning synagogue in the Western Hemisphere, founded in 1651 by Portuguese Jews who arrived via Amsterdam. Located in Willemstad, Curaao. Features a distinctive sand floor - one of only two sand-floor synagogues in the world (the other being in Jamaica). The congregation follows Sephardic rites. The adjacent Jewish Cultural Historical Museum documents over 350 years of Curaao Jewish history. Jews played a crucial role in the island's trade economy, particularly as maritime merchants.

individuals.name: Rabbi Haim Mendes Chumaceiro
individuals.bio: 19th-century rabbi of Mikv Israel-Emanuel (Jewish), leading the oldest continuous congregation in the Western Hemisphere.

connections.name: Curaao Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Curaao.

connections.name: Oldest continuous synagogue in Americas
connections.description: Founded in 1651, it is the oldest continuously functioning synagogue in the Western Hemisphere.

connections.name: Amsterdam Portuguese Synagogue
connections.description: Congregation descended from Portuguese Jews who came via Amsterdam.

connections.name: Sand floor tradition
connections.description: Features a sand floor, one of only two remaining sand-floor synagogues in the world.

connections.name: Curaao Jewish history
connections.description: Curaao Jews were instrumental in the island's trade economy from the 17th century.

Suriname.name: Jodensavanne Archaeological Site
Suriname.description: Archaeological site of Jodensavanne (Jewish Savannah), one of the earliest autonomous Jewish settlements in the New World, founded c. 1665 along the Suriname River. Sephardic Jews ran sugar plantations under Dutch colonial rule. The ruins of the Beraha VeSalom synagogue (c. 1685) are among the oldest synagogue remains in the Americas. On the UNESCO World Heritage tentative list. The site demonstrates the unique autonomy granted to Jews in the Dutch colonies, including their own courts and civil authority.

individuals.name: Samuel Nassy
individuals.bio: Sephardic Jewish plantation owner who was among the founders of the Jodensavanne settlement in 17th-century Suriname.

connections.name: Suriname Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Suriname.

connections.name: First Jewish settlement in the Americas
connections.description: Jodensavanne (Jewish Savannah) was one of the earliest autonomous Jewish settlements in the New World, founded c. 1665.

connections.name: Beraha VeSalom Synagogue
connections.description: Ruins of the Beraha VeSalom synagogue, the oldest synagogue in the Americas.

connections.name: Sephardic plantation owners
connections.description: Sephardic Jews ran sugar plantations in Suriname under Dutch colonial rule.

connections.name: UNESCO tentative list
connections.description: On the UNESCO World Heritage tentative list for its unique historical significance.

Suriname.name: Neve Shalom Synagogue (Paramaribo)
Suriname.description: Synagogue in Paramaribo, Suriname, part of the UNESCO World Heritage-listed historic inner city. Suriname's Jewish community, though small today (approximately 200), has a history dating to the 17th century when Sephardic Jews established sugar plantations. The wooden synagogue reflects the unique architectural traditions of colonial Suriname. Uniquely, the synagogue stands next to a mosque - a symbol of the interfaith tolerance for which Suriname is known.

individuals.name: Ren Fernandes
individuals.bio: Community leader of the small Jewish community of Paramaribo, Suriname.

connections.name: Suriname Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Suriname.

connections.description: Serves Suriname's remaining Jewish community in the capital Paramaribo.

connections.name: Dutch colonial heritage
connections.description: Built during the Dutch colonial period, reflecting the prosperity of Suriname's Jewish community.

Gibraltar.name: Jewish Community of Gibraltar
Gibraltar.description: Jewish community of approximately 600 in the British overseas territory of Gibraltar - one of the highest per-capita Jewish populations in the world. The Great Synagogue (Nefutsot Yehudah), established in 1724, is one of the oldest on the Iberian Peninsula. The community traces to refugees from the Spanish Inquisition and North African Jews. Given Gibraltar's strategic location, the community has historical ties to both British and Moroccan Jewry.

individuals.name: Rabbi Ronnie Hassid
individuals.bio: Chief Rabbi of Gibraltar (Jewish), leading one of the world's highest per-capita Jewish communities.

connections.name: Gibraltar Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Gibraltar.

connections.name: British overseas territory
connections.description: As a British territory, Gibraltar's Jews have strong connections to UK Jewish institutions.
