connections.description: The Great Synagogue (Nefutsot Yehudah, 1724) is one of the oldest on the Iberian Peninsula.

connections.name: Morocco connection
connections.description: Given Gibraltar's location, the community has historical ties to Moroccan Jewry across the strait.

Gibraltar.name: Gibraltar Hebrew Community
Gibraltar.description: One of the oldest Jewish communities in the British Overseas Territories. Approximately 600 Jews live in Gibraltar. Four synagogues serve the community.

Taiwan.name: Jewish Community of Taiwan
Taiwan.description: Small Jewish community of approximately 200-300 people in Taiwan, centered in Taipei. Includes American and Israeli expats, businesspeople, and academics. Chabad operates in Taipei. Taiwan and Israel share informal but significant technological and trade relationships, particularly in semiconductors and cybersecurity. The Taipei Jewish Community maintains regular services and holiday celebrations.

individuals.name: Shlomi Tabib
individuals.bio: Chabad rabbi serving Taiwan (Jewish), leading the small community in Taipei.

connections.name: Taiwan Jewish community
connections.description: Part of the Jewish community and institutional presence in Taiwan.

connections.description: Taiwan and Israel share informal but warm technological and trade relations.

Taiwan.name: Taiwan Jewish Community
Taiwan.description: Small Jewish community in Taipei, Taiwan, numbering approximately 300. Operates a community center and synagogue.

Taiwan.name: TSMC (Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company)
Taiwan.description: World's largest contract semiconductor manufacturer. Fabricates the most advanced chips for Apple, Nvidia, AMD, and others. Market cap exceeds $800 billion. The most critical company in global technology.

individuals.name: Morris Chang
individuals.bio: Chinese-American Taiwanese businessman who founded TSMC and is called the 'Father of semiconductor manufacturing.'

International.name: European Jewish Congress
International.description: The representative body of Jewish communities across Europe, advocating for Jewish interests at the European Union, OSCE, and Council of Europe. Under long-serving president Moshe Kantor (Jewish, Russian-born), the EJC focused on combating antisemitism, promoting security, and defending religious freedoms. Represents communities from over 40 European countries. Works on issues including Holocaust remembrance, Israel-Europe relations, and addressing rising antisemitism.

individuals.name: Ariel Muzicant
individuals.bio: Austrian-Israeli businessman, VP of the European Jewish Congress.

connections.description: Regional affiliate of the World Jewish Congress.

connections.name: OSCE
connections.description: Works with the OSCE on combating antisemitism across Europe.

International.name: JDC (American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee) - Global
International.description: Founded in 1914, the JDC (known as "the Joint") is the world's leading Jewish humanitarian organization, operating in over 70 countries. During WWII, funded rescue operations including the Kindertransport. After the war, helped resettle survivors. After 1989, led the revival of Jewish life across the former Soviet Union, rebuilding communities from the Baltic to Central Asia. In Israel, runs social welfare programs serving 150,000 elderly and disadvantaged. Has aided millions of people over its 110+ year history.

individuals.name: Ariel Zwang
individuals.bio: CEO of JDC (Jewish), the world's leading Jewish humanitarian organization, serving in 70+ countries.

connections.name: Israel social programs

International.name: Keren Hayesod - United Israel Appeal
International.description: Founded in 1920 at the London Zionist Conference, Keren Hayesod is the principal fundraising organization for Israel, operating in over 45 countries. One of Israel's national institutions alongside the Jewish Agency and JNF. Albert Einstein was among its early supporters. Raises hundreds of millions of dollars for immigration (aliyah), absorption of new immigrants, and social programs in Israel. Has facilitated the immigration of over 3 million Jews to Israel since its founding.

individuals.bio: World Chairman of Keren Hayesod (Jewish), the principal fundraising organization for Israel.

connections.name: Jewish Agency
connections.description: Major funder of the Jewish Agency for Israel's immigration and absorption programs.

International.name: Aleph Institute
International.description: Founded in 1981 at the direction of the Lubavitcher Rebbe, Rabbi Menachem Mendel Schneerson, to serve "the Jews that everyone forgets" - prisoners, military personnel, and their families. Provides Jewish chaplaincy to US military worldwide, religious services to Jewish prisoners, and advocates for criminal justice reform. Also offers reentry programs for released prisoners. Affiliated with Chabad-Lubavitch. One of the few Jewish organizations focused on incarcerated individuals.

individuals.name: Rabbi Sholom Lipskar
individuals.bio: Founder and president of the Aleph Institute (Jewish), established at the Lubavitcher Rebbe's direction to serve Jewish prisoners.

International.name: Aish HaTorah
International.description: Orthodox Jewish outreach organization founded in 1974 by Rabbi Noach Weinberg in Jerusalem. Its building overlooks the Western Wall. One of the most prominent "kiruv" (outreach) organizations, targeting secular and unaffiliated Jews through programs like Discovery Seminars, Fellowships, and the Aish.com website (one of the most-visited Jewish sites). Also runs Hasbara Fellowships for Israel advocacy on college campuses. Branches in over 35 countries worldwide.

individuals.name: Rabbi Noach Weinberg
individuals.bio: Founder of Aish HaTorah (1930-2009, Jewish), one of the most influential Jewish outreach (kiruv) leaders in modern history.

International.name: Limmud International
International.description: International Jewish learning movement that started in the UK in 1980. Uniquely volunteer-driven - no one is paid to present or attend. Limmud events now occur in over 40 countries, bringing together Jews of all denominations for intensive weekends of learning, debating, and cultural exchange. Sessions cover everything from Talmud to technology, politics to poetry. The model has been called "the most significant development in Jewish education in recent decades."

individuals.name: Clive Lawton
individuals.bio: Co-founder of Limmud (Jewish), the volunteer-run Jewish learning movement now operating in 40+ countries.

International.name: March of the Living
International.description: Annual educational program where thousands of young people from around the world march the 3-kilometer route from Auschwitz to Birkenau on Yom HaShoah (Holocaust Remembrance Day), then travel to Israel for Yom Ha'atzmaut (Independence Day). Founded in 1988, over 300,000 people have participated. The symbolic journey from the site of destruction to the Jewish homeland aims to teach about the Holocaust and Jewish continuity. Participants include survivors, educators, and dignitaries from 40+ countries.

individuals.name: Phyllis Heideman
individuals.bio: President of the International March of the Living (Jewish), leading the annual march from Auschwitz to Birkenau.

International.name: Ohr Somayach
International.description: Orthodox yeshiva founded in 1970 in Jerusalem by Rabbis Nota Schiller and Mendel Weinbach, pioneering the concept of a yeshiva for "baalei teshuva" - Jews with little or no religious background seeking to learn about their heritage. Main campuses in Jerusalem and Monsey, New York. The Ohr Lagolah Leadership Training program trains rabbis for underserved Jewish communities worldwide. Has educated tens of thousands since its founding. Known for intellectual rigor combined with welcoming atmosphere.

International.name: Shalom Hartman Institute
International.description: Founded in 1976 in Jerusalem by Rabbi David Hartman (Canadian-born Orthodox rabbi and philosopher). Known for its pluralistic approach - bringing Orthodox, Conservative, Reform, and secular Jews together for rigorous intellectual study and dialogue. Led by Donniel Hartman, David's son, who is a leading Jewish public intellectual. Runs influential programs for rabbis, educators, and lay leaders from across denominations. The Institute's scholarship on Jewish identity, Israel, and modernity shaped a generation of Jewish thought.

International.name: World ORT
International.description: Global Jewish education network founded in St. Petersburg, Russia in 1880 to provide vocational training for impoverished Jews. ORT (from Russian: Obshchestvo Remeslenogo i Zemledelcheskogo Truda - Society for Trades and Agricultural Labor) now operates schools and programs in over 35 countries serving 300,000+ students annually. Focus areas include STEM education, technology training, and workforce development. Major operations in Israel, Latin America, Africa, and the former Soviet Union.

International.name: International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance (IHRA)
International.description: Intergovernmental body with 35 member countries committed to Holocaust education, remembrance, and research. Grew from the 2000 Stockholm International Forum on the Holocaust. Most influential for its Working Definition of Antisemitism, adopted by hundreds of governments, universities, and institutions worldwide - though also debated for its examples relating to criticism of Israel. Partners with UNESCO and maintains networks of scholars, educators, and museums.

individuals.name: Kerry Whigham
individuals.bio: Scholar involved with IHRA, the 35-member intergovernmental body promoting Holocaust education. IHRA's antisemitism definition has been widely adopted.

International.name: Claims Conference (Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany)
International.description: Founded in 1951, the Claims Conference has negotiated over $80 billion in compensation from Germany for Holocaust survivors - the largest restitution program in history. The 1952 Luxembourg Agreement, negotiated by Nahum Goldmann, established the framework. Distributes direct payments and funds social services for approximately 260,000 survivors in 83 countries. Also recovers stolen Jewish property, including artwork. Has been both praised for its work and criticized for bureaucratic issues.

individuals.name: Gideon Taylor
individuals.bio: President of the Claims Conference (Jewish), overseeing distribution of over $80 billion in German reparations.

International.name: International March of the Living
International.description: The international dimension of the March of the Living program, coordinating delegations from 40+ countries to participate in the annual march from Auschwitz to Birkenau. Includes extended educational programming, survivor testimonies, and visits to other Holocaust sites in Poland. As the number of living survivors diminishes, the program increasingly emphasizes passing the torch of memory to new generations through recorded testimonies and interactive education.

International.name: World Mizrachi
International.description: The central organization of the Religious Zionist movement, founded in 1902 in Vilna by Rabbi Yitzchak Yaakov Reines. Mizrachi (abbreviation of "Merkaz Ruchani" - Spiritual Center) advocates combining Torah observance with Zionism. Affiliated with Bnei Akiva, the world's largest Religious Zionist youth movement (125,000 members in 40+ countries). Runs programs promoting Torah education, Israel engagement, and religious settlement. Represents the ideological bridge between Orthodoxy and Jewish nationhood.

International.name: Maccabi World Union
International.description: International Jewish sports organization founded in 1921, organizing the Maccabiah Games - the "Jewish Olympics" - held in Israel every four years since 1932. Recognized by the International Olympic Committee. Named after Judah Maccabee, the ancient Jewish military leader. Over 10,000 athletes from 80+ countries compete. Also runs youth programs and Maccabi sports clubs in 60+ countries promoting Jewish identity through athletics. The 2022 Maccabiah was the largest ever.

Tanzania.name: Jewish Community of Dar es Salaam
Tanzania.description: Small but historic Jewish community in Tanzania dating back to World War II-era refugees. The community maintains cultural connections and hosts Shabbat gatherings. Members include descendants of European refugees, Israeli expatriates, and foreign diplomats.

individuals.name: David Elias

Madagascar.description: Emerging Jewish community in Madagascar with several hundred members who have adopted Judaism. The community maintains synagogues and study centers in Antananarivo and other cities, and has sought recognition from international Jewish bodies.

Madagascar.description: Small Jewish community in Antananarivo. Notably, the Nazis briefly considered the 'Madagascar Plan' to forcibly relocate all European Jews to the island.

Madagascar.name: Community of Jewish Descent in Madagascar
Madagascar.description: Small community in Madagascar where some people claim Jewish ancestry. The 'Madagascar Plan' was an abandoned Nazi proposal to relocate European Jews to the island.

connections.name: World Jewish Congress
connections.description: Both are Jewish representative organizations

Zambia.name: Council for Zambian Jewry
Zambia.description: Jewish community organization in Zambia, based in Lusaka. Once numbered several hundred, the community has shrunk significantly but maintains communal facilities.

Zambia.name: Lusaka Hebrew Congregation
Zambia.description: Historic Jewish congregation in Zambia's capital. Jewish presence in Zambia dates to early 20th century. Small community of approximately 50 families remains.

Botswana.name: Jewish Community of Botswana
Botswana.description: Small Jewish community in Gaborone, Botswana, consisting of approximately 100 members, many involved in the diamond industry.

Lithuania.name: Lithuanian Jewish Community (LJC)
Lithuania.description: Community organization representing Jews in Lithuania. Before WWII, Lithuania was a major center of Jewish learning (the 'Jerusalem of the North'). Vilna (Vilnius) had one of the greatest Jewish populations in Europe. Approximately 95% of Lithuanian Jews perished in the Holocaust.

Lithuania.name: Vilna Gaon Jewish State Museum
Lithuania.description: Museum in Vilnius dedicated to the history and culture of Lithuanian Jews. Named after the Vilna Gaon, the great 18th-century rabbinic scholar.

individuals.name: Vilna Gaon
individuals.bio: Rabbi Elijah ben Solomon Zalman, one of the most influential Jewish scholars of modern times.

connections.name: Yad Vashem
connections.description: Both preserve Jewish history and memory

Latvia.name: Jews in Latvia Museum
Latvia.description: Museum in Riga documenting the history of the Jewish community in Latvia. Before WWII, Jews constituted about 5% of Latvia's population. Most perished in the Holocaust.

connections.name: Yad Vashem
connections.description: Both preserve Jewish history and memory

Estonia.name: Jewish Community of Estonia
Estonia.description: Small Jewish community of approximately 2,500 in Tallinn. One of the few European countries where Jews received cultural autonomy in the interwar period (1926).

Belarus.name: Union of Belarusian Jewish Public Associations and Communities
Belarus.description: Representative body of Belarusian Jews. Belarus was a major center of Jewish life before WWII, home to cities like Minsk, Brest, and Pinsk with large Jewish populations. Approximately 10,000-20,000 Jews remain.

connections.name: World Jewish Congress
connections.description: Both are Jewish representative organizations

Kazakhstan.name: Jewish Community of Kazakhstan
Kazakhstan.description: Jewish community in Kazakhstan, centered in Almaty and Nur-Sultan. Approximately 3,500 Jews live in Kazakhstan, many descended from Soviet-era relocations.

Indonesia.name: Surabaya Jewish Community
Indonesia.description: Historic Jewish community in Surabaya, East Java. Once had an active synagogue and community. Indonesia is the world's largest Muslim-majority country with a very small Jewish presence.

Iceland.name: Icelandic Jewish Community
Iceland.description: Small Jewish community in Iceland, numbering approximately 100-200. One of the smallest Jewish communities in Europe.

Democratic Republic of the Congo.name: Jewish Community of Lubumbashi
Democratic Republic of the Congo.description: Historic Jewish community in the Katanga mining region. Sephardic Jews from Rhodes and Ashkenazi Jews settled in the Congo for mining opportunities. Few Jews remain today.

Barbados.name: Nidhe Israel Synagogue
Barbados.description: Historic synagogue in Bridgetown, Barbados. One of the oldest synagogues in the Western Hemisphere. Sephardic Jews played a major role in establishing the sugar industry. The mikveh was rediscovered in 2008.

U.S. Virgin Islands.name: Hebrew Congregation of St. Thomas
U.S. Virgin Islands.description: One of the oldest synagogues in continuous use under the American flag. Located in Charlotte Amalie. Features a sand-covered floor and is a National Historic Landmark.

Tajikistan.name: Jewish Community of Dushanbe
Tajikistan.description: Small remnant Jewish community in Tajikistan. Once home to a significant Bukharan Jewish population. Most emigrated in the 1990s. Fewer than 100 Jews remain.

Nepal.name: Chabad of Kathmandu
Nepal.description: Chabad center in Kathmandu serving Israeli backpackers and tourists. Hosts massive Passover seders (over 1,500 attendees) - one of the largest in the world. Nepal has no indigenous Jewish community.

Cambodia.name: Chabad of Phnom Penh
Cambodia.description: Jewish center in Phnom Penh serving tourists and expats. Cambodia has a tiny but growing Jewish community.

Laos.name: Chabad of Vientiane
Laos.description: Chabad center in the capital of Laos, one of the newest Chabad houses in the world. Serves Israeli backpackers traveling Southeast Asia.

Sri Lanka.name: Jewish Community of Sri Lanka
Sri Lanka.description: Small Jewish community with roots in Dutch colonial period. The former synagogue in Galle Fort still exists as a commercial building.

Papua New Guinea.name: Jewish Community of Port Moresby
Papua New Guinea.description: Tiny Jewish community in Papua New Guinea, one of the most remote in the world. Fewer than 20 Jews live in the country.

Fiji.name: Jewish Community of Suva
Fiji.description: Small Jewish community in Fiji with roots going back to WWII when Jewish servicemen were stationed in the Pacific.

Malta.name: Jewish Heritage of Malta
Malta.description: Malta has Jewish roots dating to Roman times. A medieval Jewish cemetery was found in Rabat. The Jewish community was expelled in 1492. Today a small community of approximately 120 exists.

Luxembourg.name: Jewish Community of Luxembourg
Luxembourg.description: Small community of approximately 1,200 Jews. The Luxembourg synagogue, destroyed by the Nazis, was rebuilt in 1953.

Monaco.name: Association Culturelle Isralite de Monaco
Monaco.description: Jewish community organization in Monaco. The principality has a small Jewish population and one synagogue.

Andorra.name: Jewish Community of Andorra
Andorra.description: Tiny Jewish community in the Pyrenean principality. Approximately 100 Jews live in Andorra. No synagogue; community members travel to Barcelona or Toulouse.

Cyprus.name: Jewish Community of Cyprus
Cyprus.description: Ancient Jewish presence dating to Hellenistic times. After WWII, British detention camps in Cyprus held approximately 52,000 Jewish Holocaust survivors trying to reach Palestine. Today a community of several hundred.

Bosnia and Herzegovina.name: Jewish Community of Sarajevo
Bosnia and Herzegovina.description: Historic Sephardic community. Home of the famous Sarajevo Haggadah, a 14th-century illuminated manuscript. The Jewish community survived the 1992-95 siege of Sarajevo. Approximately 700 Jews remain.

North Macedonia.name: Jewish Community of Skopje
North Macedonia.description: Sephardic community established after the Spanish expulsion. On March 11, 1943, nearly all 7,148 Jews of Macedonia were deported to Treblinka. Today approximately 200 Jews remain.

Albania.name: Jewish Community of Albania
Albania.description: Albania is the only European country that had a larger Jewish population after WWII than before. Albanians of all faiths protected Jews based on the code of besa (honor). Approximately 200 Jews live in Albania today.

Slovenia.name: Jewish Community of Ljubljana
Slovenia.description: Small Jewish community in Slovenia. Jews were expelled from Ljubljana in 1515. The community was reconstituted after WWII. Approximately 300 Jews live in Slovenia.

Slovakia.name: Jewish Community of Bratislava
Slovakia.description: Bratislava (Pressburg) was one of the most important centers of Jewish learning in Europe. Rabbi Moses Sofer (the Chatam Sofer) established his famous yeshiva there. Before WWII 15,000 Jews lived there. Approximately 2,000 remain in Slovakia.

individuals.name: Moses Sofer
individuals.bio: Leading Orthodox rabbi known as the Chatam Sofer, head of the Pressburg Yeshiva, one of the most influential rabbis of the modern era.

Montenegro.name: Jewish Community of Montenegro
Montenegro.description: Tiny Jewish community in Montenegro. Most Jews lived in coastal towns under Venetian rule. Approximately 200 Jews live in Montenegro today.
